column1: A series of town hall forums presented by USA TODAY
column2: the USA TODAY Network and Seacoastonline for Republican presidential hopefuls are set to take place in Exeter
column3: New Hampshire this week.

column1: The forums will take place at Exeter Town Hall
column2: where many former presidents
column3: including Donald Trump and Barack Obama
column4: have campaigned. The forums are scheduled to take place Oct. 10-15.

column1: Former Arkansas Gov. Asa Hutchinson kicked off the event at 5 p.m. Tuesday and you can watch the replay here.
Exeter Town Hall has the distinction of being the only location remaining in New Hampshire where Abraham Lincoln spoke in 1860
column2: just months before launching his presidential campaign.

column1: Voters who attend will have a chance to directly ask candidates the questions on their mind and receive in-person responses.
The town hall forums will be streamed on USA TODAY and on USA TODAY Network outlets including Seacoastonline.com
column2: Portsmouth Herald
column3: Hampton Union
column4: Foster's Daily Democrat and Exeter News-Letter.

column1: The five candidates that have committed to meeting with voters are Asa Hutchinson
column2: Nikki Haley
column3: Doug Burgum
column4: Mike Pence and Vivek Ramaswamy.

column1: Here is the full schedule for the Exeter Town Hall forums this week. All times are Eastern.
The forums are free and open to the public on a first-come
column2: first-serve basis. At the start of the forums
column3: candidates make their brief opening remarks before proceeding to answer questions from the audience and engage in a meaningful dialogue about various issues.

column1: The attacks came by land
column2: sea
column3: air – and online.

column1: Terror propaganda − violent videos and graphic images of kidnappings and murders of civilians and soldiers that flooded social media from the deadly cross-border incursion into Israel − was a key element in Hamas’ military campaign
column2: said Graham Brookie
column3: senior director of the Atlantic Council’s Digital Forensic Research Lab.

column1: Hamas streamed from the war zone “in closer to real-time than in past conflicts
column2: ” indicating that the online strategy “was an essential part of the overall planning for their attack on Israel” to take advantage of how hyperconnected Israel is with its widespread use of smartphones and social media
column3: Brookie said.

column1: Veterans of conflict zones on Brookie’s team tracking Hamas' digital footprint were struck by the ferocity and volume of the footage
column2: the likes of which he said it had never seen
column3: he said.

column1: The effects could become more grave if Hamas makes good on a threat to broadcast executions of hostages
column2: Brookie said. Some Hamas officials have since walked back the threat.

column1: Spreading propaganda on social media networks – especially those with more lax moderation systems – is a low-cost and highly effective tactic that is increasingly being deployed by terrorist groups
column2: said Colin P. Clarke
column3: director of research at the Soufan Group
column4: a global intelligence and security consultancy.

column1: The videos and images from the deadly attacks posted by Hamas-affiliated accounts were shared by Hamas allies and unwitting participants around the globe
column2: Clarke said.

column1: The tactic is pulled from the playbooks of the Islamic State and al-Qaida
column2: which experts said pioneered the viral form of psychological warfare by livestreaming beheadings and other graphic footage.

column1: “This is the nature of asymmetric warfare – you've got to utilize tools that are going to make you seem bigger and more powerful than you are
column2: ” Clarke said. “For Hamas
column3: it costs them nothing to videotape something and send it out there
column4: and now everyone thinks that they're creeping around every corner.”

column1: Hamas fired off posts from official accounts on the encrypted messaging and social media app Telegram that ricocheted to X
column2: formerly Twitter
column3: and beyond.

column1: Telegram – which allows messaging between users but also has a “Channel” function that works similarly to X – has a long history of being used by terrorists
column2: among them the Islamic State
column3: or ISIS. The platform
column4: often labeled by extremism experts as “Terrorgram
column5: ” is increasingly embraced by domestic extremists in the U.S. in recent years because of its almost nonexistent moderation.

column1: “As soon as something posts on Telegram
column2: we see this crossflow of content to mainstream platforms
column3: either intentionally or just through the oxygen of amplification
column4: ” Brookie said.

column1: X
column2: which gutted its trust and safety teams under new owner Elon Musk
column3: was unprepared for the wave of terror propaganda that then spread to other social media platforms and messaging apps like WhatsApp.

column1: This week
column2: X said it was removing newly created Hamas-affiliated accounts and coordinating with industry peers “to try and prevent terrorist content from being distributed online.” It also recommended that people adjust their sensitive media settings if they don’t want to see disturbing content.

column1: The U.K. summoned social media executives Wednesday to demand platforms remove violent content of the Hamas attacks on Israel.
Telegram and X did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
If social media sites continue to erode guardrails and safeguards
column2: Clarke warned
column3: what is happening today will get worse.

column1: “This is just the facet of what’s called ‘fourth generation warfare
column2: ’ or ‘modern warfare’ in this era
column3: ” he said. “So
column4: whatever the next conflict is
column5: it doesn't really matter
column6: you're going to see this on steroids.”

column1: Once propaganda and disinformation reaches X
column2: the platform is allowing it to be shared and even monetized
column3: a report from the Tech Transparency Project found.

column1: The report
column2: an advance copy of which was provided exclusively to USA TODAY
column3: found several premium subscriber accounts – which pay a fee of $8 a month to the platform – sharing Hamas propaganda including violent and graphic images of the attacks on Israel.

column1: According to the report
column2: some video content appears to violate X’s “violent and hateful entities policy
column3: ” which prohibits promotion of terrorist organizations and their propaganda. It also appears to violate an X policy stating that the platform will remove accounts sharing content produced by terrorists
column4: the report states.

column1: Despite X’s announcement that it was working to remove Hamas-affiliated accounts
column2: TTP researchers "found no evidence that X had restricted the accounts sharing the Hamas attack videos
column3: ” the report says. It also notes that in some cases
column4: X ran advertisements in the comments under the video posts.

column1: The TTP report found several instances of “verified” X users
column2: some with more than 500
column3: 000 followers
column4: spreading uncensored Hamas propaganda videos.

column1: One clip posted to X shows bodycam footage of Hamas militants going room-to-room in an Israeli military base firing automatic weapons. Bloodied bodies lie on the ground in the video
column2: which has been watched more than 60
column3: 000 times.

column1: “It's been nearly 10 years since the Islamic State made heavy use of social media to amplify its propaganda and recruitment efforts. Although some platforms have improved at reducing the spread of Islamic State content
column2: today we see Hamas deploying very similar tactics on X
column3: ” TTP director Katie A Paul told USA TODAY. “The company has monetized the spread of Hamas propaganda despite its clear violations of X policy. X needs to effectively enforce the rules it has on the books as the conflict continues.”

column1: Brookie says social media platforms are being forced to grapple with a multi-front crisis to shield users from terror propaganda
column2: misleading information
column3: hate speech and violent and graphic images and footage.

column1: “The amount of content is going to be more than any team
column2: whether it’s at a platform or a research team like mine
column3: or a journalism outlet or organization could possibly sift through
column4: ” he said. “That changes the frame from who’s doing well to who’s doing the least bad in a hard situation.”

column1: The major platforms are working with the Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism (GIFCT) which was founded by Facebook
column2: Microsoft
column3: X and YouTube in 2017 to prevent terrorists and violent extremists from exploiting digital platforms.

column1: “In this rapidly evolving situation
column2: we continue to work with our members to identify and follow trends in content and activity online related to terrorist and violent extremist actors involved in the offline violence
column3: ” GIFCT said in a statement. “This includes the possibility that a range of terrorist and violent extremist networks and groups may seek to exploit the conflict for their own purposes
column4: as we have seen in past events.”

column1: Facebook
column2: YouTube and TikTok say they have poured resources into moderating content from the Israel-Hamas war.

column1: “After the terrorist attacks by Hamas on Israel on Saturday
column2: we quickly established a special operations center staffed with experts
column3: including fluent Hebrew and Arabic speakers
column4: to closely monitor and respond to this rapidly evolving situation
column5: ” Meta said in a statement.

column1: The major platforms prohibit content produced by terrorist organizations including Hamas as well as footage showing hostages.

column1: Sen. Robert Menendez was charged Thursday with conspiracy to act as a foreign agent

column1: Menendez and two co-defendants
column2: wife Nadine Menendez and Wael Hana
column3: were charged with conspiracy to represent the government of Egypt and Egyptian officials. The indictment cites the three with meeting at Manhattan restaurants with Egyptian officials on June 30
column5: and Sept. 21
column7: as part of the alleged conspiracy.

column1: The Federal Agents Registration Act requires people who represent foreign governments trying to influence U.S. policy to register with the Justice Department. Violations carry a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250
column2: 000 fine.

column1: Menendez and his co-defendants have pleaded not guilty to the charges and he remains in the Senate
column2: although he surrendered his chairmanship of the Foreign Relations Committee until the case is resolved. The trial is scheduled May 6.

column1: A former Hamas leader’s call for protests around the world has some Americans who are planning travel in the coming days weighing agonizing choices days after the militant group's deadly attack on Israeli communities.

Khaled Meshaal’s recordings reviewed by Reuters have reverberated on social media and stoked rumors that a “jihad” in the “squares and streets of the Arab and Islamic world” could lead to violence Friday.
For those Americans in Israel who want to leave
column2: the White House said the U.S. government will arrange charter flights to Europe starting Friday.

column1: Natalie Sanandaji
column3: from Long Island
column4: New York
column5: was in Greece on Thursday deciding on flight options home.

column1: “I’m hoping to get home as soon as possible

column3: tomorrow
column4: ” Sanandaji
column5: who was in Israel during the attack
column6: told USA TODAY. “People are telling us to avoid crowded places and I’m looking at these layovers in Egypt or London or Paris and those are high-risk places.”

the agency warns.
The uncertainty follows a trip to Israel by U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken, who met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Tel Aviv in a show of support.
In the U.S., National Security Council spokesman John Kirby said federal, state and local authorities are working to identify and disrupt any threats toward the Jewish community. He said 14 Americans remain missing in Israel.

A baby, an infant, riddled with bullets. Soldiers beheaded. Young people burned alive in their cars or in their highway runs,'' Blinken said. It's simply depravity in the worst imaginable way.''

Sagui Dekel-Chen

column1: Hamas has vowed to annihilate Israel and has been responsible for numerous suicide bombings and other deadly attacks since the militant group was formed in 1987. On Saturday
column2: about 1
column3: 000 Hamas fighters stormed across the Israeli border by land and sea in an attack that caught Israel's military off-guard.

column1: Hamas says Saturday's attack was partially a response to Israeli police activity at the Al-Aqsa mosque compound
column2: the third holiest site in Islam. The Jerusalem mosque is located on a holy site for Jews
column3: who refer to it as the Temple Mount. But Hamas leaders also blame unrelenting Israeli crackdowns and a 16-year blockade in Gaza and the West Bank
column4: continued construction of settlements − which the international community considers illegal − and Israel's tight military control of Gaza.

column1: Also
column2: the attack came amid thawing relations between some Arab nations and Israel
column3: the blood enemy of Hamas. The attack and Israel's harsh response could slow or derail those diplomatic overtures.

column1: Hamas – an acronym for Harakat al-Muqawama al-Islamiya
column2: or the Islamic resistance movement – was founded in 1987 during the first Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of Gaza and the West Bank by a Palestinian activist connected to the Muslim Brotherhood. The State Department designated Hamas a terrorist group in 1997. Several other nations also consider it a terrorist organization.
Hamas won parliamentary elections
column3: and in 2007 the group violently seized control of Gaza from the Palestinian Authority
column4: which was controlled by the rival Fatah movement that still governs the West Bank. There have been no elections since. The group calls for establishment of an Islamic Palestinian state that would replace the current state of Israel and believes in the use of violence to carry out the destruction of Israel.

column1: Hamas receives financial
column2: material and logistical support from Iran
column3: though so far
column4: international leaders
column5: including in Israel
column6: have said there is no evidence that Iran was directly involved in Hamas’ attack.

column1: Gaza
column2: or the Gaza Strip
column3: is a densely populated Palestinian enclave of about 2.3 million people. The narrow strip of land − about 150 square miles
column4: or less than half the size of New York City − is about 25 miles long and six miles wide. Gaza shares a northern and eastern border with Israel and a southwestern border with Egypt while its western side abuts the Mediterranean Sea.

column1: Hamas won the 2006 parliamentary elections and in 2007 seized control of the Gaza Strip from the internationally recognized Palestinian Authority. The Palestinian Authority
column2: controlled by the rival Fatah movement
column3: administers semi-autonomous areas of the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Hamas has fought four wars against Israel since taking power.

column1: The current war is a culmination of decades of conflict between Israel and the Palestinian territory
column2: which has been occupied since Israel was founded in 1948 and where Hamas rules the Gaza Strip. Jewish people and Muslims have some of their holiest sites in Jerusalem. Before Israel’s founding
column3: the land was known as the Palestinian mandate
column4: officially ruled by Great Britain. Prompted by the Holocaust
column5: the UN United Nations adopted a resolution in 1947 that aimed to divide the Palestinian mandate into two states
column6: Arab and Jewish.

column1: War quickly broke out between Israel and its Arab neighbors
column2: leading to Israeli expansion three-quarters of Palestinian mandate territory. Over half the Palestinian Arab population fled or was expelled
column3: according to the U.N. Several conflicts between Israel and Arab states in the region followed over the next decades
column4: and peace efforts that improved relations with other nations did not solve the issue of Palestinian self-determination.

column1: Israel captured the Gaza Strip
column2: east Jerusalem and the West Bank in the 1967 Mideast war and has since imposed restrictions on the freedom of movement of Palestinians there. These are all territories that had been sought by Palestinians for their future independent state. But Hamas rejects proposals for a two-state solution and believes in the eradication of Israel altogether through violent means.

column1: Palestinian uprisings
column2: or intifadas
column3: brought military clashes and protests against Israeli occupation and led to crackdowns by Israel’s military forces
column4: and many were killed and injured on both sides.

A truck drove around Harvard University's campus on Wednesday displaying the names and faces of several students allegedly affiliated with student-groups that co-signed a letter blaming Israel for Hamas' attack.

The stunt claimed by the conservative media group Accuracy in Media comes after several CEOs have called on Harvard to release the names of students affiliated with groups tied to the controversial letter that solely blamed Israel for the attack.
The billboard called the students “Harvard leading antisemites.”

column2: ” Ackman wrote.

Following the national attention to the statement

column1: Let me also state, on this matter as on others, that while our students have the right to speak for themselves, no student group — not even 30 student groups — speaks for Harvard University or its leadership, Harvard President Claudine Gay said in a statement on Tuesday.

Changes Elon Musk has put in place since he purchased Twitter and renamed it X have caused the platform to run afoul of the EU’s Digital Services Act.
Taking effect in August 2022
column2: the law penalizes social media companies with hefty fines if it's found that illegal content like terrorist propaganda or hate speech are insufficiently policed.

column1: Under Musk's leadership
column2: X has carried out massive cuts to its content moderation teams and required that users pay to have a blue checkmark that once indicated a verified account. The changes have caused many experts and media observers to worry that Musk has made the platform more susceptible to misinformation.

column1: And that was before decades of Israeli-Palestinian hostility was reignited.

Inflation is headed in the right direction but the road remains bumpy.

Consumer price increases stayed high in September after picking up over the summer as steady gains in rent and other services offset another decline in used car prices and a smaller rise in gasoline and food costs.
Consumer prices overall rose 3.7% from a year earlier
column2: similar to August's increase
column3: according to the Labor Department’s consumer price index.

column1: On a monthly basis
column2: prices increased 0.4% following a 0.6% rise in August that was fueled by a surge in pump prices.

column1: Protect your assets: Best high-yield savings accounts of 2023
Core prices
column2: which strip out volatile food and energy items and which the Federal Reserve watches more closely as it weighs interest rate changes
column3: remained high. They rose 0.3% last month after 0.2% bumps over the summer. The advance still lowered the annual increase to 4.1% from 4.3% in August
column4: marking the smallest gain since September 2021.

column1: Annual inflation has slowed significantly after hitting a 40-year high of 9.1% in June 2022
column2: including a sharp drop to 3% in the first half of 2023. But since then
column3: the cost of some goods and services has accelerated or pulled back more slowly
column4: pushing up the yearly rise.

column1: Prices for items such as used cars and furniture have dropped as pandemic-related supply-chain snarls have been resolved. But the cost of services such as rent
column2: car repairs and auto insurance
column3: have continued to drift higher in part because of briskly rising employee wages.

column1: As a result
column2: driving down inflation to the Fed’s annual 2% target is becoming a tougher slog. Barclays expects inflation broadly to dip to 3.3% in December and 2.6% at the end of 2024. Core price gains are projected to drift down to 3.7% at the end of the year and 2.8% at the close of 2024.

column1: Barclays expects the Fed to raise its key interest rate once more this year
column2: by a quarter percentage point
column3: after lifting it by 5.25 points in 16 months.

column1: Inflation is a "generalized rise in prices
column2:
according to Josh Bivens, director of research at the Economic Policy Institute, a left-leaning think tank based in Washington D.C. The cost of items and services ranging from health care, to gas, to groceries can shift depending on inflation.  
When there are too few goods to meet the demand, prices are likely to rise, according to Investopedia. That disparity is called demand pull inflation. 
The Department of Labor has a tool that enables consumers to find out shifts in their buying power.   
The Consumer Price Index (CPI) looks at the average change in prices for particular products and services over a period of time, according to the Bureau of Labor Services.
It’s one inflation measure that the Fed and the economist use as a barometer to gauge price stability. The Fed’s preferred inflation gauge is the Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index, or PCE, prepared by the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA). The next PCE report for September is due Oct. 27.

After suspending a Black student over his dreadlocks, a Texas high school sent a notice to his family saying the student will be sent to a disciplinary education program, according to a letter reviewed by the Associated Press.
Darryl George, 18, was referred to EPIC, an alternative school program, from Oct. 12 through Nov. 29 for failure to comply" with multiple campus and classroom regulations
column3: including a "violation of the dress and grooming policy
column4:
read the letter signed by Lance Murphy, the principal of Barbers Hill High School.
Murphy wrote that George can return to the classroom on Nov. 30. His family cannot appeal the decision because the alternative school referral was not for a period longer than 60 days, according to the Texas Education Code cited in the letter.
The school district did not respond to USA TODAY's request for comment.
On Aug. 31, George, a junior at Barbers Hill High School, was suspended after school officials said his twisted dreadlocks violated the district's dress and grooming code. Although the district's policy does not prohibit dreadlocks or braids, it states that male student's hair cannot be gathered or worn in a style that would allow the hair to extend below the top of a t-shirt collar
column5: below the eyebrows
column6: or below the ear lobes when let down."

column1: But George's mother
column2: Darresha George
column3: and Allie Booker
column4: the family's attorney
column5: have denied that the teenager's hairstyle violates the district's policy.

column1: Last month the family filed a formal complaint with the Texas Education Agency and a federal civil rights lawsuit against the state’s governor and attorney general
column2: alleging they failed to enforce a new law outlawing discrimination based on hairstyles.

column1: George has twisted dreadlocks tied on top of his head that he wears as an "outward expression of his Black identity and culture
column2:
according to the lawsuit filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas.
The lawsuit and supporters of George allege that his ongoing suspension is a violation of Texas' CROWN Act, a new law that is intended to prohibit discrimination on the basis of hair texture or protective hairstyle associated with race
column3:
according to state Rep. Rhetta Andrews Bowers, D-Rowlett, who authored the bill.
The suit also alleges that Texas Gov. Greg Abbott and Attorney General Ken Paxton have failed to enforce the CROWN Act, which went into effect on Sept. 1 – a day after George was suspended. The lawsuit alleges that the state leaders did not protect George's constitutional and state rights, and allowed the school district to violate the law.
On Wednesday, an attorney representing the Barbers Hill Independent School District filed a motion asking the judge to send the case back to state court, arguing that No federal claims were raised" in the lawsuit by George's family
column4: according to court records.

column1: The following day
column2: Judge George C. Hanks Jr. of the U.S. District Court in Houston denied the motion because it did not comply with court procedures
column3: records said.

column1: The attorneys for the George family and school district did not reply to requests for comment.
Barbers Hill High School has previously clashed with two other Black male students over the dress code.
Barbers Hill officials told cousins De’Andre Arnold and Kaden Bradford they had to cut their dreadlocks in 2020. Their families sued the district in May 2020
column2: and a federal judge later ruled the district’s hair policy was discriminatory. Their pending case helped spur Texas lawmakers to approve the state’s CROWN Act. Both students withdrew from the school but Bradford returned after the judge’s ruling.

column1: WASHINGTON — Words carry weight. They provide context amid chaos
column2: solace amid uncertainty
column3: hope amid horror. But what if you couldn't read? How much of the world might you miss?

column1: Authors and other members of the literary community – including first lady Jill Biden – gathered Wednesday night at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts for the Barbara Bush Foundation’s 2023 National Celebration of Reading. The night featured authors like Rebecca Yarros ("Fourth Wing")
column2: Cheryl Strayed ("Wild") and Steven Rowley ("The Guncle")
column3: and moving moments from those whose journeys to literacy haven't been as easy as flipping a page.

column1: One such person was Oliver James
column2: who gained hundreds of thousands of TikTok followers on his journey of learning to read in his 30s. At the event
column3: he read a short statement from a teleprompter – which singer Franc D'Ambrosio
column4: who is dyslexic
column5: referred to as a Cirque du Soleil feat – and captivated the audience with illuminating thoughts on the power of reading.

column1: It's hard to tell (someone) that they don't know things, James said. "But when I wasn't reading
column2: I thought I knew everything. And then I started learning how to read and found out I knew nothing."

column1: To put it in context: 130 million American adults read below a sixth-grade level – that's 54% of 16- to 74-year-olds.
Check out: USA TODAY's weekly Best-selling Booklist
It's why – especially given our polarizing political climate – reading is more fundamental than ever.

Reading forces us to challenge our preconceived notions, question our underlying assumptions and wrestle with uncomfortable truths, the first lady said before a rapt room at the Terrace Theater. "Few skills are as crucial in democracy that owes its endurance to engage and inform citizens."
Yarros started writing her books back more than a decade ago during her husband's third deployment to Afghanistan – one page in the middle of the night.
Now
column2: Yarros has written more than 15 novels – one of which
column3: fantasy novel "Fourth Wing
column4: is enjoying a high spot on USA TODAY's Best-selling Booklist. The Fourth Wing" sequel
column5: "Iron Flame
column6:
is out in a few weeks.
Fantasy gives us an opportunity to examine our own culture by creating a different one
column7: and to make remarks in our own society through fantastical adventure
column8:
Yarros told USA TODAY in an interview before the event.
The accomplished author, mother of six and military spouse championed literacy in remarks at the event: I've been raised by military parents who never want censored what I read as I grew up
column9: she said. They believed that knowing both sides of an argument made you better informed
column10: better prepared to form your own opinion
column11: or defend your point at the dinner table
column12: and the only truly unacceptable opinion was ignorance."

column1: She later denounced book bans. "As an author
column2: I can't comprehend why we would ban books
column3: shown to increase students' empathy and understanding of the world around them
column4: simply because those novels don't align with a particular viewpoint
column5: she said. And I definitely can't understand the attacks on books that represent marginalized readers."

column1: Yarros also told USA TODAY: "I wish more parents would take the opportunity to talk to their kids about what they're reading instead of banning the books
column2: that they took the time to read them and discuss them with their kids instead of simply saying you can't."

column1: What's behind the surge in book bans?A low-tech website tied to Moms for Liberty
Strayed learned how to read at 6 years old. Her world would never be the same: "I learned the power of literature is that we get to see ourselves most truly
column2: we get to see others in the world in ways that we could never conjure or imagine left to our own devices
column3: she said. We get to understand that people who seem different from us
column4: actually are the same as us."

column1: Strayed also told USA TODAY that she loves all kinds of art forms – but something about literature hits differently.

It's the only art form that honestly allows you to mind meld with somebody else, she said. "Like you get to be inside my mind. What was I thinking when my toenails were falling off? What was I telling myself when I was afraid
column2: and I had to say to myself
column3: 'I am not afraid
column4: ' as I wrote in 'Wild?' There's something very intimate about that."

column1: Rowley
column2: author of "The Celebrants" (and forthcoming "Guncle" sequel "The Guncle Abroad") told USA TODAY that acquiring books is particularly important for queer youth. "For young queer kids
column3: like sometimes they're very on their own
column4: and they don't have the support or don't feel yet that they can trust that they have the support of their parents
column5: Rowley said. Being able to have access to these stories and not have them kept from them is incredibly important."

column1: The Mamas author Helena Andrews-Dyer discussed the importance of diversity in storytelling in her prepared speech that touched on racism and classism: "We talk about books being windows to the world
column2: and they are
column3: but they have to be mirrors too. I repeat
column4: books are mirrors. And those mirrors are why I write
column5: to see and to be seen."

column1: The night closed with a few songs courtesy of famed "Phantom of the Opera" D'Ambrosio
column2: including a haunting medley from the musical. One couldn't help but feel these lyrics linger: "Close your eyes and surrender to your darkest dreams / Purge your thoughts of the life you knew before / Close your eyes
column3: let your spirit start to soar / And you'll live as you've never lived before."

We all have to face the prospect of aging at some point. We prepare for this reality for years in advance
column2: starting 401ks
column3: contributing to Medicare and Social Security as well as comparing insurance plans.

column1: For many Americans
column2: the goal is to have ample healthcare
column3: a nest egg to retire on and the ability to age peacefully at home.

column1: According to a new survey conducted between January and February of 2022
column2: however
column3: these goals are not being equally obtained by all. Conducted with 2
column4: 227 random Americans aged 50 to 80 online or via phone
column5: the survey found that Black citizens were less likely to achieve aging in place.

column1: This is thanks to a variety of factors
column2: with the two most significant being self-reported disability status and income.

column1: Social security changes:Why October 12 is a big day for Social Security recipients
Led by Sheria Robinson-Lane
column2: assistant professor in the department of systems
column3: populations and leadership with the University of Michigan's School of Nursing in Ann Arbor
column4: the study published Oct. 4 in journal Geriatric Nursing found that nearly one third of adults aged 50–80 (30.9%) reported currently living with a disability.

column1: Black adults experienced the highest rate of disability at 40% as well as higher rates of "fair" or "poor" physical health at 37.1% versus 20.9% overall.

Black households were also more likely to report having a family member with a disability present with 36.4% compared to the overall sample of 23.3%. Half of Black households also reported an income lower than $30
column2: 000 a year
column3: a significant discrepancy from the quarter of overall respondents who reported the same thing (23.3%).

column1: Older Black Americans are also more likely to live alone
column2: with 44.1% reporting they were the only one in their home versus a quarter of overall respondents. This
column3: paired with the aforementioned factors
column4: cumulate in Black adults having lower rates of confidence in their ability to afford and find necessary in-home care.

column1: How does all of this prevent Black Americans from aging at home? First and foremost
column2: said the study's authors
column3: increased rates of disability mean more strain on already thinly stretched resources.

column1: Older adults with disabilities often require some form of assistive device
column2: human support or other accommodations. The U.S. Department of Health & Human Services' Administration on Aging found that on average
column3: 70% of people 65 and up need some type of long-term care
column4: such as a nursing home or assisted living
column5: at some point
column6: while 20% will need that care for more than five years.

column1: Women face microaggressions at work:We need to talk about the macro effect of microaggressions on women at work
With assisted living costs averaging at $4
column2: 500 per month and nursing homes averaging $7
column4: 034 per month for a semi-private room or private room according to Genworth Financial's 2021 Cost of Care Survey
column5: support for older people is in no way cheap.

column1: In-home care is pricey as well
column2: with median prices hovering between $4
column4: 148 per month for homemaker services or a home health aide
column5: according to the same 2021 data. In the same year
column6: more than half of Americans had less than $250 left at the end of the month after paying necessary bills.

column1: With older Black Americans more likely to shoulder the weight of higher healthcare costs due to disability
column2: more likely to live alone without in-home familial assistance and more likely to grapple with an income under $30
column4: they face multiple barriers to aging in their own home and communities.

column1: Within the overall sample
column2: 41.3% of respondents were not confident they could afford supportive care such as assistance with chores
column3: shopping
column4: personal care or finance management if needed. Facing down the existing cost-of-living crisis
column5: many older Americans have found themselves without means to live comfortably or access necessary resources.

column1: In an already difficult fiscal climate
column2: ethnic and racial discrepancies continue to impact quality of care for our older population. According to the study's authors
column3: healthcare facilities placing a focus on adapting and optimizing care to close these gaps is an important course of action to begin addressing the disparity.

column1: Aging in place requires a proactive individual and community-based approach that facilitates older adult independence and connects adults with the social, clinical, and environmental support needed to remain in one's home for as long as possible, the study said.

column2: sending tens of thousands to rally virtually to her side
column3: there was an undeniable and uplifting sense that we had all been here before.

column1: Of course we had. This is Mary Lou Retton
column2: and this is us
column3: and there’s something very reassuring in knowing that this nation loves her just as much today as it did nearly 40 years ago
column4: when an ever-smiling 16-year-old tomboy
column5: a tiny fullback in a gymnast’s leotard
column6: barreled toward the vault at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics
column7: flew into the air and landed in every American living room.

column1: Forty years of adoration is a lot of years and a lot of love. I have been fortunate to witness it all as a journalist
column2: to interview and catch up with Mary Lou on the phone
column3: at social events
column4: at subsequent Olympics. But it all goes back to those early days in 1984
column5: summed up so succinctly and presciently by a copy of Sports Illustrated I pulled out of a cabinet Wednesday morning
column6: one of my many mementos from the L.A. Olympics
column7: which were my first.

column1: On the cover of the August 13
column2: 1984 issue is a photo of a jubilant young athlete in red
column3: white and blue
column4: fists clenched
column5: arms raised in triumph
column6: with the headline: “Only you
column7: Mary Lou!”

column1: She was lovable from the get-go. We actually met before the L.A. Games. I looked it up in my diary: it was June 3
column3: the morning after she qualified for the U.S. Olympic team at the gymnastics trials in Jacksonville. I was with the Miami Herald then
column4: and photographer Bill Frakes and I drove to the motel where Mary Lou and her family were staying. The press availability that we were expecting ended up being a family affair: just Bill
column5: me and the Rettons
column6: all sitting on chaise lounges by the pool in Florida
column7: far from their Fairmont
column8: West Virginia
column9: home.

column1: Mary Lou told me she wished she was taller. She was 4-9. “I wish I was 5 feet tall
column2: ” she said. “That would be perfect.”

column1: Her parents used to tell her they were going to give her hormone shots to help her grow but never did. So short jokes became a big part of her young life. Her favorite: “Stand up
column2: Mary Lou
column3: ” when she already was.

column1: Her father
column2: Ronnie
column3: a veritable giant at 5-7
column4: was an athlete as well. He was the sixth man
column5: a guard
column6: on the West Virginia men’s basketball team that was led by Hall of Famer Jerry West.

column1: Mary Lou was a natural athlete who was unstoppable inside the house. Her mother
column2: Lois
column3: said she finally put Mary Lou into a gymnastics class when far too many lamps were overturned.

column1: “I was a tomboy
column2: ” Mary Lou told me. “I looked like a little boy. I even ran around topless.”

column1: She said all this with a smile. Everything about this teenager
column2: unknown to me until that week
column3: screamed out fun
column4: joy
column5: happiness. Bill had an idea for a photo and asked if anyone had any bubble gum. I actually did
column6: so I handed it to Mary Lou
column7: who started chewing and then blew a massive pink bubble that covered her entire face. This made quite a picture
column8: with her grandmother standing beside her
column9: looking on with a wry smile
column10: both of them in bathing suits.

column1: That day by the pool
column2: the Rettons had no idea what was waiting for their daughter
column3: but whatever it was
column4: there was some trepidation about it.

column1: “I worry about her
column2: ” Lois Retton said. “I worry when she travels
column3: about the security when she performs. She’s 16. She should be going to proms and ball games. I feel like I’ve lost her to the world. Will she ever come back?”

column1: She did
column2: just much more famous. Mary Lou of course became the darling of those Olympics
column3: a household name
column4: a role model for several generations of young female athletes — and someone I would seek for perspective when writing about little girls in big-time sports.

column1: She has one of my favorite quotes on the subject:
“While other kids were reading about the Great Wall
column2: I was walking on it.”

column1: It’s worth remembering exactly what happened at those 1984 Olympics. With a perfect 10 on the vault at UCLA’s Pauley Pavilion
column2: Retton became the first American to win the women’s individual all-around gold medal
column3: one of the most coveted titles in all of sports. She won five medals altogether in L.A.
column4: including silvers in the team competition and on the vault
column5: and bronze medals on the uneven bars and floor exercise. Considering that no American woman had ever won an individual Olympic gymnastics medal of any color
column6: she was a revelation.

column1: She also knew luck was on her side. The strong Soviet gymnasts
column2: including the reigning women’s individual all-around world champion
column3: were not in L.A.
column4: having boycotted those Games. But the highly-regarded Romanians did compete in L.A.
column5: and
column6: as Retton said
column7: “It was a big battle. I earned my medal.”

column1: What happened next was a dream. She was everywhere
column2: from the front of the Wheaties box to SI’s Sportswoman of the Year. She appeared on gymnastics tours
column3: on TV shows and in the movies. She has been a constant presence at the Olympic Games and is one of the most sought-after speakers and celebrities in the U.S. Olympic movement.

column1: She also has four daughters
column2: all of whom have been involved in gymnastics. She got a kick out of relating how she tried to remain anonymous when taking one of her daughters to a gymnastics class. That didn’t last long.

column1: “They knew it was me
column2: ” she said with a hearty laugh.

column1: In the same week that the sports world continues to celebrate the greatness of Simone Biles
column2: there’s now an outpouring of concern over the woman who started it all.

column1: “As the first U.S. all-around Olympic gymnastics champion
column2: Mary Lou Retton became a shining icon of American excellence
column3: ” veteran sports agent Sheryl Shade texted Wednesday. “Her legacy is important
column4: as her performance and personality inspired millions of girls (and parents) to swell the ranks of women’s gymnastics in the USA. Many of my gymnast clients had her poster in their rooms and on their vision boards even though she competed years before they were born.”

column1: Who are some of those clients? Laurie Hernandez
column2: Shawn Johnson
column3: Shannon Miller
column4: Amanda Borden
column5: Jaycie Phelps and Gabby Douglas
column6: Olympic stars all.

column1: That Sports Illustrated cover had it right all those years ago. Mary Lou
column2: it has always been only you.

column1: The judge in Donald Trump's criminal case alleging that classified documents were mishandled will weigh on Thursday whether lawyers for two co-defendants are too close to witnesses.

U.S. District Judge Aileen Cannon will consider arguments related to witnesses expected to testify about the co-defendants moving boxes and trying to delete surveillance video at Mar-a-Lago. The testimony is part of the evidence against Trump and his co-defendants for allegedly retaining and hiding national security records after he left the White House.
Justice Department special counsel Jack Smith warned Cannon that lawyers representing Walt Nauta and Carlos De Oliveira
column2: two staffers at Mar-a-Lago where the FBI seized the classified documents
column3: might have conflicts.

column1: Stanley Woodward represents Nauta
column2: Trump’s personal valet. John Irving represents De Oliveira
column3: the property manager at Mar-a-Lago. Woodward and Irving also represented several witnesses in the case.

column1: Woodward told prosecutors he had no conflicts. Donnie Murrell
column2: another lawyer for De Oliveira
column3: said there was no conflict with witnesses and that even if there was
column4: Murrell could cross-examine them rather than Irving.

column1: Trump is charged with unlawful retention of national defense information. He is charged with Nauta and De Oliveira with obstruction of justice. All three have pleaded not guilty.
Here is a summary of potential conflicts prosecutors raised:
Woodward represented seven other people questioned during the investigation
column2: including three likely witnesses at trial
column3: prosecutors said.

column1: Irving represented four other people questioned during the investigation
column2: including three potential witnesses at trial
column3: prosecutors said.

column1: Prosecutors argued there could be two types of conflicts. One is that a lawyer could disclose confidences from his client during cross-examination of a witness. Another is that the attorney might “pull his punches” during cross-examination to protect his client's confidences or because of his personal interests.
In De Oliveira’s case
column2: according to prosecutors:

column1: Murrell
column2: De Oliveira's lawyer
column3: said in a court filing that Irving no longer represents the three witnesses and that he has no confidential information about those witnesses that could be a conflict in cross-examination.

column1: Here, the Government seeks a hearing based on only what it believes is a potential for a conflict, and not any actual conflict, Murrell wrote.
In Nauta's case
column2: some of the rationale that explained why each witness could face a conflict was filed in confidential documents. According to prosecutors:

column1:
All three may be witnesses for the Government at trial, raising the possibility that Mr. Woodward might be in the position of cross-examining past or current clients,” prosecutors wrote for Smith. The director of information technology changed lawyers before the grand jury handed up the indictment.
Woodward told prosecutors that he notified his various clients about potential conflicts, but doesn’t think there are any. Woodward said in a filing that he played no role in the grand jury testimony from Taveras, and the witness testified he wasn't coached."
Cannon set the hearings at 1 p.m. for De Oliveira and 3 p.m. for Nauta.
LOS ANGELES – There are movie premieres here where the red carpet is the star event.
But this is Taylor's version.

The world premiere of Taylor Swift's "Eras Tour" movie on Wednesday night was all about what was inside a very common AMC movie theater in an outdoor mall that was closed for the day. And Taylor Swift herself
column2: sitting in theater No. 2
column3: seat F8
column4: at the center
column5: next to her tour backup singers and dancers
column6: and actress Julia Garner.

column1: Hi, so you're stuck with me because I'm going to, like, sit with you and watch this thing, Swift said
column2: dressed in a strapless light blue Oscar de la Renta high-low gown before the movie began. "But before we do that
column3: I want to say thank you for wanting to spend your evening with me. ... I've always had fun doing this. I can't believe music is my career; that's crazy to me. I've always loved it. I've never had a fraction of the amount of fun I've had on the Eras tour before
column4: ever."

column1: The theater was filled with fans – some of whom her team invited via direct message on X
column2: formerly Twitter – and celebrity Swifties including Simu Liu
column3: Maren Morris and Adam Sandler and his wife and two daughters
column4: as well as Swift's own camera crew.

column1: Taylor Swift 'Eras' movie review:Concert film a thrilling revisit of her live spectacle
Swift visited each theater to thank guests before coming to the spot where she would watch her movie.

I want to say, I have friends in this room, I have my amazing backing vocalists in this room. ... We pranced on that stage grinning because of what met us on the other side and that was you, how much you cared about it. That was absolutely everything, she said. "So
column2: I think you will see that you absolutely are main characters in this film because that's what made the tour magical
column3: that's what made the tour different from anything I've ever done in my life."

column1: She continued: "Your attention to detail
column2: your preparation
column3: your passion
column4: your intensity
column5: you cared so much about these shows and that made all the difference for us. It made us want to add even more shows. I just have never felt this way about anything. I am so proud."

column1: Just before the movie started at 8:30 p.m.
column2: she said: "I think I will just watch it with you now. So let's have a blast
column3: guys. Thank you for coming."

column1: Guests ate popcorn out of commemorative Eras Tour tins and Reese's Pieces and Red Vines from a complimentary elaborate candy bar decorated with fresh flowers flown in that morning for the display. An AMC employee stopped by Swift's seat and poured glasses of white wine.
The movie replicated Swift's popular and sold-out concerts
column2: with an intimacy few felt in the stadium tour. The movie was like a close-up and clearer version of a stadium Jumbotron
column3: with details from Swift's ballerina flats to her multicolored fingernails featured.

column1: Moviegoers at the premiere captured the concert feel with sequined jackets
column2: sparkly boots
column3: pastel pouf dresses and friendship bracelets.

column1: 'Eras' tour movie etiquette:How to enjoy the Taylor Swift concert film (the right way)
Throughout the movie
column2: Swift bopped her head with the songs
column3: pumped her arms
column4: mimicked her onscreen dance moves and smiled almost nonstop. Watching her was as fun as watching the movie.

column1: It was also a movie where participation felt almost mandatory.
It's so wild. Watching her is making this so much fun, said Arianna Trinidad
column2: a Swiftie from Phoenix who attended the world premiere of the concert tour
column3: and was at the theater for the movie's world premiere. "I can't believe I'm here
column4: two rows behind her. I think we're both having the same amount of fun."

column1: As the screen showed "Look What You Made Me Do" from the "Reputation" era
column2: Sandler - sitting just behind Swift in his trademark Hawaiian polo shirt – bounced in his chair and clapped
column3: one of Swift's vocalists held her hands up in the shape of a heart
column4: and Swift vibed to the beat.

column1: Before the movie began
column2: Swift took photos with fans and made a video with Beyoncé in an empty theater. She posted on her Instagram: "She's been a guiding light throughout my career and the fact that she showed up tonight was like an actual fairytale."

column1: It was unclear if Beyoncé
column2: who opens her own movie "Renaissance: A Film by Beyoncé" with AMC in December
column3: stayed to watch the movie. She was not in the theater with Swift.

column1: While Swift's appearance at the movie was expected
column2: most people in theater No. 2 hadn't expected to watch the movie with her. Their eyes gazed from the screen to Swift
column3: while they joined her in singing everything from "Cruel Summer" to "Midnight Rain."

column1: By the end of the two-hour and 48 minute movie
column2: the crowd was standing and dancing to its final song
column3: "Karma." Swift took selfies – with a flash – with her dancers
column4: singers and Garner.

column1: The credits included cute outtakes from the tour – and some names spelled out in friendship bracelet style. After the movie
column2: Swift took photos with fans and posed while Sandler snapped a photo of her with his daughters before she slipped out a door at the back of the theater.

column1: The movie was scheduled to open on Friday. But after selling more than $100 million in presale tickets and leaving many people waiting in online queues to buy movie tickets
column2: it now will open on Thursday.

column1: Editor's note: Part one of a five-part USA TODAY series revealing why America hasn't solved its long struggle with Type 2 diabetes.
For chef Robin Ray
column2: newly married with young stepchildren
column3: the turning point came when a stabbing chest pain sent her rushing to the emergency room.

column1: For Brian Castrucci
column2: the gravity hit when the ER doc who had treated him for a near-heart attack a few weeks earlier gave him a big bear hug. “I didn’t think you’d make it
column3: ” the doctor said.

column1: The crisis unspooled more slowly for James Haynes but started in 2019 when he stepped on a rusty nail and didn’t notice.
The moments were turning points for all three to get serious about addressing their diabetes.
Type 2 diabetes
column2: in which the body can’t properly regulate blood sugar
column3: has become so common it’s almost considered inconsequential. More than 1 in 10 Americans have the disease (though many don't know) and another nearly 4 in 10 are at risk for it. In total
column4: half of all adults and a quarter of teenagers have diabetes or pre-diabetes.

column1: Its financial costs are astronomical. The country spends more than $300 billion a year to address diabetes
column2: accounting for $1 out of every $4 spent on health care.

column1: And its personal tolls are even worse: heart attacks
column2: amputations
column3: blindness
column4: kidney disease
column5: double the risk of premature death. It also causes what’s known as “diabetes distress
column6: ” the daily burdens and emotional toll of living with and managing a chronic ailment that can lead to regular dips in energy
column7: foggy thinking and depression
column8: and a sense of isolation.

column1: The most frustrating aspect of Type 2 diabetes
column2: experts say
column3: is that it has long been largely preventable and controllable.

column1: “We have made tremendous gains in understanding diabetes
column2: ” said Dr. Donald Berwick
column3: a pediatrician and former administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. “The best diabetes care can make a very big difference. You can’t say we don’t know what to do.”

column1: And yet
column2: diagnosed rates of Type 2 diabetes have soared over the past 25 years
column3: and especially over the past dozen – particularly among working-age adults like Ray
column4: Castrucci and Haynes.

column1: Roughly 40% of people who died early in the coronavirus pandemic had Type 2 diabetes
column2: a rate four times higher than people without the disease. Even when elevated blood sugar levels are below the threshold for type 2 diabetes
column3: the risk for heart disease jumps 30% to 50% compared with people with normal blood sugar levels. (Type 1 diabetes
column4: which accounts for 5% to 10% of diabetes
column5: is caused by the immune system and is unrelated to diet or lifestyle.)

column1: America’s failure to address Type 2 diabetes highlights larger problems with our food and medical systems
column2: Berwick and other experts said.

column1: A soda costs less than a bottle of water
column2: a double cheeseburger and fries less than a carton of blueberries. Patients wait months for medical appointments only to see the back of a white coat for the short time they’re allotted. Treating disease costs society far more than preventing it but typically provides more profit for insurance companies
column3: hospitals and the pharmaceutical industry.

column1: The USA TODAY Health team spoke with scores of health care providers
column2: researchers
column3: community leaders and patients for this five-part series to understand why Type 2 diabetes continues to worsen in America despite known solutions.

column1: The answer isn't simple. It involves systemic problems facing everyone in society
column2: not just those with diabetes: a food system designed to sell products; a medical system in which cutting off a leg is less expensive than saving it; the high cost of healthy living and the fact that breaking habits takes a lot more than just personal willpower.

column1: This first story looks at what it takes for people to cope with or overcome the disease.
Then
column2: we explore one community in a David vs. Goliath battle against a food system that fails to prioritize people's health.

column1: More in series:Diabetes runs deep in rural Mississippi. Locals have taken to growing their own solutions.
We next travel to Colorado
column2: which has the lowest level of diabetes in the nation. Yet even in this state
column3: where hiking trails and gorgeous views abound
column4: economic and other disparities make it easier for some people to avoid diabetes than others.

column1: More in series:A diabetes disparity: Why Colorado's healthy lifestyle brand isn't shared by all
It's tough to manage a chronic illness in the face of high medical costs
column2: scattered care and caregiver frustration and burnout
column3: so we highlight that next.

column1: More in series:The steep cost of Type 2: When diabetes dragged her down
column2: she chose to fight

column1: Finally
column2: we explore solutions
column3: addressing why it will take a combination of education
column4: medication
column5: medical devices and improved food access to solve this national problem.

column1: More in series:Solutions exist to end the Type 2 diabetes dilemma but too few get the help they need
The system is fixable
column2: said Dr. Dariush Mozaffarian
column3: a cardiologist and professor at the Tufts University School of Medicine in Boston.

column1: But it will take "sensible action" from across many sectors
column2: including health care
column3: science
column4: nutrition
column5: business
column6: public health and politics to change the financial and other incentives that drive so many Americans toward sickness instead of health.

column1: If we do it all, we could fix a lot of this in 10 years, said Mozaffarian
column2: who serves on the President’s Council on Sports
column3: Fitness
column4: and Nutrition. "If we do it incrementally or don't do it at all
column5: we're all going to be toast in 50 years from diet-related illnesses and a depleted environment."

column1: There’s no question personal responsibility plays a role in fighting diabetes.
Haynes
column2: Ray and Castrucci radically changed their lifestyles and sought help after their come-to-Jesus experiences. They’ve reduced their dependence on daily medication and hope to have saved themselves the horrors of more amputations
column3: blindness and dialysis. They’ve extended their lives and improved the quality of that time.

column1: But like many medical problems
column2: the challenges of diabetes go well beyond individual responsibility and blame.

column1: “There are structural issues that we have to start paying attention to and addressing
column2: ” said Dr. Shivani Agarwal
column3: an endocrinologist who specializes in research and treating young adults with diabetes at Montefiore Medical Center and Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York. Agarwal recently led a series of studies in the journal The Lancet that looked at diabetes rates around the world.

column1: Poverty
column2: the studies showed
column3: was a major driver of diabetes
column4: along with racism and unequal access to healthy food and high-quality medical care.

column1: Personal stories illustrate how these structural issues play out in the lives of so many Americans.
Ray
column3: director of culinary operations at HOSCO/North Sarah Food Hub in St. Louis
column4: got weight-loss surgery and then put her culinary expertise to good use.

column1: Castrucci
column3: who runs a public health nonprofit outside Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: used his advantages provided by his work
column6: salary and insurance to “buy” himself better health.

column1: “I’m healthy because of privilege – not diet
column2: not exercise
column3: not determination
column4: ” he said.

column1: Haynes
column3: a former truck driver and maintenance technician in Gulfport
column4: Mississippi
column5: has fewer material assets
column6: but his attitude and the advantages he does have explain why he's still around
column7: despite all he has been through.

column1: “It’s going to be all right after a while
column2: as long as I keep this spirit
column3: ” he said.

column1: Ray’s love for food began when she was 8 years old
column2: watching Julia Child on TV. During family gatherings
column3: she would run around taking everyone’s dinner order. Then she’d scurry back to the kitchen with a notepad full of scribbles.

column1: Throughout her life
column2: she made fried chicken
column3: pork chops
column4: baked mac and cheese
column5: collard greens
column6: and even a whole roasted chicken filled with wild rice and two sticks of butter – everything that made her soul sing.

column1: In her world
column2: food was home. Food was family. Food was love.

column1: But that was some pretty tough love.

column2: Ray was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes. Her father
column3: grandmother
column4: aunts and uncles all had diabetes. She knew what it meant.

column1: “For you to tell me I can’t have ice blue raspberry Kool-Aid was like you shut down my world
column2: ” Ray said. “I didn’t want to accept it. So
column3: I ate
column4: because you eat through your emotions.”

column1: She didn't dwell on the diagnosis and continued with life. Her culinary career took her to Italy
column2: where she learned and fell even more in love with food. She returned to St. Louis
column3: got married and became a mom to her husband’s two children ‒ “beautiful bonus babies
column4: ” as she described them. Through the years
column5: she continued to express love through cooking and eating.

column2: a stabbing chest pain sent her to the emergency room. Doctors assured Ray she hadn’t had a heart attack
column3: but they warned that her life was on the line. At 5-foot-2
column4: she weighed 334 pounds and had an A1C
column5: a measure of average blood sugar of 11%
column6: well above the 6.5% cutoff to be considered diabetic. Her diabetes – and her diet – were out of control.

column1: “That scared me. … It was gut-wrenching and terrifying
column2: ” she said. “I’m fighting against something that’s fighting me back and I did not know how to win.”

column1: She and her primary care doctor decided she would pursue weight loss surgery.
But she also decided to use her culinary prowess to transform her diet. She reconfigured favorite foods
column2: substituting healthier ingredients: Collard greens cooked in smoked fats or ham hocks turned into a kale
column3: turnip and rutabaga recipe flavored with natural chicken broth fat
column4: oils and seasonings.

column1: She fostered her feelings into new recipes and brought them to North Sarah Food Hub
column2: which partnered with Barnes-Jewish Hospital to make packaged
column3: pre-made meals for St. Louis residents with diabetes and limited access to fresh food.

column1: “I had to restructure the food that I put in my mouth. I had to think about what I was eating and how I was eating and how it was going to be good for my body
column2: ” she said. “I became excited about food again
column3: and food became a joy.”

column1: It isn’t always easy
column2: of course. Ray admits to an occasional cookie craving. But now she takes the time to think about how her body processes that cookie and whether it’s worthwhile.

column1: She hopes her cooking can help other people make the same transformation she did. Her staff at North Sarah helps her create new recipes for others. She wants to provide nourishment that allows people to avoid illness and medicine.
“Nobody wants to take 55 pills
column2: nobody wants to feel like a patient
column3: but how do you fix that? It’s by our food
column4: ” she said. “That should be what we’re teaching our community and our culture and our children. … It’s not always about the macaroni noodle with a smile
column5: it’s about what’s good for your body.”

column1: Castrucci is a third-generation diabetes patient. The lifetime risk of developing Type 2 diabetes if a parent has it is 40%. If both parents have it
column2: the risk jumps to 70%.

column1: He knew he was at risk
column2: but he pushed his luck
column3: he said
column4: by eating poorly during the pandemic and falling out of his exercise routine. With the luxury of working from home
column5: walking to the kitchen and bathroom was often the extent of his daily activity.

column1: On Feb. 14
column2: 2022 – Valentine’s Day – he went to an urgent care clinic
column3: concerned his breathing trouble meant he had bronchitis. His blood pressure measured 210 over 110
column4: well above normal levels that top out at 120 over 80. A chest X-ray showed fluid filling his lungs
column5: leading to congestive heart failure.

column1: The clinic sent him straight to a local emergency room
column2: where he was diagnosed with a blockage of the left descending artery – a clogged artery made worse by diabetes. If he had waited any longer
column3: he would have had a massive heart attack
column4: his doctor later told him.

column1: After his release from the hospital
column2: he went to the drugstore to fill his new prescriptions. The pharmacist told him she couldn’t fill one because it would cost $1
column3: 000. He’d have to wait until his insurance approved it. “Please fill it
column4: ” he said. She stressed the cost. “Fill it
column5: ” he pleaded
column6: putting the charge on his credit card.

column1: Medication helped him lose 70 pounds in three months. When his local drugstore ran out of the weight-loss drug
column2: he easily drove to another pharmacy and then another to find what he needed.

column1: His 100 hours of high-quality cardiac rehabilitation were fully covered by insurance.
For my midlife crisis, I got healthy, Castrucci said.
He could devote all his energy to getting well because he didn’t have to focus on how to afford his care. “(I) paid almost nothing for the whole episode
column2: ” he said
column3: “and never worried about it because I have really good insurance.”

column1: Even so
column2: Castrucci pays out-of-pocket for a cardiologist and an endocrinologist because the best ones near him don’t accept insurance.

column1: Every time he goes to Walgreens to refill his medications
column2: Castrucci said
column3: he sees someone turned away because they can’t afford their prescriptions. When they finally show up in the emergency room
column4: “because they will
column5: ” they will cost the system far more
column6: he said.

column1: “Health outcomes are dictated by economics. It’s a whole side of privilege that we don’t always talk about.”
On the day Haynes stepped on a rusty nail in 2019
column2: he walked all day as the nail pierced the sole of his sneaker and then his foot. By the time he took off his shoe that night
column3: his foot was infected. He landed in the hospital for two months as doctors and nurses tried
column4: mostly unsuccessfully
column5: to get the infection and Haynes’ blood sugar under control.

column1: By the time he was released
column2: he knew enough about Type 2 diabetes to realize his daily blood sugar levels – typically in the mid-400s – were four times above what he had been told to shoot for.

column1: But nothing he did or ate seemed to make a difference. He had long since traded ribs for salads
column2: beer for water.

column1: His wife
column2: Angela
column3: barely noticed when James started wearing multiple pairs of socks
column4: pouring powder on his feet and buying bigger shoes. His feet tingled a lot
column5: he said
column6: but he was coping with it.

column1: James ended up in the emergency room again
column2: dehydrated and in need of antibiotics. The doctor amputated the baby toe on his right foot
column3: leaving a large open wound.

column1:
We're going to leave this open because we'll probably have to take more,” Angela remembered the doctor saying. “I didn't like that we're not going to try to save anything, we're just going to start cutting.”
James was fading.
His arm muscles shriveled and he lost his Popeye physique. Antibiotics left him looking sickly, his voice so weak Angela could barely hear him. “I felt like I was watching my husband slowly dying,” she said.
Finally, taking her doctor sister’s advice, Angela emailed Dr. Foluso Fakorede’s office to ask for an appointment. She thought it would take months to get James in to see the heart disease specialist, but the office called and asked if they could come the next day. 
The Hayneses would end up going back to see Fakorede many times − sometimes twice in one week, driving more than five hours each way from Gulfport north to Cleveland, Mississippi.
“We started looking forward to these visits because there was always hope,” Angela Haynes said, though she felt guilty they were taking up so much of the important doctor’s time. 
Fakorede, who is on a personal mission to save people with diabetes from amputations, noticed what other doctors had missed. Haynes had blockages in blood vessels on both legs. 
Once he got the blood flowing again, Haynes began to feel better. His flesh returned to its normal color. The wound started healing at last. Walking became easier.
Then disaster struck again. 
On July 2, 2022, Haynes caught COVID-19. Everything went downhill after that
column2:
he said.
During his 13-day illness, the bacteria in his foot raged out of control. He ended up back in the hospital and unable to withstand the long drive to Fakorede’s office.
Every week, a surgeon would come to the door of his hospital room and before even stepping all the way in ask Haynes whether he had decided to get his leg amputated. 
This is my leg. I was born with this. And you're walking in like you're cutting a piece of cake
column3:
Haynes said.
He was worried about how he’d get around, how he’d be able to work to support his family if he had only one leg. No one took the time to explain why they thought the leg needed to come off or how he’d cope without it, Haynes said. 
In late November, he was finally sent home in a wheelchair. But just three weeks later, as he was getting out of the car after wound care, his right leg gave out and he fell to the ground. Back at the hospital, Haynes was told his foot was broken, essentially beyond repair. He agreed to a below-the-knee amputation.
Released right before Christmas, he spent the next three weeks in bed wondering how he’d manage the rest of his life.
Finally, it looked as if his luck might be turning around.
With the leg gone, his diabetes improved. His blood sugar dropped into the 120s or one-teens. His blurry vision cleared up.
During his long hospital stay, he befriended nurses and learned about a program for people who needed prostheses. The man who ran it called early in the year and said he had received a donated leg. If it fit Haynes, he could have it while waiting for insurance to pay for a personalized one. Miraculously, it did. 
Haynes spent the next six months teaching himself to walk again. The donor leg was heavy and uncomfortable. He wasn't mobile enough to hold down a job.
One late spring night, picking up dinner at a nearby restaurant, he headed to the bathroom for a pit stop. A sink had been leaking all day and Haynes slipped in the puddle, falling backward.
He's still recovering from the resulting wrist surgery.
He and Angela are living – barely – off her part-time salary as a secretary and a church organist.
Haynes has tried at least three or four times" to receive government assistance
column4: but they keep losing his paperwork
column5: or not believing he's disabled
column6: though he once checked himself out of the hospital and arrived at an appointment in his wheelchair to prove he didn't have a leg.

column1: Still
column2: he clings to his faith and the positive attitude he has long used to cheer up himself and others. These are his secret weapons against diabetes and everything else life throws his way.

column1: I try to put a smile on other people's faces, he said. "It keeps my day going."
Contributing: Nada Hassanein

column2: most accurate snapshot of what people are reading by showing which titles are selling. It is a master list
column3: unbound by genre and format

column1: “I am so thrilled that the USA Today Best-selling Booklist is coming back!" says bestselling author Colleen Hoover in a statement. "It gives so many authors the wonderful opportunity to be recognized as bestsellers and for readers to discover their next favorite book.”
Hoover

column1: Check out: USA TODAY's weekly Best-selling Booklist
The USA TODAY list is a ranking of the top-selling titles each week from a broad range of businesses including major chains
column2: independent bookstores and online retailers. It reflects combined sales of titles in print and electronic format
column3: if available. Our data team weighs and compiles those numbers to generate the week's 150 top-selling titles. The rankings reflect sales from the previous Monday through Sunday. The full list will publish online at 6 a.m. Wednesdays
column4: with the top 50 titles publishing in print Thursdays.

column1: The list
column2: which began in 1993
