column1: We can't wait to see what you've been reading!
SHEFAYIM KIBBUTZ
column2: Israel − They exchanged text messages and emojis. Brief status updates with words of encouragement. A picture of the beloved family dog
column3: Tutsi.

column1: Until no more messages came.
And then
column2: Cindy Flash
column3: an American
column4: and her Israeli husband
column5: Igal
column6: vanished into the violence
column7: presumed kidnapped by Hamas.

column1: Four days after Hamas attacked Israel
column2: more than 100 Israelis and possibly dozens of foreign nationals are thought to be held captive in the Gaza Strip. At least 14 U.S. citizens have been killed and an unknown number are still unaccounted for.

column1: Flash
column3: originally from St. Paul
column4: Minnesota
column5: is one of them. She lives in Kfar Aza
column6: a kibbutz in southern Israel near Gaza
column7: where some of the most harrowing and grisly stories have been emerging over the past few days.

column1: They are breaking down the safe room door, Flash said in one of her final messages to her daughter Keren
column2: 34. "We need someone to come by the house right now." Keren had been communicating with her parents from a few houses away.

column1: Keren described her mother
column2: an administrator in a local college
column3: as someone who had the "sweetest biggest heart
column4:
whom everyone knew and loved, and who had spent a lifetime advocating for the rights of Palestinians, including those who live in Gaza, where she may now be held.
She emigrated to Israel decades ago after a visit during college, when she fell in love with Israel's system of kibbutzim − collectives traditionally centered on agriculture but which have evolved to accommodate myriad interests, tastes and even businesses. 
They didn't deserve this
column5: '' her daughter said Tuesday on the grounds of a sprawling hotel and resort on a coastal kibbutz northeast of Tel Aviv
column6: where hundreds of people were evacuated after the attack. "No one deserves this."

column1: It was filled with volunteers bringing sandwiches and sweetcakes. Sobbing teenagers
column2: reunited after days of having their worst fears confirmed
column3: hugged one another tightly. Small groups of people sat at tables hunched over laptops compiling lists of the missing. A manager said about 300 people from Kfar Aza were staying at the hotel.

column1: Before the attack
column2: Kfar Aza had a population of about 800. Nobody knows for sure how many survived.

column1: Cindy and Igal's home in Kfar Aza sits right next to the security fence Hamas militants broke through Saturday morning as they attacked Israel by land
column2: sea and air.

column1: The couple had recently renovated it
column2: which had required that they move away from the kibbutz for a few months.

column1: They were so happy to be back, Keren said.
And their daughter said that despite their proximity to Gaza
column2: everyone in the family had always felt secure and reveled in their area's lush vegetation
column3: tranquility and sense of community.

column1: In fact
column2: the extended Flash family had expected a very different Saturday from the one they got.

column1: They had planned a family picnic. And later that afternoon they were going to make and fly kites in the local soccer field as part of an annual community event. Maybe
column2: they thought
column3: they'd have a little ice cream and relax after a hectic week of family life and work. A DJ was going to play.

column1: Instead
column2: Keren
column3: a Pilates instructor
column4: and her husband
column5: Avidor Schwartzman
column7: a media consultant
column8: woke abruptly around 6:30 a.m. to a blaring alarm system and heard what appeared to be the sound of bombs going off. They leaped out of bed and dashed down the hall to grab their 1-year-old baby
column9: Saar
column12: water and a little food. Then they locked themselves in a room of concrete and reinforced steel.

column1: Around the same time
column2: Cindy and Igal
column4: locked themselves in their own safe room. The sounds of bombs gradually turned into the sounds of automatic gunfire as Hamas militants encircled Kfar Aza and began going house to house to hunt people down.

column1: We started losing contact with so many people on various WhatsApp groups, said Keren
column2: who along with Avidor and Saar was eventually rescued by Israeli security services. ''We would hear that they were wounded
column3: and then they would just drop off completely."

column1: Israel media reported Tuesday that the bodies of 40 children and babies were found in Kfar Aza
column2: some of whom had been beheaded. An Israel Defense Forces spokesperson said Kfar Aza was a "massacre." The bodies of civilians and militants were found scattered throughout the kibbutz. He declined to comment on the beheadings. One report
column3: which USA TODAY could not independently verify
column4: said that multiple people had been beheaded and that charred bodies had been found. The Israeli death toll from the Hamas attack has passed 1

column1: Neither the U.S. nor Israeli authorities had been able to provide them with any information about where her parents might be
column2: Keren said.

column1: But she had not lost hope they would be found.
Anytime someone calls us, any authority from the kibbutz or anywhere, our hearts sink down, and then they say, 'We don't have any new information.'
Shaylee Atary
column3: another Kfar Aza resident
column4: spent several days coming to terms with this feeling as well.

column1: She last saw her husband
column2: Yahav Winner
column4: on Saturday as he barricaded a window of their home to allow time for Shaylee and their 1-month old daughter
column5: Shaya
column6: to flee.

column1: He kept saying to me, 'This is not the day we are going to die,' Atary said.

We could hear the attackers walking on the grass outside the window. There was a crunching sound because the leaves have started to fall down because of the season. We couldn't talk because we didn't want them to hear our voices, so we were signaling silently to each other. And then, as they were breaking through the window, Yahav looked at me for a quarter-second. He didn't say goodbye, but I understood that it was like a kind of signal that I should run.
She fled first to some nearby bushes
column2: and then to an empty garden shed.

column1: And running
column2: for Atary
column3: is hard because of a car accident that has made it difficult for her to walk. She also was carrying Shaya.

column1: As she hid in the shed
column2: Atary found a hammer and screwdriver
column3: which she put in her pockets. She put some old pots on her and Shaya's head
column4: who was − miraculously − asleep.

column1: But then the baby woke up and began to cry
column2: which attracted the attention of the attackers. She could hear them walking toward her. She feared they would shoot into the shed indiscriminately.

column1: I knew I had to run again, she said. "But this time
column2: it was a decision
column3: not so much an instinct. So again I fled
column4: and when I reached a large grassy area that is in the middle of our kibbutz
column5: I thought 'Well
column6: maybe this is how I die
column7: despite what Yahav said.'"

column1: Moments later
column2: a family with children sheltering in their home saw her and ushered her inside
column3: risking their lives. She stayed in this safe room for the next 27 hours
column4: without food or water
column5: and as the oxygen in the sealed safe room dwindled
column6: before they were rescued by Israel's military.

column1: Yahav is a very protective, she said of her husband. "He's also smart. I believe he probably surrendered to allow us to escape."
Late Tuesday the news finally came. Yahav's body had been found.
In my head now, I tell myself that when he looked at me what he was saying was: 'Shaylee, you are with the child. I'm holding the door. Go', she said.
Then I think, why didn't I say: 'Don't be a hero. Come with me.'

The U.S. government announced it will provide charter flights for American citizens and their immediate families looking to leave Israel.
The flights
column2: which are set to begin on Friday
column3: will operate to locations in Europe where there is more commercial capacity across the Atlantic. U.S. citizens in Israel in need of assistance should complete the crisis intake form at travel.state.gov.

column1: “We are all acutely aware of limited availability right now on commercial flights out of Israel and the demand signal of U.S. citizens who may want to depart. The president has asked his team to ensure we are assisting U.S. citizens who do want to leave Israel in providing them with a safe means of doing that
column2: ” John Kirby
column3: coordinator for strategic communications at the National Security Council said during a White House press briefing Thursday. “We’re also exploring other options to expand the capacity of doing this including exploring whether it’s possible to help Americans leave by land and by sea.”

column1: Kirby said that the State Department is still finalizing details of the plan and did not make more specifics available.

It’s hard to wrap your mind around: The social justice warriors on college campuses around America have come out in support of terrorists who last weekend raped and murdered and beheaded innocent people (including children
column2: women and the elderly) in Israel.

column1: These are the same students who need safe spaces from those who may talk about race or gender in a way they find offensive
column2: or who will shout down and demand the cancellation of speakers with whom they disagree.

column1: Yet
column2: some of them seem perfectly OK with defending the atrocities committed when Hamas invaded Israel in a surprise attack in which the terrorists murdered at least 1
column3: 200 Israelis; 27 Americans also died and more than a dozen are missing.

column1: It seems the higher ed bubble has decided it’s “woke” to support Hamas and to shun Israel
column2: regardless of how horrific the situation.

column1: And even though many of these students believe “words are violence
column2: ” they defend real violence.

column1: Supporting Israel:Biden's response to Hamas terror attack was weak. US needs strong leadership to support allies.
Student organizations at more than a dozen prominent U.S. universities have issued statements pointing the full blame of the Hamas attack on the back of Israel. Those include Columbia University
column2: the University of Michigan Law School and Northwestern University.

column1: And on Thursday
column2: local university chapters of Students for Justice in Palestine are planning a “day of resistance” and “protest for Palestine.” In other words
column3: they are standing in solidarity with Hamas terrorists who just slaughtered innocents in the name of “resistance.”

column1: Sickeningly
column2: posters advertising the events highlight a paraglider. Hamas terrorists used paragliders to descend into Israel and proceeded to murder hundreds of young people at a music festival.

column1: Perhaps the worst offenders – or at least the ones who have received the most attention – are the more than 30 student groups at Harvard University who signed on to a letter stating they “hold the Israeli regime entirely responsible for all unfolding violence.”
“Today’s events did not occur in a vacuum
column2: ” the students state. “For the last two decades
column3: millions of Palestinians in Gaza have been forced to live in an open-air prison. Israeli officials promise to ‘open the gates of hell
column4: ’ and the massacres in Gaza have already commenced.

column1: “In the coming days
column2: Palestinians will be forced to bear the full brunt of Israel’s violence. The apartheid regime is the only one to blame.”

column1: The statement has unsurprisingly attracted backlash
column2: and the Harvard Undergraduate Palestine Solidarity Committee has since hidden the names of the other groups that signed on to the misguided missive.

column1: You can't say that:Oberlin coach stood up for women in sports. Then faced public shaming from her college.
The students haven’t apologized per se
column2: however. They simply seem taken aback that their outrageous views aren’t being welcomed with open arms.

column1: For instance
column2: some major CEOs and investors are calling on Harvard to release the names of the students who signed the statement – so that they can make sure they never employ these people.

column1: Harsh? Maybe. Deserved? Yes.
As Texas Republican Sen. Ted Cruz (and Harvard Law grad) posited on X
column2: formerly Twitter: “What the hell is wrong with Harvard?”

column1: Former Harvard President Lawrence Summers has also publicly called out the student statement: “Harvard is being defined by the morally unconscionable statement apparently coming from two dozen student groups blaming all the violence on Israel. I am sickened. I cannot fathom the Administration’s failure to disassociate the University and condemn this statement.”
As of this writing
column2: the Harvard administration has refrained from directly condemning the student statement.

column1: I’m a firm supporter of free speech
column2: and I think the lack of open debate on college campuses is a huge problem. While one can argue that these student groups have the right to say whatever they want
column3: it’s certainly worth questioning why so many "top" institutions are defending such awful acts.

column1: Canceling comedy:Hope for free speech? Kat Timpf riffs on the power of comedy and dangers of cancel culture.
It’s not just students who are to blame here. They are learning this behavior from somewhere.
Yale associate professor Zareena Grewal
column2: for example
column3: has come out openly in support of Hamas terrorism
column4: stating that “settlers are not civilians" after Saturday's attacks. And college administrations that like to issue statements on pretty much everything else have been noticeably silent now.

column1: Greg Lukianoff
column2: CEO of the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression
column3: recently put it this way: “If you find yourself
column4: you know
column5: cheering the people who are raping
column6: murdering
column7: kidnapping … shouldn’t that be a point for reflection?”

column1: It should.
For students and administrators who remain puzzled about how to respond to the attack on Israel
column2: Ben Sasse
column3: the president of the University of Florida (and former GOP U.S. senator)
column4: offered an excellent example:

column1: “Our educational mission here begins with the recognition and explicit acknowledgment of human dignity – the same human dignity that Hamas’ terrorists openly scorn. Every single human life matters. We are committed to that truth. We will tell that truth.”
Ingrid Jacques is a columnist at USA TODAY. Contact her at ijacques@usatoday.com or on X
column2: formerly Twitter: @Ingrid_Jacques

column1: Detroit Lions linebacker Alex Anzalone said in a social media post Thursday his parents are on their way home to Florida after being stranded in Jerusalem when war broke out between Israel and Hamas last weekend.
Thank you to everyone who has been saying prayers for my family and their safety, Anzalone wrote on X

The UAW strike against the Ford Kentucky Truck Plant is a signal that hourly workers are willing to inflict − and sustain − increasingly serious financial pain to achieve their goals during labor negotiations
column2: as the union and the Detroit Three approach a full month without resolution.

column1: The financial impact of the surprise strike called Wednesday night was swift and immediate.
LAS VEGAS – The Green Bay Packers aren’t a talentless team.
They probably have as much or more talent than two of the three teams that have beaten them this year.
But
column2: boy
column3: are they a bad team.

column1: Their offense is a mess. Their defense can be pretty good but only to a point. They are affected any time one of their starters can’t play because of injury. And they have too many players who just do what they’re told and not whatever it takes to be a difference-maker.

column1: Lior Onaly-Kelsey celebrated their 15th birthday two weeks ago. They also celebrated the end of a years-long battle against Greater Albany Public School District.
A federal jury in Eugene this month awarded them $317
column2: 353 in damages
column3: concluding the district had discriminated against Onaly-Kelsey when they were in the third grade and failed to properly respond to harassment and bullying.

column1: At a park near their house
column2: Onaly-Kelsey seems happy and curious
column3: eagerly sharing stories about rock climbing and participating in their current school's robotics club.

column1: Their excitement to be a teen attending a Corvallis high school is a stark difference from their emotions as an Albany elementary school student.
Indigenous land acknowledgments are everywhere.
After taking hold on college campuses
column2: they are recited with growing frequency at schools
column3: sporting events and church services.

column1: They are added as signatures at the end of emails. They are being posted on the websites of museums
column2: libraries
column3: and other institutions as the era of racial reckoning and social justice that has followed the emergence of the Black Lives Matter movement and the killing of George Floyd continues to evolve.

column1: They are even yelled at concerts
column2: as reggae artist Nattali Rize did during a recent show in Phoenix
column3: drawing loud applause.

column1: Some of the statements are as brief as a single sentence.
Spoon Daftary apologized into his headset for a slightly rushed segment
column2: but the clock was already ticking on this commercial break.

column1: Just go with the flow, the "Thursday Night Football" senior coordinating producer ordered from the command truck at FedEx Field
column2: not long after the Chicago Bears defeated the Washington Commanders. "Everyone have fun here."

column1: That’s usually not an issue for the traveling studio crew of Richard Sherman
column2: Andrew Whitworth
column3: Ryan Fitzpatrick
column4: Tony Gonzalez and host Charissa Thompson – the people Daftary is instructing from the truck. They were about to play a game
column5: he said
column6: as celebrity chef David Chang rejoined the set.

column1: It’s a simple premise. Producers from the truck will put up a name on the screen. The panel must answer whether that person played in the NFL or is a United States Congressperson – "On the Hill" or "On the Field" – all while chowing down on spicy chicken sandwiches from Chang’s restaurant.
Roll the dice here, Daftary said. "What can go wrong?"
NFL STATS CENTRAL: The latest NFL scores
column2: schedules
column3: odds
column4: stats and more.

column1: The hijinks may lose a viewer more interested in a traditional NFL post-game show. But for the type of content Daftary’s bosses at Amazon Prime Video desire
column2: this is par for the course.

column1: Now in the second year of exclusively streaming the games
column2: Daftary wants the postgame show to be memorable enough – through both creative bits and substantive football conversation – sports fans are talking about it Friday morning.

column1: My dream is somebody says, ‘Ah, (expletive), I fell asleep. What did I miss?’ Daftary told USA TODAY Sports. "That’s what I want to continue to push to our staff and to our talent. I want our show to be that: ‘I gotta stay up late to watch.’"
As Daftary and executive producer Mike Muriano started building the “TNF” studio team
column2: they were aware of the natural constraints all pregame
column3: halftime and postgame shows have structurally. But as Amazon became the league's first new media partner in nearly 30 years
column4: the company also saw the opportunity of a blank canvas.

column1: We're OK with this feeling a little more raw and authentic, I think, than sort of the polished Sunday morning pregame shows that I've been a part of in the past, said Daftary
column2: who spent nine years at FOX
column3: where he held the same role for "FOX NFL Kickoff."

column1: Daftary said FOX’s takeover of the NFC package in 1993 ushered in the modern era of studio programming. A streaming giant taking center stage for the NFL one night per week represented a chance to take another step toward the boundaries.
Collectively, we're just like, ‘We have to take some swings, we know not everything’s gonna be great, Daftary said. "But like
column2: we want to take the swings and see where we land."

column1: One place they landed this season was Intercourse
column2: Pennsylvania
column3: for a dispatch by contributor Marshawn Lynch from Amish country.

column1: That type of segment likely would not have been flown at network television. At Amazon
column2: it’s encouraged.

column1: It's refreshing, Muriano told USA TODAY Sports. "Sometimes
column2: senior management is saying ‘No
column3: push a little bit more’ and we're the ones going
column4: ‘Hey
column5: not that far.’"

column1: Finding talking heads who took the job seriously – but not necessarily themselves – has been essential in delivering a different type of show
column2: Muriano said. Their willingness to pitch ideas makes the show that much better
column3: he added.

column1: We've got a group that is invested that way, which again, that's so rewarding to see that you're not the only one trying to come up with everything, said Muriano
column2: who has been involved in producing every "Thursday Night Football" game in NFL history. "The show is better for it."

column1: Thompson
column2: Fitzpatrick
column3: Sherman
column4: Whitworth
column5: Gonzalez and the producers will have a video call – a 45-minute brain dump
column6: as Daftary put it – every Monday to discuss that week’s upcoming game. From there
column7: the producers begin outlining a show ahead of a Monday afternoon production call in which the sketch becomes more of a rundown. Last week
column8: when Daftary mentioned that Fitzpatrick lost his mind upon hearing that Commanders part-owner Magic Johnson would be joining the pregame show
column9: the producers started coming up with ideas to leverage his fanboying into a made-for-TV moment.

column1: Reading the letters Fitzpatrick wrote to Johnson as a boy was one idea. The crew brainstormed ways for Johnson to sign items for Fitzpatrick and how to place that into the segment. Of course
column2: it would have to be right before commercial break. And they’d have to make sure Johnson sat next to the former quarterback.

column1: When it was showtime 72 hours later

column1: Week 5 in the NFL provided needed perspective.
In all
column2: the slate didn't provide too many stunning outcomes or last-second twists. But four of the top 10 teams in USA TODAY Sports' power rankings suffered a loss this week
column3: and some of the top outfits continued to separate themselves from the pack as they expanded their body of work. Meanwhile
column4: other groups that had missteps in the first few weeks had the chance to start setting things straight − or see their seasons spiral further out of control.

column1: Here's our full rundown of the biggest winners and losers from Week 5 in the NFL:
What's scary about the 5-0 49ers is not solely the manner in which they thoroughly dismantled the Dallas Cowboys in a 42-10 blowout on Sunday night
column2: but rather that it all seemed a little ordinary. That's life as the clearly best team in football after five weeks.

column1: Still

column4: including three to tight end George Kittle. San Francisco managed to outgain Dallas by nearly 225 yards (422-197) and is now one of five teams in league history to score 30+ points in eight consecutive regular-season games. The defense
column5: meanwhile

column2: 122 yards) that fans had been hoping to see since this summer. Running back Travis Etienne wore down a gassed defense and ripped off a 35-yard touchdown to help put the game out of reach. And the defense kept Josh Allen off balance with consistent pressure via the blitz. With a manageable schedule before the Week 9 bye
column3: the Jaguars have a chance to create some distance in the AFC South race and set up a favorable outlook for playoff seeding.

column1: Netting one offensive touchdown against what is far and away the league's worst defense is nothing to brag about
column2: but Sunday was about far more than the stats for Hackett and the New York Jets. After Sean Payton opened up to USA TODAY Sports' Jarrett Bell by ripping into Hackett's performance last year as the Denver Broncos' coach
column3: both the Jets offensive coordinator and head coach Robert Saleh seemed to address the hypercritical comments through gritted teeth in recent months. No need to hold back anymore
column4: however

column6: maybe Breece Hall deserved the game ball over Hackett after he rescued the offense with his 72-yard scoring scamper and 177 rushing yards overall. But Hackett can now let the result – as well as the Jets' players and social media team – do all the talking for him.

column1: In the first four weeks of the season
column2: Ridder was a severely limiting factor for the Falcons' burgeoning offense
column3: which averaged a league-worst 156 yards through the air during that span. This week
column4: the second-year signal-caller was far more catalyst than caretaker in a last-second 21-19 comeback win against the Houston Texans.

column1: Ridder completed 28 of 37 attempts for a career-high 329 yards while tallying two touchdowns (one passing
column2: one rushing) to power the offense. Long-awaited connections with his top targets in tight end Kyle Pitts (seven catches
column3: 87 yards) and wide receiver Drake London (six catches
column4: 78 yards) finally materialized. And he deftly navigated the final drive
column5: completing all five of his passes for 44 yards to set up Younghoe Koo for the game-winning 37-yard field goal as time expired. Ridder's standing never seemed to be in question within the Falcons
column6: but this outing gives the offense something to build on.

column1: Maybe dispatching the Arizona Cardinals 34-20 in a get-right game doesn't completely undo the myriad setbacks the team suffered in its first four games
column2: but the Bengals appear to be on a much steadier course now. Burrow finally looked fluid and comfortable
column3: with much of his mobility seemingly having returned after the quarterback was hampered by a calf injury since the start of the season. And just one week after he explained in frustration that he's "always (expletive) open
column4:
Chase exploded for 15 catches, 192 yards and three touchdowns. The squeaky receiver gets the targets.
For all the histrionics about Cincinnati's start, the Bengals now stand at 2-3 with their star players seemingly back in a good place. There's still work to be done, but there's no reason to write this team off.
One of the more disappointing developments of September was the steadily building training camp buzz around Pickens – the Pittsburgh Steelers' ultra-promising second-year receiver – fading into a dull hum amid persistent woes plaguing his entire offense. For one week, at least, fans got a glimpse of the dynamic downfield threat that Pickens can be.
Trailing by four with just over two minutes remaining against the Baltimore Ravens, Steelers quarterback Kenny Pickett found the 6-3, 200-pound target on a back-shoulder throw for a 21-yard gain. Two plays later, Pickens dusted Ravens cornerback Marlon Humphrey – who was playing in his first game back after August foot surgery – for a 41-yard go-ahead touchdown in a 17-10 triumph. It's probably not the kind of play that the Steelers faithful can routinely expect from oft-criticized offensive coordinator Matt Canada. But incorporating Pickens more can only help invigorate what has been a languishing attack.
Throughout most of his time with the Cowboys, McCarthy has pounced on opponents with a significant talent deficit, allowing composed offense and opportunistic and highly aggressive defense to take care of overmatched foes. On Sunday, he got a reminder of what it's like to be on the other side of that dynamic.
It's not clear if the Cowboys could have done much differently to have had a semblance of a chance in Sunday night's catastrophic outing against the 49ers. What is apparent: As both as a coach and a play-caller, McCarthy proved to be no match for Kyle Shanahan. Dak Prescott said his three-interception night might be the most humbling game I've ever been a part of
column5: and McCarthy's avowed commitment to run the damn ball" produced a team total of 57 yards on 19 carries. In what was clearly designed to be a statement game for the Cowboys after the 49ers ended their playoff hopes in the past two seasons
column6: Dallas was outclassed in almost every facet. What McCarthy can muster might be enough to beat up on the bottom and middle tiers of the NFC
column7: but any notion of the Cowboys beating the 49ers – and potentially the Philadelphia Eagles – on the road in January seems like a distant dream.

column1: Suffering the two most lopsided losses of his career in consecutive weeks has left Bill Belichick and the Patriots in a particularly inauspicious spot. But there's a special indignity in the manner in which New England has dropped to this point
column2: a bespoke misery based on Belichick's specific buttons. At the root of it all is Jones
column3: whose head-scratching pick-six to Tyrann Mathieu in a 34-0 rout by the New Orleans Saints was the quarterback's third of the season and second in as many games. That kind of carelessness is no doubt maddening to a coach who hammers fundamentals and sound ball security. But Belichick is not merely the victim here
column4: as his slew of personnel mistakes over the last few years – as well as his befuddling offensive staffing decisions in 2022 – have severely hampered the third-year passer's development. After pulling Jones late again in Sunday's blowout
column5: Belichick again stood by his starter. But this pairing is looking more tenuous with each week
column6: and Jones might need to find mentorship elsewhere to get his career back on track.

column1: It took a truly multifaceted meltdown for John Harbaugh and Co. to squander what should have been a decisive victory. The formerly maligned receiving corps had a throwback performance in the worst way possible
column2: with Nelson Agholor and Rashod Bateman dropping surefire touchdowns. Lamar Jackson unraveled late in the fourth quarter with an interception that paved the way for Pittsburgh's comeback and a fumble that deflated any hopes for Baltimore's own rally. And prior to all that
column3: a blocked punt for a safety helped spark a Steelers team that had been stagnant.

column1: The slip-up could prove costly in the long run. The Ravens had a chance to begin pulling away from the pack in the AFC North
column2: but instead they fell into a first-place tie with Pittsburgh.

column1: Whatever mojo they had from last week's statement win over the Miami Dolphins must not have made it through customs for the overseas showdown with the Jaguars. The offense was imbalanced and error-prone. The defense was trampled for 29 first downs and 196 rushing yards.
Most worrisome
column2: however
column3: were the mounting injuries. All-Pro linebacker and defensive linchpin Matt Milano is expected to be out for the season with what multiple outlets have reported is a fractured leg and a knee injury
column4: and defensive tackle DaQuan Jones suffered a pectoral injury. On Sunday
column5: Buffalo already started to see the effect of losing top cornerback Tre'Davious White for the year to a torn Achilles
column6: with Jacksonville's receivers too often exploiting an overmatched secondary. If the Bills don't shore things up
column7: this could be a harbinger of the franchise's fate against the AFC's contender class.

column1: There's still no reason to sound the alarm on a No. 1 pick who's just four starts into his professional career. Still

column4: but chalk it up to a good play by a tremendously talented defender. The second of Young's two interceptions
column5: however

column1: An Oct. 4 Facebook post (direct link

column1: Follow us on Facebook! Like our page to get updates throughout the day on our latest debunks
This is wrong on multiple fronts. There is no evidence that Tagg Romney or Paul Pelosi Jr. are connected to the Ukrainian energy company Burisma at all. And
column2: accordingly
column3: there is no evidence of any criminal investigation along those lines.

column1: President Joe Biden's son Hunter Biden sat on the board of Burisma from 2014 to 2019. Some Republicans have claimed then-Vice President Joe Biden wrongfully used his power to force the removal of a Ukrainian prosecutor who was investigating the company
column2: but a 2020 Senate investigation found no evidence of wrongdoing on the part of the president.

column1: There is no evidence that the children of Utah Sen. Mitt Romney or former Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi were involved with the company. And there's no evidence of any investigation involving the two.
The Department of Justice has made no announcement of any such investigation
column2: and no credible news outlets have reported on a probe involving Tagg Romney and Paul Pelosi Jr.

column1: There is also no evidence that Newsmax reported on the supposed probe into the two men. Newsmax did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
The Facebook post is a new variation of a long-running claim of ties between Ukraine and the sons of various politicians.

column2: as well as the sons of President Joe Biden and former Secretary of State John Kerry
column3: were all on the board of directors for energy companies doing business in Ukraine. Only Hunter Biden has worked for a Ukranian company.

column1: There is no evidence that Tagg Romney or Paul Pelosi

column4: Jr. and Burisma Holdings were "completely false." USA TODAY reached out to the Department of Justice and the offices of Mitt Romney and Nancy Pelosi for comment but did not receive a response.

column1: Inflation is headed in the right direction but the road remains bumpy.

Consumer price increases stayed high in September after picking up over the summer as steady gains in rent and other services offset another decline in used car prices and a smaller rise in gasoline and food costs.
Consumer prices overall rose 3.7% from a year earlier
column2: similar to August's increase
column3: according to the Labor Department’s consumer price index.

column1: On a monthly basis
column2: prices increased 0.4% following a 0.6% rise in August that was fueled by a surge in pump prices.

column1: Protect your assets: Best high-yield savings accounts of 2023
Core prices
column2: which strip out volatile food and energy items and which the Federal Reserve watches more closely as it weighs interest rate changes
column3: remained high. They rose 0.3% last month after 0.2% bumps over the summer. The advance still lowered the annual increase to 4.1% from 4.3% in August
column4: marking the smallest gain since September 2021.

column1: Annual inflation has slowed significantly after hitting a 40-year high of 9.1% in June 2022
column2: including a sharp drop to 3% in the first half of 2023. But since then
column3: the cost of some goods and services has accelerated or pulled back more slowly
column4: pushing up the yearly rise.

column1: Prices for items such as used cars and furniture have dropped as pandemic-related supply-chain snarls have been resolved. But the cost of services such as rent
column2: car repairs and auto insurance
column3: have continued to drift higher in part because of briskly rising employee wages.

column1: As a result
column2: driving down inflation to the Fed’s annual 2% target is becoming a tougher slog. Barclays expects inflation broadly to dip to 3.3% in December and 2.6% at the end of 2024. Core price gains are projected to drift down to 3.7% at the end of the year and 2.8% at the close of 2024.

column1: Barclays expects the Fed to raise its key interest rate once more this year
column2: by a quarter percentage point
column3: after lifting it by 5.25 points in 16 months.

column1: But other economists say tumbling wholesale costs will prompt a faster pullback in inflation.

Overall, there is nothing here that will convince Fed officials to hike rates at the next...meeting, and we continue to expect a more rapid decline in inflation and weaker economic growth to result in rates being cut much more aggressively next year than markets are pricing in, says economist Andrew Hunter of Capital Economics.
Stocks were mixed in late morning trading as investors digested the uncertain odds of another Fed rate increase. The Dow Jones industrial average was down about 70 points
column2: or 0.21% while the S&P 500 index was up 2 points or 0.05%.

column1: Households
column2: meanwhile
column3: are still struggling. Although price increases are moderating
column4: costs are still high and many Americans say they aren’t feeling much relief.

column3: of Valencia
column4: California
column5: says he’s most frustrated by high gas and grocery costs. “It’s out there
column6: wherever you go
column7: ” says Novack

column1: He says he pays $6.50 a gallon for gas in California and as much as $135 for weekly groceries for him and his wife

column1: Gasoline prices rose 2.1% in September after surging 10.6% the previous month and they’re up 3% from a year earlier. Pump prices are well below their $5 peak in summer 2022 and are likely move lower in the short term following the busy summer driving season despite the Israel-Hamas war
column2: which has pushed up oil prices.

column1: Grocery prices rose more modestly
column2: inching up 0.1% and lowering the yearly increase to 2.4%. The cost of commodities such as wheat and corn generally have fallen as major producers Ukraine and Russia have found alternative shipping routes that skirt their 18-month war.

column1: Last month
column2: the price of breakfast cereal fell 0.5%
column3: while rice and fish both slid 1.3%.

column1: But some proteins moved higher. Bacon rose 4.8% following a 4% rise in August; uncooked ground beef increased 0.6%; and eggs jumped 0.9% after a string of declines.
Rent
column2: which has been the biggest inflation driver
column3: rose a sturdy 0.5% for the second straight month
column4: though that’s down from a spate of stronger gains. That nudged up the yearly rise to 7.4%. Economists expect rent increases to pull back
column5: based on new leases
column6: but that shift has been slow to filter through to existing leases.

column1: Generally
column2: the pattern of rising service costs fueled by healthy wage growth and falling goods prices continued last month.

column1: The federal funds rate is what banks pay each other for overnight loans. If that rate rises
column2: banks typically pass along that extra cost
column3: meaning it becomes more expensive to borrow as rates increase on services and items ranging from credit cards to home equity lines. That’s why the funds rate is the primary tool used by the Federal Reserve to try and put the brakes on inflation.

column1: When it costs more to borrow
column2: businesses and consumers are less inclined to do it
column3: and that means an overheated economy can cool and price increases may slow.

column1: Social Security recipients found out Thursday how much of a raise they will get next year. That’s because the consumer price index report contains data the Social Security Administration (SSA) uses to determine the cost-of-living adjustment or COLA for 2024.

column1: Inflation is a "generalized rise in prices
column2:
according to Josh Bivens, director of research at the Economic Policy Institute, a left-leaning think tank based in Washington D.C. The cost of items and services ranging from health care, to gas, to groceries can shift depending on inflation.  
When there are too few goods to meet the demand, prices are likely to rise, according to Investopedia. That disparity is called demand pull inflation. 
The Department of Labor has a tool that enables consumers to find out shifts in their buying power.   
The Consumer Price Index (CPI) looks at the average change in prices for particular products and services over a period of time, according to the Bureau of Labor Services.
It’s one inflation measure that the Fed and the economist use as a barometer to gauge price stability. The Fed’s preferred inflation gauge is the Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index, or PCE, prepared by the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA). The next PCE report for September is due Oct. 27.

Wages vs. inflation:US wage growth is finally outpacing inflation. Many Americans aren't feeling it.
Most of us seem to know that the average American lives between 70 and 80 years: 73.5 years for men, 79.3 for women, to be exact.
Fewer of us understand that life expectancy rises with age. An American man who turns 70 today will live to 85, on average. A woman of 70 will live to 87. 
That knowledge is called longevity literacy. Many of us don’t have it, and ignorance may cost us.
Let's say a man retires at 65 with $250,000 in savings. If he spends it down at a rate of $30,000 a year, the money might last him to age 73.5. But longevity tables say he can expect to live another decade, to 84.
A large share of older Americans, and especially men, don’t know how long their own retirement is going to last: in other words, how long they are going to live.
Longevity literacy matters when it comes to retirement planning. If your retirement budget assumes you will live to 75, and you make it to 85, you will probably run out of money.
“Moving into retirement, you have to think about, ‘When am I going to die?’” said Paul Yakoboski, a senior economist at the TIAA Institute, the research arm of the financial-services nonprofit. “That filters back on how I’m managing my money, how I’m drawing it down.”
The TIAA Institute publishes widely read surveys on retirement finance. When the institute asked Americans, in a recent survey, how long a man of 65 is likely to live, only one-third of the men gave the correct answer: 19 more years.
A larger share of men in the TIAA survey, 35%, underestimated the lifespan of a retirement-age male. Another 23% said they didn’t know. That response, in particular, left researchers bewildered: the question was multiple-choice.
Women seem to understand longevity somewhat better. In the survey, 36% correctly answered that a woman of 65 can expect to live about 22 more years, to age 87. Only 26% guessed low.
“Women just have a better grasp on that,” Yakoboski said. “The reality of most households, it’s the woman who focuses on the healthcare in the family and everybody’s wellbeing and caregiving issues.”
Their findings draw on a nationally representative survey of 3,503 adults.
Luigi Ferrucci is 69. According to official CDC data for human longevity, men live to about 74, which would give Ferrucci another five years.
But Ferrucci works at the National Institute on Aging, and he knows about longevity. If an American male reaches age 69, he can expect to live to 85, according to a simple longevity calculator from the Social Security Administration.
Ferrucci expects to live longer than that.
“My mother died at the age of 97, and my father died at the age of 98,” both in Italy, said Ferrucci, scientific director at the federal agency. He credits good genes and the Mediterranean diet.
The human lifespans reported by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are “calculated at birth,” Ferrucci said. Those are the numbers most Americans learn in school, the ones reported in the newspaper every year.
But life expectancy goes up from there. Simply put: The longer you do live, the longer you will live.
“Mortality is very high in the first year of life, and then declines, and then tends to increase gradually,” Ferrucci said.
TIAA has made longevity literacy something of an institutional crusade, putting out reports that warn of dire consequences for older Americans who do not plan for the full span of their retirement.
“You look at the numbers, there’s a good chance someone at 67 is going to be alive at 90,” Yakoboski said, speaking in a video conference call interview. “Some of those people are going to be alive at 100.”
His colleague, Andrea Sticha, chimed in: “The decision you have to make is whether to outlive your money or leave something behind.” Sticha is deputy academic director of the Global Financial Literacy Excellence Center at Stanford University.
The takeaway here is twofold, the researchers said: Figure out how long you are going to live, and make sure you have a retirement plan that covers those years.
The TIAA researchers have noticed that people with strong longevity literacy, about 12% of the population, are more likely than other adults to have a retirement plan. Conversely, people with a solid retirement plan tend to understand how long they will live. The two traits go hand in hand.
“Individuals with better longevity literacy do a better job planning and saving for retirement,” Sticha said. “There’s a very strong link between longevity literacy and retirement outcomes.”
Here are a few simple tips for retirement planning:
Sticha and Yakoboski collaborated with researcher Annamaria Lusardi on an August TIAA report on longevity literacy.
The scholars are alarmed that so many adults underestimate how long they will live. If anything, people should err in the opposite direction. If you are 65 now and expect to reach 85, plan for 90.
How much money do you need to retire?Most Americans calculate $1.8 million, survey says.
Roughly half of Americans have at least attempted to calculate how much money they will need to live comfortably in retirement, according to the Employee Benefit Research Institute's 2023 Retirement Confidence Survey.
And how much should you save for retirement? One analysis, from the investment firm T. Rowe Price, suggests a savings target of seven to 13 times your annual salary by age 65.
The EBRI survey found that only 64% of workers believe they will have the funds to last through retirement. The figure declined sharply over the past year. Americans are worried about nagging inflation and sagging retirement savings, which took a hit in 2022. The average 401(k) account lost about one-fifth of its value last year, according to Fidelity Investments data.
Budgeting for retirement is more important than ever, said Craig Copeland, director of wealth benefits research at EBRI, because more Americans are setting the budget themselves.
In decades past, many American retirees relied primarily on Social Security and defined-benefit pensions, funding sources that guaranteed steady payments until death.
Over time, the traditional pension has given way to the 401 (k) and other defined-contribution plans. Upon retirement, the worker sets the schedule for withdrawing the money.
“Longevity,” Copeland said, “is the key factor in that equation.”
We all have to face the prospect of aging at some point. We prepare for this reality for years in advance, starting 401ks, contributing to Medicare and Social Security as well as comparing insurance plans.
For many Americans, the goal is to have ample healthcare, a nest egg to retire on and the ability to age peacefully at home.
According to a new survey conducted between January and February of 2022, however, these goals are not being equally obtained by all. Conducted with 2,227 random Americans aged 50 to 80 online or via phone, the survey found that Black citizens were less likely to achieve aging in place.
This is thanks to a variety of factors, with the two most significant being self-reported disability status and income.
Social security changes:Why October 12 is a big day for Social Security recipients
Led by Sheria Robinson-Lane, assistant professor in the department of systems, populations and leadership with the University of Michigan's School of Nursing in Ann Arbor, the study published Oct. 4 in journal Geriatric Nursing found that nearly one third of adults aged 50–80 (30.9%) reported currently living with a disability.
Black adults experienced the highest rate of disability at 40% as well as higher rates of fair" or "poor" physical health at 37.1% versus 20.9% overall.

Inflation is a "generalized rise in prices
column2:
said Josh Bivens, the director of research at the Economic Policy Institute, a left-leaning think tank based in Washington D.C. For example, goods like gas, rent or food can be impacted by inflation. 
Inflation
column3: though
column4: really is meant to only refer to all goods and services
column5: together
column6: rising in price by some common amount
column7:
he explained. 
Inflation can be caused by several factors. The most common is a macroeconomic excess of spending over the economy's relative ability to produce goods and services
column8:
Bivens said. 
In this instance, more people are spending money on goods or services that are not readily available to meet those demands, so producers begin to raise prices.
If everyone in the economy
column9: tomorrow
column10: decided they weren't going to save any money from their paychecks
column11: and they're just going to spend every last dollar out of the blue
column12: they would all run to the stores and try to buy things
column14: producers haven't produced enough to accommodate that big surge of across-the-board spending. So
column15: you would see prices bid up."

column1: Another cause of inflation is a lack of producers. If there are not enough workers to produce the demanded good or service
column2: this would lead to an increase in prices as well
column3: Bivens said.

column1: Labor is the primary component of cost of producing anything, he explained.
There is also a level of "built-in inflation" within economies
column2: where central banks try to get inflation to hover roughly at a certain level.

column1: In the U.S.
column2: the Federal Reserve's target inflation is 2%. This means businesses can increase prices by 2% each year
column3: and it shouldn't impose a cost burden on consumers. Workers can also ask for a 2% wage raise based on these increases
column4: so they can still afford goods and services.

column1: That 2% is kind of the built-in inflation; what everyone expects to happen, Bivens said.
Rent inflation:Tenants struggle with rising rent as prices hit all-time highs
CPI stands for the consumer price index. It is a metric used by the US Bureau of Labor Statistics to gauge how much the price of consumer goods and services has changed over time.
It can effectively measure inflation in an urban market and give government officials and everyday citizens alike an idea of the health of the overall economy.
The most recent CPI report
column2: released in early August
column3: showed that consumer prices in July rose 3.2% from a year earlier
column4: up from a 3% annual rise in June but far below a four-decade high of 9.1% in June 2022. Month over month
column5: prices increased a modest 0.2%
column6: similar to June.

column1: In the most basic sense
column2: inflation is measured by comparing the current price of goods and services against their recent history.

column1: This is done by looking at a number of government-released data reports.
The CPI is the most prominent of these metrics. Released by the US Bureau of Labor Statistics
column2: the consumer price index measures the prices of goods in an urban market
column3: which represents over 90% of the American public.

column1: The CPI looks at a 'fixed basket' of some 80
column2: 000 goods and services to come up with these numbers. What gets put in that basket depends on the consumer expenditures survey which polls Americans to determine which goods are important. The importance of those goods then determines their weight in the CPI– for example
column3: the price of something like gasoline
column4: which forms an integral part of many people’s cost of living
column5: will contribute more than other items.

column1: The CPI does not just have one version though.

Another version – the chained consumer price Index for all urban consumers is used to adjust tax brackets. The virtue of the chained CPI is that it takes into account the product substitutions shoppers make
column2: which happens often when prices go up amid inflation. In doing this
column3: it provides a more accurate look at consumer spending and doesn’t overstate inflation.

column1: Inflation can also be measured through the price index for personal consumption expenditures (PCE). This metric
column2: released by the Bureau of Economic Analysis
column3: takes a more holistic view. Rather than calculating the change in prices for goods paid solely out of pocket for consumers
column4: the PCE takes into account all expenses
column5: including health care coverage compensated by insurance or the government.

column1: The PCE is what the Fed uses as its gold standard measure of inflation.
The final piece of the puzzle to factor in is ‘core inflation.’ This is a term used by economists to reflect the rate of inflation
column2: excluding prices for food and energy which are notoriously variable.

column1: If inflation goes beyond its target percentage
column2: though

column1: Whatever your target is, you don't want to go really far above that. You want people to be able to make plans and have a predictable sense of how much prices and wages will rise over the next year, Bivens said.
In order to control inflation
column2: one of the Federal Reserve's main tools is the federal funds rate
column3: which is the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans. If that rate rises
column4: banks generally pass on their additional cost to customers.

A big rise in the unemployment rate is going to put a lot of downward pressure on inflation, he said. "As the economy slows

column1: Favorite foods are often the centerpiece of holiday gatherings. Pumpkin bread and caramel apples at Halloween

column1: Another favorite holiday (and year-round) spice is cinnamon − a spice that's often purported to be as good for one's health as it is tasty in dishes like cinnamon rolls
column2: snickerdoodles and apple pie.

column1: A versatile and popular spice used for thousands of years
column2: cinnamon comes from various species of cinnamon trees scientifically known as Cinnamomum
column3: per The National Institutes of Health National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health (NCCIH). Such trees are native to Sri Lanka and India
column4: but they are also found in Indonesia
column5: China
column6: Vietnam
column7: and South America. Each locale harvests and processes various types of the spice
column8: but the two most popular kinds are cassia cinnamon and ceylon cinnamon.

column1: Cinnamon is unique because
column2: unlike the many spices that come from the root
column3: stem
column4: or leaves of a plant
column5: cinnamon comes from the inner bark of a tree. After being cut from young cinnamon trees and peeled
column6: the bark curls into the familiar rolls people associated with cinnamon. These rolls are called quills or sticks. Cinnamon is often sold as these bundles
column7: but it's also commonly ground into powder or processed into pill or oil form.

column1: Depending on its form
column2: cinnamon can be used as a spice in cooking
column3: for aromatherapy
column4: or as a health supplement.

column1: Though cinnamon has been studied extensively for many purported health benefits including ones involving diabetes
column2: insulin resistance
column3: and irritable bowel syndrome
column4: collectively the studies don't show that cinnamon clearly supports any health condition. Some such studies are certainly promising
column5: but results have been mixed and inconclusive overall. One reason why is because "some of these studies used different types and amounts of cinnamon
column6: and some studies were of poor quality
column7: explains Jill Weisenberger, MS, RDN, a Virginia-based registered dietician and author of Prediabetes: A Complete Guide."

column1: Still
column2: cinnamon has been associated with some general health benefits. As aromatherapy
column3: for instance
column4: cinnamon can be relaxing and stress reducing. Cinnamon is also known to have anti-inflammatory properties
column5: which could matter because inflammation is linked to a host of medical conditions including heart disease.

column1: Also promising are studies that show that cinnamon may lower LDL cholesterol
column2: known as "bad" cholesterol
column3: though such research is ongoing. "Cinnamon also contains antioxidants that can help protect the body from oxidative stress and free radicals which can play a role in reducing the risk of chronic diseases
column4:
adds Jen Messer, a nutrition consultant and registered dietitian at Jen Messer Nutrition.
What's more, some studies have also found a positive effect of cinnamon on metabolism
column5: she says. But she cautions to be wary of anyone who over exaggerates such effects, especially any claims that push cinnamon's ability to reduce belly fat or promote significant weight loss." She also warns anyone taking cinnamon for the purpose of improving insulin resistance to remember that
column6: "its effects on blood sugar can vary
column7: so cinnamon should never replace medical treatment for these conditions."

column1: Even though cinnamon may not have all the health benefits it's purported to
column2: it's also not likely to do harm in modest amounts.

column1: As a health supplement
column2: the NCCIH notes that cinnamon appears to be safe when taken as directed. But in large amounts - not typically cooking amounts - or when taken over long periods of time
column3: "cinnamon may become harmful to the liver
column4:
cautions Weisenberger. In high quantities, cinnamon is also associated with side effects like gastrointestinal issues, mouth sores, or allergic reactions. 
When used in cooking or added to tea or milk, however, Weisenberger says you should be comfortable using cinnamon regularly."

column1: Supporting Israel:Biden's response to Hamas terror attack was weak. US needs strong leadership to support allies.
Student organizations at more than a dozen prominent U.S. universities have issued statements pointing the full blame of the Hamas attack on the back of Israel. Those include Columbia University

column1: And on Thursday

column1: Sickeningly

column1: Perhaps the worst offenders – or at least the ones who have received the most attention – are the more than 30 student groups at Harvard University who signed on to a letter stating they “hold the Israeli regime entirely responsible for all unfolding violence.”
“Today’s events did not occur in a vacuum
column2: ” the students state. “For the last two decades

column4: ’ and the massacres in Gaza have already commenced.

column1: The statement has unsurprisingly attracted backlash

column1: You can't say that:Oberlin coach stood up for women in sports. Then faced public shaming from her college.
The students haven’t apologized per se
column2: however. They simply seem taken aback that their outrageous views aren’t being welcomed with open arms.

column1: For instance
column2: some major CEOs and investors are calling on Harvard to release the names of the students who signed the statement – so that they can make sure they never employ these people.

column1: Harsh? Maybe. Deserved? Yes.
As Texas Republican Sen. Ted Cruz (and Harvard Law grad) posited on X
column2: formerly Twitter: “What the hell is wrong with Harvard?”

column1: Former Harvard President Lawrence Summers has also publicly called out the student statement: “Harvard is being defined by the morally unconscionable statement apparently coming from two dozen student groups blaming all the violence on Israel. I am sickened. I cannot fathom the Administration’s failure to disassociate the University and condemn this statement.”
As of this writing
column2: the Harvard administration has refrained from directly condemning the student statement.

column1: I’m a firm supporter of free speech
column2: and I think the lack of open debate on college campuses is a huge problem. While one can argue that these student groups have the right to say whatever they want

column1: Canceling comedy:Hope for free speech? Kat Timpf riffs on the power of comedy and dangers of cancel culture.
It’s not just students who are to blame here. They are learning this behavior from somewhere.
Yale associate professor Zareena Grewal
column2: for example

column4: stating that “settlers are not civilians" after Saturday's attacks. And college administrations that like to issue statements on pretty much everything else have been noticeably silent now.

For students and administrators who remain puzzled about how to respond to the attack on Israel

column1: Over the past 20 years
column2: according to authors Gretchen Morgenson and Joshua Rosner
column3: the number of federal white-collar prosecutions fell by half. Think of the limited prosecutions following the 2008 financial crisis as proof. The question now is whether the high-profile trial of cryptocurrency magnate Sam Bankman-Fried is about to change that.

column1: First
column2: some history. In the 1980s after the savings and loan crisis
column3: the Department of Justice convicted more than 1
column4: 000 bankers. This aggressive approach reached its apex with 2006’s Enron trial.

column1: Since then
column2: though
column3: the number of white-collar prosecutions has dwindled. One reason may be that the financial machinations at the center of white-collar schemes became so complex that prosecutors hesitated to try to explain them to juries.

column1: Whatever the reason
column2: frustration is mounting. Populist movements have blossomed on the right and left
column3: sharing a distrust of the rich. Faith in institutions has plummeted. For my generation (I’m a millennial who graduated college in 2008)
column4: we have never known a world where these sorts of cases were the top priority for authorities.

column1: But now Sam Bankman-Fried
column2: known as SBF
column3: and his cryptocurrency exchange (FTX) have entered the chat. If SBF is convicted
column4: it will be Enron for millennials − a generational case that could resuscitate the practice of white-collar convictions. Here’s why.

column1: Set aside the complexity of margin loans
column2: digital currency and cross-border regulations. The question facing SBF’s jury is simple: Did he lie to − did he intend to trick − his customers and use their money as his own?

column1: Proving intent is hard. We cannot crawl inside the mind of a defendant.
Prosecutors instead use circumstantial evidence
column2: such as altered financial statements
column3: to connect the dots.

column1: Crypto's former golden boy is tarnished.What investors can learn from FTX's failure.
I’ve seen plenty of white-collar investigative files
column2: and proving intent will be particularly challenging here. SBF’s defense is that he was an absent-minded professor who lost track of how much money was going in and out of a booming crypto exchange.

column1: Showing intent is even harder when words such as “blockchain” also have to be explained to the jury.
And the stakes for winning are high. Forbes once called SBF the “richest self-made newcomer in Forbes 400 history.” For my parents
column2: I’ve explained it as the equivalent of indicting Warren Buffett.

column1: Will Trump go to prison?Why jail time is unlikely for the former president.
For those of us who work in white-collar law enforcement
column2: we’re watching closely. Prosecutors make decisions about what they think a jury will believe based on what they think society will accept. Will a jury of 12 folks − a teacher
column3: a physician assistant
column4: a train conductor − be able to wade through abstruse finance terms and find SBF guilty?

column1: If so
column2: it may imbue other prosecutors with confidence to take on similar cases.

column1: Or have prosecutors emerged from their post-2006 hidy-hole only to get kicked in the teeth? Was this the wrong case for such a gamble?
If so
column2: law enforcement will have another piece of evidence that financial fraud trials in the age of crypto (and collateralized debt obligations and every other complex instrument) may not be worth trying.

column1: Shad White is the state auditor of Mississippi.
This week
column2: the movie version of Taylor Swift’s record-obliterating Eras Tour opens in theaters around the world. It will be easier than ever to watch Taylor Swift perform. Really
column3: watching Taylor Swift do anything seems to be our national pastime. When she was photographed eating a chicken strip with ketchup and “seemingly ranch
column4: ” it made so many headlines that Heinz and the official Empire State Building entered the conversation.

column1: Swift has reached an unfathomable level of fame. One reason we can’t stop looking at her
column2: perhaps
column3: is that her career has always been built around relatability and identification. When we look at her
column4: we see ourselves.

column1: The concept of Taylor Swift’s Eras makes this even easier. As each of her albums has become associated with a distinct personality − a hairstyle
column2: color and vibe − people can look to Swift to express who they are and who they are not
column3: as well as how those categories shift over time.

column1: Taylor Swift first introduced us to the imagery of her eras and the idea of using different versions of herself to represent different albums
column2: moments and personalities back in 2017
column3: in the music video for the "Reputation" track “Look What You Made Me Do.” In it
column4: the different Taylors fight each other
column5: wrestle
column6: cry and hurl insults
column7: seemingly at war with each other. It’s a message about killing the old self and reinventing your identity to survive.

column1: The Eras Tour performance of “Look What You Made Me Do” says something new. Stomping around in a one-legged
column2: snake-bedazzled jumpsuit
column3: Swift slings lines like “The old Taylor can’t come to the phone right now … 'cause she’s dead.” Surrounding Swift on the massive stage
column4: the show’s dancers stand locked away in glass boxes
column5: each dressed like a different Taylor era.

column1: Instagram post registers record voters:Taylor Swift has power to swing the presidential election. What if nothing else matters?
Through visual performance cues
column2: Swift speaks to the experience of being misunderstood and misrepresented by others and the disorienting experience of letting yourself become defined by those outside assertions. Even as we accept those identities in an attempt to appease others
column3: all too often we’re left only with self-loathing. Ultimately
column4: her performance speaks to the things we do to ourselves when we let our identities become defined by the judgments of people around us.

column1: It is much easier said than done to refute or even ignore the identities the dominant culture expects us to perform. To use the parlance of “Look What You Made Me Do
column2: ” we are all made to play a role
column3: like it or not.

column1: The glass boxes the Taylors are trapped in call to mind glass ceilings yet to be shattered. They also put us on display
column2: easy to see
column3: as tokens of freedom and progress
column4: while still being stuck. Women today have more options about who we can be and where we can go than generations before us
column5: yes. But we are not yet fully free.

column1: We are given options of predetermined identities – ones that make sense to patriarchy – and asked to choose. Who do you want to be? Madonna or whore? Career woman or wife and mother? Pretty or smart? Sporty or flirty? Carrie
column2: Samantha
column3: Charlotte or Miranda?

column1: In some ways
column2: the zeitgeist has attempted to turn Swift’s eras into another one of these metrics. Are you the romantic "Fearless
column3: the upbeat 1989" or melancholic "Evermore"? We accept these categories
column4: use them to sort ourselves and let those categories set the expectations of how we should behave. In some ways
column5: this itself is somewhat liberating.

column1: Taylor’s eras offer women other markers of growth and identity beyond getting married and/or having children. As a single woman in her 30s with no children
column2: my life is sometimes seen by others as stagnant or empty. It’s an untrue assessment
column3: but one that’s pervasive still.

column1: Patriarchy looks first at how a woman is related to others
column2: typically men
column3: to determine who she is. I appreciate that Taylor Swift’s eras offer new ways of presenting aspects of my identity. Swift is also an unmarried
column4: childless woman in her 30s
column5: and her eras take seriously life changes
column6: interests
column7: milestones and identifications that are often dismissed or overlooked. Who do you want to be? Miss
column8: Mrs. or Ms.?

column1: As women learn to navigate gender roles and try to remain intact while navigating unfriendly systems
column2: we are not only expected to choose a box
column3: to select a label
column4: but also to eschew any other version ourselves that falls outside that box. Working mothers still face the "motherhood penalty" at the office. Full-time working moms make 74 cents to every working father’s dollar. Working mothers of color make even less. Attempts to exist in two boxes at once – even if both boxes are “approved options” by the dominant culture – are still punished.

column1: Taylor Swift has punk ethics:Rerecording albums to own her masters is infinitely more punk rock than I am
Taylor Swift hasn’t just rejected the dominant culture’s mandate to choose one identity
column2: she isn’t just the sum of her eras: She is herself − something we
column3: as entities existing outside of her – can never fully know
column4: much less dictate.

column1: This sort of celebration of nuance – an acceptance of and rejoicing in the fullness of female identity – is healing. As our lives become more and more restricted
column2: as the government rolls back women’s rights and our ability to choose what roles we will and will not play
column3: the Eras Tour rolls forward with a glimmer of hope.

column1: We can
column2: at least
column3: be nice to ourselves. And we can only ever dismantle oppressive ideologies if we cease trying to make ourselves acceptable to those ideologies. Together
column4: but rooted in our own self-actualized identities
column5: we can stop playing along with what patriarchy makes women do.

column1: Juliette Holder is a Ph.D. student studying rhetoric at Texas Woman’s University
column2: where she also teaches writing. Her research focuses on feminist rhetorics in popular culture.

column1: As an Iranian American political scientist and author of books on Iran
column2: Islam and the Middle East
column3: I am horrified by the cold-blooded slaughter and kidnapping of hundreds of Israeli citizens by the Iran-backed Palestinian groups
column4: Hamas and Islamic Jihad.

column1: No enlightened Muslim should conflate the legitimate grievance of Palestinians vis-a-vis the state of Israel with the utterly abhorrent and
column2: fully unlawful from the prism of international humanitarian laws
column3: massacre of Israeli civilians
column4: deserving the strongest unequivocal condemnation. What Hamas did with its massacre of innocent civilians was to rob the Palestinian movement of its moral rightness. Those who praise these acts of terror have no conscience. Iran must use its influence to gain the freedom of Israeli hostages. I also fully support the United Nations secretary-general’s call for an immediate end of Gaza’s siege.

column1: Contrary to the misguided celebration of some people in Iran and elsewhere in the Muslim world
column2: the moral standard of any decent Muslim can only guide us to nothing but strong denunciation of the abominable atrocities visited on innocent Israelis in the hands of Palestinian militants openly supported by Iran's hard-liners. The latter have now exposed Iran to potential retaliatory strike by Israel
column3: which has done absolutely nothing to Iran
column4: except helping Iran fight its Iraqi invaders during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war
column5: without which Saddam Hussein might have prevailed and wrested away a large chunk of Iranian territory.

column1: Indeed
column2: the last time I looked at the Middle East map
column3: Iran and Israel are distant from each other and there is no direct Iranian national security interest at stake in the long-standing Israel-Palestinian conflict
column4: except the zealous religious ideology
column5: resulting in Iran's hard-liners' overcommitment to an issue not germane to Iran's national interests at all.

column1: Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi
column2: who nowadays boasts about Iran's full support for Hamas
column3: needs to explain to the Iranian nation what is the connection between the Palestinian issue and Iran's national interests? And has he a short memory and forgotten that when the Iran-Iraq war ended
column4: there were upwards of 15
column5: 000 Palestinian prisoners of war in Iran's camps
column6: as many Palestinians volunteered in Hussein's army invading Iran.

column1: To open a caveat
column2: this author once taught at Tufts University and had a conversation with a great Palestinian writer
column3: the late Edward Said
column4: who never criticized Hussein and even questioned
column5: in his piece in Sunday London Times
column6: the accuracy of reports that Hussein had killed hundred of Kurds by using chemical weapons
column7: asking him why he never condemned Hussein's invasion of Iran
column8: since the UN had found him guilty of starting the war in 1980? Said's answer shocked me. "I am an Arab nationalist
column9: what do you think?" Until that moment I had thought that Said was beyond such petty nationalisms and was a cosmopolitan intellectual

column1: So
column2: the question remains: Why should Iran overcommit itself to a cause directly unrelated to Iran's national interests
column3: to the point of Tehran's leaders jeopardizing the nation's peace and security by providing full support for a brutal terroristic assault on Israeli civilians
column4: irrespective of how badly the current Israeli government has been mistreating the Palestinians?

column1: The Iranian government has not been installed in power to represent the Palestinians or any other nation
column2: only the Iranian nation
column3: which has a proud historical legacy related to Cyrus the Great's liberation of Jews and allowing them to return to their homeland and rebuild their temple.

column1: That enduring legacy of Iran's proud history ought to militate
column2: theoretically speaking
column3: against any religious-inspired tendency to succumb to the logic of exterminism vis-a-vis Israel put on full display by the Hamas militants terrorizing the civilians in southern Israel. So
column4: should in the next days or weeks
column5: Israeli bombs begin to fall on Iran's nuclear facilities in retaliation
column6: Iran's ruling clergy have only themselves to blame.
