column1: An expense report Tucker submitted to Michigan State for his hotel and meal costs showed the trip's purpose was “administrative” and did not involve any personal travel. The costs were paid by the Spartan Fund
column2: the athletic department’s fundraising arm; he had flown to Florida on a donor’s private plane.

column1: Tucker told Veidlinger he had canceled Tracy’s July 25 in-person training because his new mental conditioning coach
column2: Ben Newman
column3: needed to implement a new program. But Veidlinger would obtain records from the school showing Newman had been meeting weekly with the team since early June and did not hold any meetings between July 15 and 28.

column1: During the interview
column2: Tucker also made an explosive new allegation: He said his associate had told him that renowned ESPN investigative reporter Paula Lavigne was investigating the veracity of the gang-rape story at the heart of Tracy’s public persona. The information
column3: Tucker said
column4: made him question how Tracy “goes about her business.”

column1: Veidlinger did not address this allegation in her report
column2: but Lavigne denied the allegation.

column1: “Neither (Tracy's) organization nor Tracy is or has been the target of any investigative reporting
column2: ” Lavigne said in a statement to USA TODAY. “I’m perplexed that Mel Tucker would respond to a complaint of sexual harassment by involving me or ESPN.”

column1: Tucker did not identify any witnesses who could support his version of events
column2: including his associate
column3: whom he said he had promised anonymity. That same associate
column4: Tucker said
column5: told him that Alvarado
column6: Tracy’s assistant
column7: had been gossiping about his marriage – a claim Alvarado denied.

column1: Veidlinger delivered her final 106-page investigation report in July.
Along the way
column2: she had learned that one potentially rich source of evidence was missing: Both Tracy and Tucker had deleted their text messages with each other. Tucker would tell her that he deletes his messages regularly because he receives so many; Tracy said she did so in a panic after their last phone call
column3: feeling she needed to cut all ties with him.

column1: Per Title IX and school policy
column2: Veidlinger did not issue a finding of fault in her final report
column3: but instead summarized the facts and referred the case for a hearing.

column1: At the hearing
column2: planned for October
column3: both sides will have the opportunity to present evidence and make arguments. Another outside Title IX attorney hired by the school will then decide whether the evidence shows that Tucker likely violated school rules.

column1: Among the witnesses who will be missing from Tracy’s witness list is her assistant and best friend
column2: Alvarado. She died in a car accident in June.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Belveal argued Alvarado’s death “presents yet another reason that this case should be dismissed.”

column1: Letters Belveal sent Veidlinger throughout the case accuse her of bias against Tucker – and men more broadly.

One letter in May contained a list of 170 perceived problems with Veidlinger’s draft report and questions she should have asked Tracy and her witnesses. They included why Tracy had not returned Tucker’s gifts
column2: why she had given him her Venmo username and what opinions she held about Michigan State basketball coach Tom Izzo
column3: former football coach Mark Dantonio and former president John Engler
column4: all of whom had been associated with past sexual misconduct controversies.

column1: A fair process
column2: Belveal wrote
column3: would expose Tracy’s allegations as “nothing more than another agenda-driven attempt … to defame Respondent and the University.”

column1: “We request that the investigation be reopened
column2: ” Belveal wrote
column3: “that each of the questions be asked of the appropriate witnesses
column4: that jurisdiction be reassessed
column5: and that the matter be dismissed.”

column1: Kenny Jacoby is an investigative reporter for USA TODAY covering sexual harassment and violence and Title IX. Contact him by email at kjacoby@usatoday.com or follow him on X @kennyjacoby.
On a sunny Thursday morning
column2: Michigan State University football coach Mel Tucker strolled through tomato fields at a farm in Immokalee
column3: Florida
column4: toured its processing plants and loaded baskets of bright green fruit into a truck.

column1: It was a private event thrown by the school to promote its migrant student services program
column2: which provides financial aid and support to farmworkers seeking college degrees. After the April 28
column4: tour
column5: disclosed in records obtained by USA TODAY this week
column6: Tucker met with community leaders and alumni.

column1: That night
column2: Tucker would make the now-infamous phone call from his hotel room in nearby Naples
column3: during which he is accused of masturbating and making unwanted sexual comments to Brenda Tracy
column4: a prominent rape survivor and activist he had hired to speak to his team about sexual violence.

column1: Yet
column2: when Tucker met with the university’s outside investigator in March for his interview in the sexual harassment case against him
column3: he insisted the trip was not work-related – a claim the investigator would disprove in her report.

column1: It’s just one example of Tucker failing to keep his story straight at the most consequential moment of his career.
With his job
column2: reputation and the roughly $80 million left on his contract at stake
column3: Tucker repeatedly made false statements to the investigator and misled her about basic facts
column4: such as his location during the phone call and the date it occurred
column5: a USA TODAY review of more than 1
column6: 200 pages of case documents found.

column1: The investigator
column2: Rebecca Leitman Veidlinger
column3: and the news organization both obtained documents and witness statements that discredit key aspects of Tucker’s version of events.

column1: Michigan State suspended Tucker without pay on Sept. 10
column2: hours after Tracy went public for the first time with her story in USA TODAY. On Monday
column3: the school informed Tucker it plans to fire him for cause based on the conduct he had admitted to and the embarrassment he had caused the school.

column1: Investigation:Michigan State football coach Mel Tucker accused of sexually harassing rape survivor
Although Tucker denied sexually harassing Tracy
column2: he acknowledged masturbating on the call
column3: saying he and Tracy had been in a romantic relationship and had consensual “phone sex.” Tracy said Tucker’s romantic interest in her was completely one-sided and that she had tried to set boundaries multiple times during their yearlong business partnership.

column1: Per his contract
column2: Tucker has until Tuesday to make a case for keeping his job. Regardless
column3: a formal hearing to determine whether Tucker violated school policies against sexual harassment and exploitation is expected to proceed on Oct. 5 and 6.

column1: Since his suspension
column2: Tucker has issued multiple public statements defending himself
column3: attacking Tracy and accusing Veidlinger of bias. He accused the school of conducting a “sham” hearing and having “ulterior motives.” Yet even in these written statements
column4: the central details of his story changed entirely.

column1: Tucker
column2: who previously hung up on a reporter who called him on his cellphone asking about the case
column3: did not respond to a message seeking comment for this story. His attorney
column4: Jennifer Belveal
column5: has not responded to phone calls and emails. Tracy declined to comment for this story.

column1: In the absence of eyewitnesses or recordings
column2: sexual harassment cases usually boil down to whose account is more credible
column3: said Elizabeth Abdnour
column4: a Lansing-based attorney and former Michigan State Title IX investigator who has taken part in dozens of campus cases.

column1: “It’s very
column2: very unusual that you would have some outside piece of evidence that would give you a clear decision
column3: ” Abdnour said. “Very often you’re weighing credibility based on little bits and pieces of information.”

column1: In multiple cases she has worked
column2: Abdnour said the respondents lost because they were found to have a greater propensity for lying than the complainants. The hearing officer must determine how much weight to give Tucker’s false and conflicting statements
column3: Abdnour said
column4: and they could sway the case in Tracy’s favor.

column1: “I believe a fact finder could assess these pieces of evidence about credibility and make a determination that Brenda is more credible than Mel
column2: ” she said. “In my experience
column3: a clear sign of a lack of credibility is generally taken very seriously.”

column1: By the time Tucker met with Veidlinger for his interview
column2: he had had months to prepare.

column1: The school had informed him of Tracy’s complaint on Dec. 22
column2: the day after she filed it. Veidlinger had interviewed Tracy and all six of her witnesses by the end of January. Tucker was the only holdout.

column1: Rather than tell his side of the story right away
column2: Tucker and his attorney spent three months trying to stop the investigation
column3: case documents show. They wrote legal arguments urging Michigan State to drop the case and twice approached Tracy’s attorney proposing a settlement agreement. Tracy said no
column4: and the school pressed forward.

column1: On March 22
column2: the day of his interview
column3: Tucker sent Veidlinger a seven-page written account of his interactions with Tracy and lists of their “currently existing” text message and call history
column4: which he said his legal team had compiled. Only a handful of text messages remained; he and Tracy both told the investigator they had deleted their texts with each other in the months after the April 2022 phone call.

column1: In his interview
column2: which lasted 3 ½ hours
column3: Tucker questioned whether Tracy had mixed up the date of the call. He said he recalled being at his home in East Lansing when it occurred
column4: but his own records showed that he had been in Florida on April 28
column5: attending a charity function that was “absolutely not a University-sponsored event.”

column1: His seven-page account told a different story – that he had called her while he was “alone in a hotel room.”
Veidlinger does not appear to have asked Tucker about the discrepancy
column2: based on case documents. But by then she knew what he told her in the interview was untrue: she had already obtained records proving he had not been home in East Lansing.

column1: An expense report he had submitted to the university for reimbursement of his hotel and meals shows Tucker flew to Naples
column2: Florida
column3: to attend a golf fundraiser hosted by The Greg H. Montgomery Jr. Foundation for Ultimate Growth
column4: which raises awareness for suicide prevention. It showed he stayed at the Hilton from April 27 to 29
column5: that the trip’s purpose was “administrative” and that it did not involve personal travel. He had flown there on a donor’s private plane.

column1: The trip is when Tucker toured the farm in Immokalee to help promote Michigan State’s College Assistance Migrant Program. The event was titled “Working to make dreams a reality
column2: ” according to an agenda obtained from the university by USA TODAY through a public records request. The agenda features Tucker’s name prominently. Tucker posted photos from the tour on his Twitter account.

column1: That Tucker was on a university-sponsored work trip during the incident was a contributing factor in the university’s determination that it had jurisdiction to investigate
column2: the investigation report shows.

column1: Tucker’s lists of calls and text messages also were missing an important detail: They did not show any communication with Tracy on April 28. He acknowledged in the interview
column2: however
column3: that he had not reviewed the lists before submitting them and that they may have been incomplete.

column1: Tracy
column2: meanwhile
column3: had already provided Veidlinger with her official cellphone records from Sprint that confirmed the date of their call: April 28.

column1: Tucker and Tracy did not speak in the three months after the April 28 call.
Meanwhile
column2: their assistants were planning Tracy’s third visit to campus – an in-person training with coaches and players scheduled for July 25.

column1: Tucker canceled that training three days before
column2: the investigation report shows. When Tracy spoke to him by phone on Aug. 2 seeking to find out why
column3: she would tell the investigator in her interview that Tucker insinuated he would harm her career if she spoke about his conduct. He never rescheduled her visit
column4: and they never spoke again.

column1: The cancellation became a key focus of the investigator – one of a series of alleged incidents that taken together would meet the definition of sexual harassment
column2: which can include pressuring someone into engaging in sexual behavior for an employment benefit and threatening that rejecting such behavior will carry a negative consequence.

column1: “Reported allegations that a University employee is engaging in misconduct within the vendor-vendee relationship for which they are the decision-maker
column2: and/or impeding in such a services relationship based on a quid-pro-quo sexual harassment allegation
column3: is within a University sponsored program or activity
column4: ” Veidlinger wrote in the report
column5: so school policy covered it.

column1: Tucker tried to distance himself from the cancellation in a public statement on Sept. 11
column2: the day after Michigan State suspended him without pay.

column1: “I never cancelled any presentation
column2: ” he wrote. “Given a personnel change and scheduling challenges as football season approached
column3: we merely postponed it until January 2023. She chose to file her complaint instead of proceeding with the training.”

column1: But that statement contradicts what he told the investigator. When Veidlinger asked in his March interview if he had a role in canceling Tracy’s visit
column2: Tucker said
column3: “Yes
column4: absolutely I did
column5: ” the report shows
column6: and that he did not recall any discussions about rescheduling Tracy for January. Such timing would not make sense
column7: he added
column8: because most of his new players would not yet be on campus.

column1: Tucker also told the investigator why he canceled the visit
column2: blaming it on a scheduling conflict. He said he had recently hired a mental conditioning coach
column3: Ben Newman
column4: who needed to implement his new program on short notice. There was limited time in fall camp
column5: Tucker said
column6: and he didn’t want to “overwhelm” the players. He said he decided to yield the time to Newman.

column1: Veidlinger
column2: however
column3: would later obtain records showing Newman did not meet with the team on July 25
column4: the day of Tracy’s planned visit. He had been meeting with them weekly since June 6
column5: the records showed but held no meetings between July 15 and July 28.

column1: One of Tucker’s assistants
column2: who is a witness in the case
column3: also told the investigator that Tucker asked him via text message to cancel it. He said he was never instructed to reschedule.

column1: In his interview
column2: Tucker told Veidlinger that his relationship with Tracy frayed after the April 2022 phone call – not because of the incident
column3: but because of information he learned after that caused him not to trust her.

column1: According to Tucker
column2: an associate of his had told him over the summer that Tracy’s assistant
column3: Ahlan Alvarado
column4: had been gossiping about Tucker’s marriage
column5: telling others it was “on the rocks.” Tucker said he was “devastated” because he had confided in Tracy about his marital problems
column6: and he believed she had discussed them with Alvarado.

column1: Tucker confronted Tracy about the alleged gossiping during the Aug. 2 phone call
column2: they both told the investigator. Tracy said he berated and bullied her
column3: repeatedly saying he could not trust her. She said she told him she did not know what he was talking about.

column1: Alvarado – who was killed in a car crash in June – would deny discussing Tucker’s marriage with anyone in her January interview with Veidlinger.
During the Aug. 2 call
column2: Tracy said she pressed Tucker to identify his source – the associate. She told Veidlinger she believed Tucker had made it up as a pretext for canceling her visit and ending her relationship with the school.

column1: Veidlinger also asked Tucker to reveal the source of his claim
column2: but he refused to say. In her report
column3: she wrote that he said he had “given (his) word that (he) wouldn’t divulge their name.”

column1: Tucker never revealed the associate’s name to the investigator
column2: nor did he identify anyone who could support his version of events. In his Sept. 11 public statement
column3: however
column4: he lamented that the hearing would not afford him the opportunity to “offer any substantive evidence of innocence.”

column1: It was not the only claim he attributed to his anonymous associate. In his interview
column2: he said that same person told him that ESPN investigative reporter Paula Lavigne was investigating how Tracy “goes about her business” by claiming to be a rape survivor.

column1: Tucker said this further caused him to believe Tracy was untrustworthy because she believed Lavigne was her friend but didn’t know she was investigating the rape story at the center of her public persona.
It turned out to be yet another falsehood.
Reached by USA TODAY
column2: Lavigne said in an emailed statement that she was “perplexed that Mel Tucker would respond to a complaint of sexual harassment by involving me or ESPN.” She said Tracy has been a source of information for her for several years
column3: and that she has featured Tracy’s comments and advocacy work in multiple news stories.

column1: “That has been the extent of my reporting on Tracy and her organization
column2: ” Lavigne wrote. “Neither the organization nor Tracy is or has been the target of any investigative reporting.”

column1: Asked who might have told Tucker this misinformation
column2: Lavigne responded
column3: “I have absolutely no idea who would have alleged this to anyone.”

column1: Kenny Jacoby is an investigative reporter for USA TODAY covering sexual harassment and violence and Title IX. Contact him by email at kjacoby@usatoday.com or follow him on X @kennyjacoby.
Contributing: USA TODAY reporter Steve Berkowitz.
The bullets came in plywood crates.
Any given box was about the size of a small microwave oven. The printed label stuck to each one demonstrated a militaristic brevity. “CARTRIDGES FOR WEAPONS
column2: INERT PROJECTILE
column3: ” next to a bright yellow hazmat sticker
column4: “EXPLOSIVES.”

column1: Inside the boxes: drab green steel cans of .50-caliber ammunition. Each round was giant
column2: more than 5 inches long
column3: built to be fired from a gun so big it is typically bolted to a truck. The bullets were clipped together in long strands for rapid
column4: machine-gun fire.

column1: By the time Bill Brown got to the boxes
column2: they sat double-stacked eight high atop wooden pallets inside a Missouri warehouse. The pallets went on
column3: row after row. Three million bullets in all.

column1: It was enough ammunition to feed a single machine gun – if fired nonstop at its rated speed eight hours a day
column2: seven days a week – for almost six months.

column1: Brown’s job was to get it out of there and toward the Ukrainian front lines. The faster
column2: the better.

column1: “War is bad
column2: ” Brown said. “Loss of life is bad. But at the end of the day
column3: it’s very profitable and injects revenue into this military industrial base.”

column1: There would be virtually no public record of this Ukrainian arms shipment. As a weapons dealer
column2: Brown’s company would deliver the bullets under a system known as a direct commercial sale. The ammunition required a State Department signoff – but the secret deal would never appear in a White House announcement or the Congressional Record.

column1: Instead
column2: it was part of a shadowy system of brokers
column3: exporters
column4: arms dealers and country-to-country transfers that has become one part of the race to meet demand on distant battlefields.

column1: Western weaponry fueled Ukraine’s summertime counteroffensive along a 600-mile front. President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said the effort was delayed in part by the wait for more arms. Amid concerns about that slowly progessing counteroffensive
column2: Secretary of State Antony Blinken arrived in Kyiv on Wednesday with a promise of up to $175 million more in military equipment.

column1: Most of America’s $44 billion in documented support to Ukraine came in the form of old U.S. military stock
column2: donated directly by the federal government. In general
column3: commercial sales over $14 million
column4: and sales of military-grade weaponry like mortars or missiles
column5: require State Department approval and congressional notification.

column1: But other aid comes via private sales.
More than 14
column2: 000 U.S. entities are registered to conduct defense trade activities. Their deals are monitored by an alphabet soup of agencies including Departments of Homeland Security
column3: Commerce
column4: Defense and the Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco
column5: Firearms and Explosives. Trade secrecy clauses in federal law mean this flow of gear
column6: weapons and ammunition is almost never revealed to the public.

column1: Brown
column2: who works for a small Nevada-based logistics company called Battle Born Munitions
column3: provided USA TODAY with a rare look behind the curtain of these private sales. Details about the shipment were verified by his employer and the European government that made the purchase. State Department officials declined to answer questions about the specific shipment Brown described.

column1: This March sale and the secret number of other shipments like it fuel Ukraine’s fight against a Russian invasion. Those sales also release an unknown amount of weaponry into the world. What becomes of that weaponry after it’s sold – and especially after it’s delivered – is difficult to track.
As Brown surveyed the warehouse in Missouri
column2: a crew steered forklifts and skid lifts among the stacks of plain wooden boxes. From high in the trusses
column3: suspended lamp fixtures bathed the boxes in artificial daylight. Brown lifted his camera and started snapping photos.

column1: In just a few hours
column2: he and his cargo would be boarding a jumbo jet. Three million bullets would climb to the stratosphere and hurtle across the north Atlantic toward a European dawn.

column1: From Ukraine:War crimes in Ukraine may be unprecedented. So is the country's push for swift justice.
The bullets had once been bound for Saudi Arabia.
Lot number SMQ19K401L026 had rolled off the assembly line in 2019 at Lake City Army Ammunition Plant near Kansas City. Lake City
column2: owned by the government and run by a contractor
column3: sprawls across nearly 4
column4: 000 acres of green Missouri farmland. Roads curve past World War II-era bunkers known as igloos
column5: spaced out amid the countryside – far enough apart that an explosion in one won’t trigger a chain reaction in the others.

column1: Lake City has been pumping out ammunition almost without pause since 1941. It is the largest small-arms manufacturing plant in the world.
Today the plant is run by Olin-Winchester
column2: but in 2019
column3: the bullets were made by some of the 1
column4: 700 workers employed by Northrop Grumman. And in 2019
column5: Saudi Arabia was stocking up on weapons during the Trump administration
column6: fueling the war in Yemen and other conflicts that drew criticism from congressional Democrats.

column1: The plant manufactures .50-caliber ammunition on a rolling basis
column2: for both military and commercial buyers. That’s a testament to just what a legend the bullet – and the gun that shoots it – has become.
the technology was already a century old. The .50 caliber was the brainchild of American gunsmith John Browning during World War I. Built to respond to German anti-tank rifles
column3: the M2 was first tested in 1918
column4: and it entered widespread service in 1923. It earned the nickname “Ma Deuce” and has served in combat ever since
column5: bolted to trucks
column6: ships
column7: planes and handheld stands on the battlefield.

column1: The .50-caliber rounds – named for their diameter
column2: about half an inch – can easily hit targets more than a mile away. At closer ranges
column3: they will blast through solid concrete or armored vehicles. The gun can fire at a sustained rate of about 40 shots per minute.

column1: Military setups use strings of “linked” ammunition to feed into machine guns. Spaced out after every fourth bullet
column2: so-called tracer rounds have small pyrotechnic charges that illuminate the line of fire
column3: aiding in targeting.

column1: The gun’s longevity and versatility made it popular for militaries the world over. But this particular batch of bullets wouldn’t end up being sold to Saudi Arabia.
The Biden administration put a temporary freeze on sales to the Saudi government in 2021 as it reviewed weapons deals approved under Donald Trump. Instead
column2: Brown said
column3: the bullets were sold to a U.S. ammunition provider
column4: only to be held up again. Ultimately
column5: they were mothballed.

column1: Then
column2: in spring 2023
column3: the bullets found a buyer
column4: or actually two: first Battle Born; ultimately
column5: the Netherlands.

column1: The European country
column2: a NATO ally
column3: needed a big supply of ammunition. It wouldn’t be keeping the bullets but giving them to Ukraine. Its purchase
column4: essentially a donation
column5: would count toward the country’s required NATO contribution.

column1: Brown had a line on exactly what they needed. It was sitting in the warehouse in Missouri.
He arrived in March to personally oversee the shipment. As he prepped for delivery
column2: Brown dropped tiny black tracking devices onto several of the pallets. Just $55 apiece
column3: the units use GPS and cell signals to keep tabs on the load. The idea was to ensure it wouldn’t fall into the wrong hands.

column1: But packing up the bullets was just the beginning. As with anything that’s deadly and made of metal
column2: the shipping costs can be extreme.

column1: Brown said the question for the buyer was simple: “How fast do you want it? Forty-five to 60 days on a ship? Or in five days if I fly it?”
Brown – or Chief Bill
column2: as he prefers – is a no-nonsense 35-year veteran of the U.S. Army and former helicopter pilot. He retired as a chief warrant officer and lives in Orlando.

column1: Now 59
column2: he still spends a lot of time on the road – 10 international trips this year. He says his arms logistics work takes him to places most Americans would rather avoid – near the Syrian border or to unstable regions of Iraq.

column1: He’ll travel halfway around the world
column2: he quips
column3: “have some soup
column4: and go back to Warsaw to head home.” The trips aren’t really about the destinations. They’re about the cargo.

column1: On that spring day in Missouri
column2: forklifts carefully loaded 107 pallets of the ammo onto 18 flatbed semitrailers. They’d all make the eight-hour drive to O’Hare International Airport.

column1: In Chicago
column2: two Boeing 747-400s operated by National Airlines would be ready for the freight.

column1: Four pallets each were stacked and shrink-wrapped to create “air pallets” or “cookie sheets” weighing 12
column2: 800 pounds. Each plane could carry up to 17 of the pallets that ran the length of each plane secured by white cargo netting.

column1: Flight records Brown provided show the two planes departed about seven hours apart
column2: one in early afternoon
column3: one after dark.

column1: The flight would take nine hours. Brown wasn’t going to the Netherlands
column2: even though it was the buyer. The planes were bound for Rzeszów
column3: Poland.

column1: The ancient city sits at the foot of the Carpathian Mountains in southeastern Poland. It has a gleaming modern airport next to a major east-west freeway. From there
column2: it’s barely 60 miles to the border with Ukraine.

column1: It was an expensive journey. The trucking company’s bill for those 18 semis? $85
column2: 000. Chartering the two 747s? $625
column3: 000. Each.

column1: But this shipment of .50-cal rounds was profitable for Battle Born Munitions
column2: according to Brown.

column1: The company purchased the 3 million rounds from Northrop Grumman at a bargain and resold them for more than double the price. (In subsequent interviews
column2: representatives at BBM disputed the specific totals Brown mentioned
column3: saying the accurate figures were protected by “various commercial and government non-disclosure agreements.” They did not dispute the other specifics of the deal he provided.)

column1: Retail prices for .50-caliber ammunition run roughly $5 per bullet. At that rate
column2: the whole shipment would have been worth $15 million.

column1: The pricing might also be elastic. The Dutch mark up the price of the bullets and count it toward their NATO contribution
column2: pegged to a percentage of gross domestic product
column3: Brown said. The Netherlands has contributed about $15 billion to NATO this year
column4: or about 1.7% of its GDP and just under the NATO mandate of 2%.

column1: Representatives of the Dutch military confirmed the shipment to USA TODAY but declined to comment further about the pricing or details.
The war in Ukraine has only increased the demand for private deals. The State Department signed off on more than $154 billion in commercial arms deals directly to foreign countries in 2022
column2: a 48% increase from the previous year.

column1: Direct commercial sales represent a modest portion of the contribution to Ukraine compared with the $44 billion donated by the U.S.
column2: but they still amounted to more than $600 million in sales from U.S. companies to the Ukrainian government last year alone. That doesn’t include sales to other countries that also support Ukraine – sales like the one Brown described.

column1: Jim Bartlett
column2: an attorney with expertise in the specialized international arms transactions
column3: said private U.S. businesses are playing a small but important role in the conflict.

column1: “American companies are happy to export defense articles to foreign buyers approved by the U.S. State Department
column2: ” Bartlett said. “There’s an effort at the State Department to quickly clear the ones headed for Ukraine. … You get head-of-the-line privileges.”

column1: Those sales also come with risks.
Direct sales face fewer regulatory controls
column2: oversight and enforcement
column3: said Robert Nichols
column4: an international military sales expert and attorney at the law firm Nichols Liu.

column1: “You can imagine the range of characters involved in supplying a war effort
column2: ” Nichols said. “Some are highly credible. Others will skirt the law and sometimes step over the line by paying bribes
column3: committing fraud and hiding their transactions.”

column1: So far
column2: the Department of Justice has indicted just a handful of arms brokers over deals related to the war in Ukraine. Court records show the government has charged Miami-based Oleg Patsulya and Vasilii Besedin with illegally attempting to sell American-made aircraft parts to Russia. They allegedly lied to Commerce Department agents and told them the parts were bound for Turkey. Both pleaded not guilty to the charges this summer.

column1: A State Department spokesman declined to provide details of enforcement actions but said
column2: “The United States takes seriously our responsibility to protect American military and dual-use technologies and prevent their diversion
column3: including through strong enforcement actions.”

column1: NATO said it oversees allied arms deliveries
column2: and that those arms generally reach Ukraine. NATO itself technically only provides non-non-lethal aid
column3: like fuel
column4: medical supplies and generators.

column1: Brown
column2: of Battle Born
column3: says he fields calls weekly from “clowns” without the proper licensing
column4: whom he reports to the State Department for potential violations. Some raise red flags when they approach him about transactions that include payment via diamonds or gold.

column1: He prefers traditional wire transfers with approved sales partners since he knows government officials are watching. He validates the contracts and checks certificates for the final users. That’s part of why he traveled with the ammunition. He would be meeting a Dutch military official for the official handoff.
“My job is to keep us all out of jail
column2: ” Brown said.

column1: The two 747s touched down in Poland
column2: one before the sun
column3: the other in late morning. Brown exchanged paperwork with a young Dutch military staffer who signed for the delivery
column4: he said. They traded military patches as souvenirs. They snapped a photo together.

column1: The bullets bought by the Netherlands would never touch Dutch soil.
U.S. aid:Billions from the US flows to Ukraine. Here's where it comes from
column2: and how it adds up

column1: Despite playing a small role proportionately in the war
column2: $600 million in direct commercial sales can buy a lot of small weaponry.

column1: And those weapons are the kind most apt to fall into illicit use
column2: said Elias Yousif
column3: a research analyst at the Stimson Center
column4: a nonprofit think tank.

column1: Put another way: It’s hard to sneak away an F-16 or a missile launcher the size of a tractor-trailer. But a bunch of guns or a pallet of ammo? Much easier to resell.
“In the commercial sector
column2: especially in a new market
column3: the risk increases
column4: ” Yousif said.

column1: After Russia invaded Ukraine in 2014
column2: the Small Arms Survey
column3: a Swiss arms research project
column4: estimated that within a year
column5: battlefield seizures and other forms of diversion led to 300
column6: 000 small arms and light weapons going missing
column7: including 100
column8: 000 in Crimea alone.

column1: When small arms go missing
column2: they can go missing into another country
column3: maybe one led by a despot or even a terrorist organization.

column1: The U.S. government says diversion of American donations has been widely absent so far in Ukraine. That could be a combination of intensive “end-use-monitoring” programs and the reality of the battlefield
column2: where supplies are rapidly put to use.

column1: But even if not now
column2: unused ammo could be resold someday.

column1: “History shows us this isn’t a short-term issue
column2: ” Yousif said.  “These are commodities with very long shelf lives.”

column1: Florida-based Global Ordnance
column2: another State Department-licensed exporter
column3: is a competitor in the direct weapons sales business. General counsel Bryan Van Brunt said the company has extensive protocols in place to track shipments and make sure the end-users are federally approved
column4: though he declined to provide specifics about those systems.

column1: Brown
column2: with Battle Born Munitions
column3: says the company employs a mix of simple and sophisticated tracking technology to ensure his shipments are tracked to end users. The black GPS devices he dropped onto his cargo tracked the ammo all the way across the globe.

column1: But that system only works as long as Brown is actually tracking. “Technically
column2: my role ends when I deliver it to NATO
column3: ” he said.

column1: Sometime after the 747s touched down in Poland
column2: along with signing the paperwork and snapping a selfie with the Dutch official
column3: Brown found the tiny black GPS trackers and lifted them off the pallets.

column1: Ukrainian trucks would arrive at the airport to pick up the ammunition. They would point toward the border
column2: and onward to Lviv
column3: and some distant battlefield.

column1: Brown would point in the opposite direction. Just like one of his quips: Fly in
column2: have soup
column3: get home. He headed toward Warsaw
column4: with the GPS trackers in his bag.

column1: Nick Penzenstadler is a reporter on the USA TODAY investigations team. Contact him at npenz@usatoday.com or @npenzenstadler
column2: or on Signal at (720) 507-5273.

column1: The geography professor didn’t hide his clown fetish or the fact that he sometimes indulged his urges by recruiting students as subjects. He posted regularly about it on social media.
“I have a facepaint fetish and convince the cute girls in my classes to let me paint their faces
column2: ” he once wrote.

column1: Yet Joseph Tokosh held jobs at two colleges and was on the tenure track at a third before student journalists at Nicholls State University in Louisiana exposed his behavior. He submitted his resignation the same day their story was published.

His interactions with students and open discussion of his fetish happened in both mainstream and tailored digital spaces. He popped into Facebook groups geared toward new students and niche forums on websites like Reddit. He posted videos on YouTube. In one Reddit post on a forum meant to highlight hard-to-believe stories
column2: Tokosh posted pictures of several women in white face paint.

column1: Over the years
column2: two students reported him to campus police; others complained online. He left Kent State University after pleading no contest to something different: a theft charge that involved entering his peers’ offices without permission and taking a USB drive. Tokosh has not been charged with any other crime.

column1: Tokosh’s career trajectory exposes inadequacies in the background check system that colleges and universities are supposed to have in place to protect students – especially when evidence of the concerning behavior resides largely on the internet. Nicholls State
column2: for example
column3: told USA TODAY Network reporters it does not routinely check social media for new hires.

column1: A federal law intended to ensure the academic privacy of students also makes it difficult to determine how Tokosh was able to move so freely from campus to campus. Both Kent State and Northern Illinois University – where he taught while finishing his doctorate – noted Tokosh’s protected status as a graduate student in declining to answer questions.
Sophie Levan was a freshman at Kent State in 2017 when she encountered Tokosh
column2: then 28
column3: in a Facebook group intended as a gathering place for new students. Tokosh had offered cash to anyone willing to let him paint their faces. Levan
column4: then 18
column5: agreed.

column1: The money was appealing but the interactions soured.
Tokosh
column2: she said
column3: insisted he come pick her up and take her to the building that housed the geography department
column4: where he would paint her face. Uneasy
column5: Levan stopped responding. Tokosh got angry and wouldn’t give up
column6: she said
column7: which led her to file a police report.

column1: “I felt like the school would want to know about it
column2: ” Levan said. “I thought maybe they could prevent anything bad from happening since other girls would go with him.”

column1: She said there was never any followup from campus police – or anyone else.
USA TODAY Network reporters reviewed the experiences of six students who were the subject of Tokosh’s attention going back to his time at Kent State.
In addition to Levan
column2: the other person who reported Tokosh to campus police could not be reached for comment. The two who expressed public concerns on social media told USA TODAY they never heard from their campus officials either.

column1: USA TODAY attempted to reach Tokosh via phone
column2: social media and a certified letter. A person answered a phone call to a number associated with Tokosh
column3: but he hung up after the reporter identified himself. A reporter also reached someone who identified herself as Tokosh’s mother. She said she would pass along that reporters were trying to reach him.

column1: Tokosh told the Nicholls student journalists that he did have an assignment where students were required to paint their faces as part of a cultural exercise. Prior to the article in the student newspaper The Nicholls Worth
column2: the university had already cut Tokosh loose. He said his contract was not renewed because he was the target of a “grade inflation task force.”

column1: The university
column2: however
column3: “does not have any such task force
column4: ” according to Nicholls spokesman Jerad David.

column1: Tokosh also told students the face painting was a requirement in his cultural geography class to better understand other cultures. In a video interview with Hannah Robert
column2: the station manager for the student-run KNSU TV
column3: he says: “That's an assignment in one of my classes where they actually come up with their own face paint and makeup design inspired by a culture and they implement it.”

column1: It’s a well-established trend in the academic world for professors to bounce from one institution to another without having to disclose why they left their last post
column2: said Julie Libarkin
column3: an associate dean at Michigan State University. She has seen the pattern often in her work maintaining a database of publicly documented sexual misconduct by faculty and staff.

column1: As for grad students? Libarkin said people have requested she add them to her list
column2: but universities’ conservative interpretations of the law get in the way.

column1: “I don’t on purpose
column2: ” she said
column3: “because that’s information that almost never comes out.”

column1: Tokosh arrived at Kent State in 2015 with bachelor’s and master’s degrees in geography from Indiana University of Pennsylvania
column2: according to his curriculum vitae. He was working toward his doctorate and researched fading businesses. His work about shopping malls in the Rust Belt won several awards. Like many graduate students
column3: he also taught classes.

column1: Then
column2: Tokosh started showing up in the Facebook groups for new students. In a December 2017 post
column3: an account under the name “Joe Tokosh” posted several pictures of women made up to look like clowns or skulls.

column1: “If anyone is looking for some extra cash
column2: I am looking for people to practice facepainting on!” he wrote. “I will literally pay you!”

column1: Those are the types of posts that caught Levan’s eye. Not only was she pressed for cash
column2: she was interested in movie makeup and thought the face painting could be fun based on the photos Tokosh had posted. But Levan said she soon realized that those images were stock photos and not representative of what Tokosh could do.

column1: What’s more
column2: she figured out that he was a graduate student
column3: a fact she said he didn’t disclose in his posts.

column1: When Tokosh offered to pick her up from her dorm
column2: she refused. But
column3: she said
column4: Tokosh kept insisting she agreed to participate. Levan stopped responding to his messages and filed a police report with the Kent State police in January 2018. They advised her only to stop talking to Tokosh
column5: she said
column6: and let them know if “anything of consequence occurred.”

column1: Months after she refused to meet up and filed the police report
column2: Tokosh texted a picture of himself wearing white face paint to her cellphone. It arrived at midnight and contained no message
column3: although writing on his shirt read: “I'm not a failure.”

column1: “There was some negative intention with sending that photo
column2: ” Levan said. “It’s definitely burned into my mind.”

column1: What Levan didn’t know is that campus police had been put on notice a year earlier when another student filed a similar report. That student told police Tokosh reached out to her and her friends after they posted their numbers on a Facebook group for undergraduates. He would send “get to know you” messages
column2: the police report said
column3: and then ask the student if she was “interested in having her face painted for one of his class projects.”

column1: When she found out Tokosh was a graduate student
column2: she said no and eventually blocked him on Facebook and Snapchat
column3: according to the report. Tokosh continued to text her.

column1: “She does not have any concerns for her safety
column2: but just wanted this documented
column3: ” the police report read.

column1: In July 2017
column2: another student had retweeted a message from Kent State’s Twitter account that asked for Kent State love stories. She wrote: “A geography professor requested me on facebook and asked if he could paint my face like a clown.”

column1: The student confirmed to USA TODAY that the professor was Tokosh and shared a screenshot of a Facebook friend request he sent her. She said she suspected Tokosh also found her on a freshman Facebook group because she posted there often.
She said she tweeted to draw officials’ attention to it and moved on but now wishes she had reported it officially.
College campuses are supposed to offer students special protections from sexual harassment even when it falls short of criminal behavior. Title IX
column2: often associated with equity in women’s sports
column3: also addresses “sex-based harassment
column4: which encompasses sexual assault and other forms of sexual violence” at schools that receive federal funding.

column1: Colleges infrequently and unevenly enforce the rule
column2: however. A 2022 USA TODAY investigation found just one of every 12
column3: 400 students was suspended in connection with sexual misconduct.

column1: The student who shared her story online said the only response she received was from a graduate student in the geography department
column2: who contacted her on Oct. 1
column3: 2018. In an email
column4: he wrote that he had seen her post and suspected he knew which faculty member had asked her about face painting.

column1: “I brought it to the attention of some of our faculty because I was pretty sure I knew who it was
column2: but they were certain it wasn’t that individual and that you probably just meant geology
column3: ” he wrote.

column1: He went on to reference another student being “approached in (at least by just looking at your tweet) a much more aggressive way.” The grad student asked the undergraduate for more information
column2: but
column3: she told USA TODAY
column4: she didn’t respond. She said she started drafting a reply
column5: but a year had passed. She wanted to move on.

column1: Kent State would not say whether any actions were taken after the students’ reports
column2: but Eric Mansfield
column3: a spokesman for the university
column4: said the police department confirmed that the students who filed police reports were provided with “university resources
column5: which would include other non-criminal avenues to pursue (Counseling Services
column6: Title IX
column7: Center for Sexual and Relationship Violence Services
column8: etc.) as a general police practice.”

column1: Levan does not recall police offering her services
column2: but she said she didn’t want counseling. She wanted Tokosh investigated.

column1: Mansfield also said that the university monitors social media but that colleges “can’t always see or track every mention on social media.”

Police records show that officers did investigate when Tokosh was accused of breaking into geography department offices. A blotter item in the local newspaper shows police obtained an arrest warrant in connection with a third-degree felony burglary charge. Court documents indicate Tokosh pleaded no contest to a theft on Oct. 19
Kent State would not explain what led to Tokosh’s departure during that fall semester. Instead
column2: the university said that since Tokosh was a graduate student
column3: any information about him was protected by the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act. It also would not say whether school officials shared Tokosh’s disciplinary record with other colleges or even if it was standard practice to do so for grad students.

column1: “Due to FERPA
column2: student education records are private
column3: ” said Emily Vincent
column4: a university spokeswoman. “Also
column5: we do not comment on personnel matters.”

column1: When Congress passed FERPA in 1974
column2: its author
column3: Sen. James L. Buckley of New York
column4: said the intent was to protect the academic privacy of students and their families. In more recent years
column5: Buckley has become critical of the law and how schools interpret it. He told the Columbus Dispatch in 2010 that “the law needs to be revamped.”

column1: Survivors of sexual violence and students accuse universities of using the law to avoid negative media coverage. Students with a history of bad behavior may jump from one school to another without the public ever knowing about their histories. Law enforcement records don’t fall under FERPA’s purview
column2: but a wide variety of questionable behavior does.

column1: One case involved Brandon Austin
column2: who was accused of sexual assault at Providence College in 2013 while on the school’s basketball team. But Providence College initially said Austin was suspended for violating the school’s code of student conduct and declined to share further details with the Providence Journal
column3: citing federal privacy laws. Austin denied wrongdoing and was not charged with a crime.

column1: Austin was able to transfer to the University of Oregon
column2: where he was again accused of sexual assault
column3: along with other players. Police investigated the claims
column4: and the local district attorney declined to press charges. The university expelled him anyway but raised FERPA when it declined to release records showing what Oregon knew about the allegations
column5: according to the Oregonian.

column1: LeRoy Rooker was the director of the U.S. Education Department office that oversaw FERPA for more than two decades. Rooker
column2: now a senior fellow with the American Association of Collegiate Registrars and Admissions Officers
column3: said FERPA is not a confidentiality law – it is focused on education records. And it doesn’t apply when a student is “seeking or intending to enroll” at another college.

column1: Therefore
column2: Rooker said
column3: Kent State could have shared information about Tokosh with Northern Illinois.

column1: Rooker also said FERPA would not have prevented Kent State from telling reporters if other universities had inquired about Tokosh
column2: though they could not have disclosed what they shared.

column1: He blamed the overuse of the law on fear of being sued.
“In this litigious age
column2: institutions get a little wonky about whether they will forward
column3: say
column4: disciplinary records
column5: ” Rooker said. “On the other hand
column6: if you have something and you don’t share it when you can and something happens at the next institution
column7: I would say that’s a big liability.”

column1: Backgrounding job applicants has become increasingly complex.
While most U.S. employers conduct background screening
column2: according to trade group data
column3: those inquiries typically focus on criminal history. Social media receives far less attention even though that is where people are most likely to share their unguarded thoughts.

column1: Undertaking a full review of a person’s social media presence is more difficult than just checking an applicant’s Facebook page.
Does an applicant have an account on X
column2: formerly Twitter? How about an account with Discord
column3: an online platform frequented by gamers
column4: where leaked Pentagon documents were recently shared? Or what about a Telegram account
column5: a messaging platform popular among white nationalists? Further complicating things
column6: it’s common on sites like Reddit for users to adopt usernames and describe experiences with little to no ties to reality.

column1: A little digging
column2: however
column3: can turn up a lot of dirt.

column1: Tokosh has a LinkedIn page that includes his teaching stints at Northern Illinois University and Nicholls State University. His time as a student and instructor at Kent State is absent.
For LinkedIn
column2: a custom URL includes a play on his name and his chosen field of study: Joeography. Tokosh would later use that moniker in promotional materials for a class at Nicholls State. That is the same handle used on Reddit by someone with a special interest in face paint.

column1: One post features a video of Tokosh throwing a pie at someone. Other posts mention a “clown fetish.” In a forum titled “Creepy
column2: ” he wrote
column3: “I convince pretty girls to let me paint their faces
column4: ” along with a photo with multiple women in white face paint.

column1: That and other similar posts remained live for years until they were taken down after the Nicholls students published their story in late March.
USA TODAY Network reporters captured screenshots before they disappeared. With dates in 2019
column2: the posts feature a young woman wearing a Kent State T-shirt. The material would have been available to administrators at Northern Illinois before the start of the fall 2019 semester.

column1: Joe King
column2: a spokesman for Northern Illinois
column3: said departments hiring new graduate students are “not required to check social media or investigate a disciplinary history.” He added some departments may reach out to the graduate students’ former advisers.

column1: King said he could not determine if the university was aware of Tokosh’s behavior at Kent State. He said that due to FERPA
column2: he could not share specifics about Tokosh’s time at Northern Illinois
column3: including whether students had complained about him.

column1: But there are signs the behavior continued.

A YouTube account under the name “Joe Tokosh” included at least two videos in 2020 of a man throwing pies at women. One of the videos features a young woman also seen in the screenshots from Tokosh’s Reddit account.
Comments on one from October 2020 read: “You can have a video of her tied up getting pied via cash app.” That video was viewed more than 30
column2: 000 times before it was turned off in late July
column3: around the time a USA TODAY reporter reached out to Tokosh.

column1: A former Northern Illinois State student shared text messages exchanged with Tokosh in which he asked to paint her face on multiple occasions. USA TODAY has agreed not to name her because she is concerned Tokosh might retaliate against her.
In the text messages
column2: Tokosh shared a photo of a young woman in white face paint – an image also posted to the Joeography Reddit account. She said she declined to do it but was aware that other Northern Illinois students had participated.

column1: By fall 2022
column2: when he had moved on to Nicholls
column3: Tokosh revealed to the student that he had required students in his cultural geography class to paint their faces.

column1: The Northern Illinois student asked Tokosh what he did with the photos
column2: and she said he suggested that he might spin them off into a research project someday. She asked
column3: had anyone complained? She said Tokosh responded: Why would they?

column1: Many students would find a reason to complain
column2: as Nicholls State student journalist Sally-Anne Torres learned firsthand. It started in January when one of her fellow reporters picked up an odd rumor: a professor was offering extra credit for students willing to paint their faces like clowns. Initially
column3: Torres dismissed it because it seemed too unusual and there weren’t a lot of leads to follow.

column1: By Feb. 7
column2: university administrators informed Tokosh that his contract would not be renewed
column3: according to an email obtained by USA TODAY via a records request. They gave no reason for the nonrenewal
column4: but on Feb. 12
column5: Tokosh emailed his students that the university was letting him go. He blamed his departure on giving too many A’s.

column1: That seemed suspicious to Torres.
During her reporting
column2: she received a tip about Tokosh’s Reddit posts in which he wrote of his “clown fetish” and how he enlisted his students to participate in it.

column1: “It wasn’t just this innocent thing that a lot of these girls thought it was
column2: ” Torres said. “As a professor or teacher
column3: that is somebody students are supposed to trust. He used his power to ruin that trust and to do these things
column4: and that made me angry for them.”

column1: Torres spoke to six students who shared their experiences with Tokosh. Some
column2: she said
column3: were followed on Twitter by him while others opted into an extra credit assignment he offered.

column1: The women told Torres he sometimes giggled and laughed as they painted their faces in his office.
On March 27
column2: the Nicholls Worth published a story headlined
column3: “Geography professor suspended immediately
column4: students allege sexual harassment.” KNSU TV
column5: a student broadcast network
column6: also aired footage in which Tokosh defended the assignment on camera. That same day
column7: Tokosh submitted his resignation.

column1: The story’s publication prompted other students to come forward about Tokosh and their frustration with the university.

Bradley Price took an online class with Tokosh and said the professor required students to photograph themselves with their faces painted. Price said Tokosh told them the assignment was to help them understand Japanese culture
column2: but then Tokosh offered him bonus points if he could get a female friend to paint her face.

column1: It seemed unusual at the time
column2: Price said
column3: because his friend wasn’t in the class. It became more concerning to him on reading the student newspaper’s report.

column1: “I feel frankly disgusted and disappointed that Nicholls couldn’t do a proper background check on this professor
column2: because this is unacceptable
column3: ” Price said.

column1: Bella Ramos
column2: a junior at Nicholls State who did not take any of Tokosh’s classes
column3: told USA TODAY that someone using the handle @Joeography21 followed her on Twitter in late 2021 and started liking all her selfies.

column1: Ramos learned that the person behind the account was likely a professor at the university. She posted about the behavior in January 2022
column2: but nothing came of it. She also found the Joeography Reddit account. On March 27
column3: the same day the student newspaper published its piece
column4: Ramos posted screenshots of her discoveries on Twitter with the message
column5: “Found a Nicholls state university professor on Reddit.”

column1: “I wish the university had acted sooner because all this information was public on the internet
column2: ” she told USA TODAY.

column1: No one from the university
column2: she said
column3: has ever reached out.

column2: N.H.−Ron DeSantis began a two-day New Hampshire swing Thursday by displaying a revamped campaign style that includes amped-up criticism of Donald Trump.

column1: DeSantis focused on Trump's comments Wednesday criticizing the Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netahnyahu and his government over the war with Hamas
column2: and describing Hezbollah militants as "very smart."

column1: Now is not the time to be attacking our ally, DeSantis told supporters at the New Hampshire State House.
Several Republicans noted that
column2: after the 2020 election
column3: Trump attacked Netanyahu for hailing Biden as the president-elect.

column1: It’s clear he’s angry at Netanyahu for recognizing Trump lost in 2020, said a statement from Never Back Down
column2: a pro-DeSantis political action committee. "Trump puts himself first."

column1: What did Trump say about Netanyahu?Trump blames Netanyahu for Hamas attacks
column2: calls Hezbollah leaders 'very smart'

column1: DeSantis spoke after formally filing for January’s New Hampshire primary
column2: a contest he declared “wide open” despite Trump’s huge lead in polls.

column1: “If you want to change from Trump
column2: I think I’m the best leader
column3: ” DeSantis said
column4: adding that he gives Republicans “the best chance to be able to do well” in a general election.

column1: DeSantis
column2: who has seen his support erode after months of attacks from Trump
column3: has gradually escalated counter-criticism of the former president throughout the campaign. He has been more pointed in recent days
column4: part of a strategy adjustment that includes more interviews with mainstream media outlets.

column1: The Florida governor plans to spend Thursday touring the northern part of the state along with members of his political action committee
column2: Never Back Down.

column1: He is scheduled to participate Friday in traditional events
column2: including a "Politics and Eggs" breakfast hosted by the New Hampshire Institute of Politics.

column1: DeSantis and other Republican candidates are scheduled to address the state Republican Party's "First in the Nation Leadership Summit" in Nashua
column2: N.H. this weekend.

column1: The U.S. government announced it will provide charter flights for American citizens and their immediate families looking to leave Israel.
The flights
column2: which are set to begin on Friday
column3: will operate to locations in Europe where there is more commercial capacity across the Atlantic. U.S. citizens in Israel in need of assistance should complete the crisis intake form at travel.state.gov.

column1: “We are all acutely aware of limited availability right now on commercial flights out of Israel and the demand signal of U.S. citizens who may want to depart. The president has asked his team to ensure we are assisting U.S. citizens who do want to leave Israel in providing them with a safe means of doing that
column2: ” John Kirby
column3: coordinator for strategic communications at the National Security Council said during a White House press briefing Thursday. “We’re also exploring other options to expand the capacity of doing this including exploring whether it’s possible to help Americans leave by land and by sea.”

column1: Kirby said that the State Department is still finalizing details of the plan and did not make more specifics available.

Hi there OnPolitics readers! In less than a year
column2: the 118th Congress has already made history.

column1: There were significant firsts
column2: such as House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries becoming the first Black lawmaker to lead a party in Congress
column3: USA TODAY’s Savannah Kuchar reports.

column1: But the upper and lower chambers have also prompted more offbeat headlines
column2: from marathon votes for House speaker to bribery and fraud charges. Here’s a recap of history-making moments:

column1: Kevin McCarthy's marathon election: A hold-out faction among House Republicans stalled the vote for House speaker for four days − and 15 rounds of voting − in January.

George Santos indicted on fraud charges: The New York Republican faces a 23-count indictment accusing him of stealing campaign donor identities and using their credit cards to for unauthorized charges.
Who wore it best? A minor rule change that allowed for casual dress in the Senate sparked an immediate backlash. Senators went on to pass a resolution codifying a formal dress code for lawmakers.
Gold bars and bribes? Democratic New Jersey Sen. Bob Menendez was indicted last month for a second time
column2: after he and his wife allegedly accepted bribes in the form of cash
column3: a car and gold bars.  He was indicted again today.

column1: Read more here:4 unusual ways this Congress has made history

An Oct. 4 Facebook post (direct link
column2: archive link) claims the sons of two well-known politicians are in legal trouble.

column1: “Tagg Romney & Paul Pelosi
column2: Jr. Children of Mitt Romney and Nancy Pelosi are now under criminal investigation for business dealing in Ukraine’s Bursima Energy (sic)
column3: ” reads the post.  It was later updated to attribute the information to Newsmax.

column1: The post was shared more than 250 times in two days. Another version of the post was shared more than 13
column2: 000 times on X
column3: formerly Twitter.

column1: Follow us on Facebook! Like our page to get updates throughout the day on our latest debunks
This is wrong on multiple fronts. There is no evidence that Tagg Romney or Paul Pelosi Jr. are connected to the Ukrainian energy company Burisma at all. And
column2: accordingly
column3: there is no evidence of any criminal investigation along those lines.

column1: President Joe Biden's son Hunter Biden sat on the board of Burisma from 2014 to 2019. Some Republicans have claimed then-Vice President Joe Biden wrongfully used his power to force the removal of a Ukrainian prosecutor who was investigating the company
column2: but a 2020 Senate investigation found no evidence of wrongdoing on the part of the president.

column1: There is no evidence that the children of Utah Sen. Mitt Romney or former Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi were involved with the company. And there's no evidence of any investigation involving the two.
The Department of Justice has made no announcement of any such investigation
column2: and no credible news outlets have reported on a probe involving Tagg Romney and Paul Pelosi Jr.

column1: There is also no evidence that Newsmax reported on the supposed probe into the two men. Newsmax did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
The Facebook post is a new variation of a long-running claim of ties between Ukraine and the sons of various politicians.
USA TODAY in 2021 debunked the similar claim that Tagg Romney and Paul Pelosi Jr.
column2: as well as the sons of President Joe Biden and former Secretary of State John Kerry
column3: were all on the board of directors for energy companies doing business in Ukraine. Only Hunter Biden has worked for a Ukranian company.

column1: Fact check: Mitt Romney announced he won't seek reelection in 2024
column2: but he's not resigning

column1: Former President Donald Trump tried to connect Mitt Romney to Burisma in 2020 after the senator voted to impeach Trump related to efforts to pressure Ukraine to investigate political rivals in exchange for military aid
column2: as reported by POLITICO. The allegation was made on the grounds that an advisor from Mitt Romney’s 2012 presidential campaign was on the company’s board of directors.

column1: There is no evidence that Tagg Romney or Paul Pelosi
column2: Jr. have worked for Ukrainian companies.

column1: Drew Hammill
column2: Nancy Pelosi's former deputy chief of staff
column3: told USA TODAY in 2020 that claims of a relationship between Paul Pelosi
column4: Jr. and Burisma Holdings were "completely false." USA TODAY reached out to the Department of Justice and the offices of Mitt Romney and Nancy Pelosi for comment but did not receive a response.

column1: Paul Pelosi
column2: Jr.

The attacks came by land
column2: sea
column3: air – and online.

column1: Terror propaganda − violent videos and graphic images of kidnappings and murders of civilians and soldiers that flooded social media from the deadly cross-border incursion into Israel − was a key element in Hamas’ military campaign
column2: said Graham Brookie
column3: senior director of the Atlantic Council’s Digital Forensic Research Lab.

column1: Hamas streamed from the war zone “in closer to real-time than in past conflicts
column2: ” indicating that the online strategy “was an essential part of the overall planning for their attack on Israel” to take advantage of how hyperconnected Israel is with its widespread use of smartphones and social media
column3: Brookie said.

column1: Veterans of conflict zones on Brookie’s team tracking Hamas' digital footprint were struck by the ferocity and volume of the footage
column2: the likes of which he said it had never seen
column3: he said.

column1: The effects could become more grave if Hamas makes good on a threat to broadcast executions of hostages
column2: Brookie said. Some Hamas officials have since walked back the threat.

column1: Spreading propaganda on social media networks – especially those with more lax moderation systems – is a low-cost and highly effective tactic that is increasingly being deployed by terrorist groups
column2: said Colin P. Clarke
column3: director of research at the Soufan Group
column4: a global intelligence and security consultancy.

column1: The videos and images from the deadly attacks posted by Hamas-affiliated accounts were shared by Hamas allies and unwitting participants around the globe
column2: Clarke said.

column1: The tactic is pulled from the playbooks of the Islamic State and al-Qaida
column2: which experts said pioneered the viral form of psychological warfare by livestreaming beheadings and other graphic footage.

column1: “This is the nature of asymmetric warfare – you've got to utilize tools that are going to make you seem bigger and more powerful than you are
column2: ” Clarke said. “For Hamas
column3: it costs them nothing to videotape something and send it out there
column4: and now everyone thinks that they're creeping around every corner.”

column1: Hamas fired off posts from official accounts on the encrypted messaging and social media app Telegram that ricocheted to X
column2: formerly Twitter
column3: and beyond.

column1: Telegram – which allows messaging between users but also has a “Channel” function that works similarly to X – has a long history of being used by terrorists
column2: among them the Islamic State
column3: or ISIS. The platform
column4: often labeled by extremism experts as “Terrorgram
column5: ” is increasingly embraced by domestic extremists in the U.S. in recent years because of its almost nonexistent moderation.

column1: “As soon as something posts on Telegram
column2: we see this crossflow of content to mainstream platforms
column3: either intentionally or just through the oxygen of amplification
column4: ” Brookie said.

column1: X
column2: which gutted its trust and safety teams under new owner Elon Musk
column3: was unprepared for the wave of terror propaganda that then spread to other social media platforms and messaging apps like WhatsApp.

column1: This week
column2: X said it was removing newly created Hamas-affiliated accounts and coordinating with industry peers “to try and prevent terrorist content from being distributed online.” It also recommended that people adjust their sensitive media settings if they don’t want to see disturbing content.

column1: The U.K. summoned social media executives Wednesday to demand platforms remove violent content of the Hamas attacks on Israel.
Telegram and X did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
If social media sites continue to erode guardrails and safeguards
column2: Clarke warned
column3: what is happening today will get worse.

column1: “This is just the facet of what’s called ‘fourth generation warfare
column2: ’ or ‘modern warfare’ in this era
column3: ” he said. “So
column4: whatever the next conflict is
column5: it doesn't really matter
column6: you're going to see this on steroids.”

column1: Once propaganda and disinformation reaches X
column2: the platform is allowing it to be shared and even monetized
column3: a report from the Tech Transparency Project found.

column1: The report
column2: an advance copy of which was provided exclusively to USA TODAY
column3: found several premium subscriber accounts – which pay a fee of $8 a month to the platform – sharing Hamas propaganda including violent and graphic images of the attacks on Israel.

column1: According to the report
column2: some video content appears to violate X’s “violent and hateful entities policy
column3: ” which prohibits promotion of terrorist organizations and their propaganda. It also appears to violate an X policy stating that the platform will remove accounts sharing content produced by terrorists
column4: the report states.

column1: Despite X’s announcement that it was working to remove Hamas-affiliated accounts
column2: TTP researchers "found no evidence that X had restricted the accounts sharing the Hamas attack videos
column3: ” the report says. It also notes that in some cases
column4: X ran advertisements in the comments under the video posts.

column1: The TTP report found several instances of “verified” X users
column2: some with more than 500
column3: 000 followers
column4: spreading uncensored Hamas propaganda videos.

column1: One clip posted to X shows bodycam footage of Hamas militants going room-to-room in an Israeli military base firing automatic weapons. Bloodied bodies lie on the ground in the video
column2: which has been watched more than 60
column3: 000 times.

column1: “It's been nearly 10 years since the Islamic State made heavy use of social media to amplify its propaganda and recruitment efforts. Although some platforms have improved at reducing the spread of Islamic State content
column2: today we see Hamas deploying very similar tactics on X
column3: ” TTP director Katie A Paul told USA TODAY. “The company has monetized the spread of Hamas propaganda despite its clear violations of X policy. X needs to effectively enforce the rules it has on the books as the conflict continues.”

column1: Brookie says social media platforms are being forced to grapple with a multi-front crisis to shield users from terror propaganda
column2: misleading information
column3: hate speech and violent and graphic images and footage.

column1: “The amount of content is going to be more than any team
column2: whether it’s at a platform or a research team like mine
column3: or a journalism outlet or organization could possibly sift through
column4: ” he said. “That changes the frame from who’s doing well to who’s doing the least bad in a hard situation.”

column1: The major platforms are working with the Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism (GIFCT) which was founded by Facebook
column2: Microsoft
column3: X and YouTube in 2017 to prevent terrorists and violent extremists from exploiting digital platforms.

column1: “In this rapidly evolving situation
column2: we continue to work with our members to identify and follow trends in content and activity online related to terrorist and violent extremist actors involved in the offline violence
column3: ” GIFCT said in a statement. “This includes the possibility that a range of terrorist and violent extremist networks and groups may seek to exploit the conflict for their own purposes
column4: as we have seen in past events.”

column1: Facebook
column2: YouTube and TikTok say they have poured resources into moderating content from the Israel-Hamas war.

column1: “After the terrorist attacks by Hamas on Israel on Saturday
column2: we quickly established a special operations center staffed with experts
column3: including fluent Hebrew and Arabic speakers
column4: to closely monitor and respond to this rapidly evolving situation
column5: ” Meta said in a statement.

column1: The major platforms prohibit content produced by terrorist organizations including Hamas as well as footage showing hostages.
