column1: I really like the new Apple Watch Series 9. It reminds me a lot of my Apple Watch Series 8.
I’ve been evaluating the latest smartwatches from Apple
column2: Samsung and Google. And at first blush
column3: separating this year’s models from their predecessors seems a little like deciphering whether that SUV in the parking lot is a 2019 or 2020 Chevy Tahoe.

column1: That’s good news if you splurged for a new smartwatch last fall
column2: because your investment is anything but obsolete. By the same token
column3: there’s more to this year’s models than powder-coated wheel finishes and trim decals. So if you’re considering an upgrade after a few years – or even switching teams – there’s plenty to consider.

column1: Apple and Samsung have turned it up to … 2
column2: 000. That’s 2
column3: 000 nits
column4: a measure of brightness
column5: Which is
column6: like
column7: really bright.

column1: Both the new Apple Watch Series 9 (starting at $399 for 41mm
column2: $529 as tested
column3: 45mm aluminum with LTE) and the Samsung Watch 6 Classic (starting at $369.99 for 43mm
column4: $449.99 as tested
column5: 47mm stainless steel with LTE) are incredibly easy to read – even here
column6: in the extreme desert sun. For some reason
column7: I found the Series 9’s 2
column8: 000-nit display to be somewhat brighter and crisper than the Watch 6 Classic’s 2
column9: 000-nit display.

column1: The Google Pixel Watch 2 (starting at $349.99
column2: $399.99 as tested with LTE) checks in at 1
column3: 000 nits
column4: the same as the inaugural Pixel Watch as well as last year’s offerings from Samsung and Apple. Although it pales in comparison to the 2
column5: 000-nit displays
column6: I can still read the 1
column7: 000-nit screens outside. And if you’re more likely to read a message in Scarsdale than Scottsdale
column8: then the new 2
column9: 000-nit options may not have the same appeal.

column1: Apple Watch Series 9 (iOS)
Apple also upgraded the Watch’s internal processors
column2: which the company credits for a few new features
column3: like “Double Tap.” The Double Tap hand gesture – the Watch detects when you quickly press your thumb and middle fingers together – can help control the device when you can’t reach over with your other hand to answer a call or scan alerts. In my beta-testing of the feature
column4: it worked a lot like “Assistive Touch
column5: ” which Apple introduced two years ago
column6: only a bit snappier.

column1: The added horsepower also gives Siri offline capabilities that improve the voice assistant’s speed and accuracy.
iOS updates again?:Apple is urging everyone to update iPhone and iPad iOS (again). Why you should do it now.
Samsung Galaxy Watch 6 Classic (Android)
A lot of what’s new-and-improved with Samsung’s flagship smartwatch actually comes from Google’s Wear OS
column2: which Samsung recommitted to a couple years ago. The Watch 6 Classic is livelier and more responsive than the Watch 5 Pro
column3: with better graphics for alerts and more engaging apps. And sleep tracking seems to be more reliable
column4: accurate and – as a consequence – relevant.

column1: Although the processor and sensors are largely identical
column2: the Watch 6 Classic is easier to visually identify because Samsung brought back a popular engagement tool: the rotating bezel.

column1: Google Pixel Watch 2 (Android)
The Google offering
column2: available Thursday
column3: endured the most substantial changes year over year
column4: by far. But it is just the second iteration of a formidable undertaking to meld the popular fitness platform from Fitbit
column5: which Google bought four years ago
column6: with the premium Wear OS smartwatch ecosystem. It’s already spawned a worthy contender. But there’s still a lot to do.

column1: The Pixel Watch 2 boasts a new
column2: more accurate heartrate sensor that is much better at tracking vigorous activity. There’s now a temperature sensor as well as cEDA for stress monitoring. It has an upgraded processor and more durable glass. It also runs the new Wear OS 4
column3: just like Samsung’s Watch 6 series.

column1: The Fitbit/Wear mix-and-match journey is most evident when the two platforms have a different approach to the same task. For example
column2: Fitbit’s all-in-one app is at odds with how Wear OS – and other vendors as well
column3: for that matter – on-board and configure hardware. That has made it challenging for Fitbit to add Google features to its devices
column4: just as it has been for Google to add Fitbit’s app to its devices.

column1: It is also making it challenging to swap back and forth between the Pixel Watch 2 and the original Watch or – more difficult – traditional Fitbit devices. I’m juggling three wearables right now – the new Fitbit Charge 6 as well as the two Pixel Watches – and it can be downright aggravating. Conversely
column2: that process is automatic and hassle-free for those swapping Apple or Samsung devices. Samsung’s relative ease at handling the task is particularly illustrative
column3: given that Google’s own Wear OS is managing the handoff.

column1: Through it all
column2: the 41mm Pixel Watch 2 is an attractive
column3: well-built watch with a great health and fitness pedigree. I wish Google would offer two sizes
column4: as Apple and Samsung do. I prefer the beefier
column5: 45mm-47mm options. Hopefully Google will get around to that in future revisions.

column1: I also wish Google would offer better battery life. But I’m not holding my breath.
Online hate surge:Online hate surges after Hamas attacks Israel. Why everyone is blaming social media.
Unfortunately
column2: Big Tech seems content to offer mediocre battery life for their pricey
column3: high-powered smartwatches. Apple has never promised more than a waking day between charges on full power.

column1: That obviously hasn’t hurt Apple – and Samsung has taken a cue. The Watch 6 Classic simply matches Apple battery life
column2: rather than beating it with 36- to 48-hour battery life
column3: as in previous generations.

column1: Most disappointing is Google
column2: which is foregoing Fitbit’s multiday battery legacy by providing up to just 24 hours of power in the Pixel Watch 2.

column1: Multiday battery life would be a major upgrade. It’s not only more convenient. It also makes smartwatches more engaging. For one thing
column2: it dramatically boosts the likelihood of tracking sleep
column3: one of the most crucial health indicators.

column1: Battery life aside
column2: these are three very good watches to choose from. So if you’re kicking the tires on a new model
column3: don’t let the recycled styling dissuade you. The Apple Watch and Samsung Galaxy Watch series are both locked in after years of refinement. And while it’s comparatively early on for the Pixel Watch series
column4: Google has done a good job so far combining two very established platforms.

column1: The concept that we are all computer-generated characters occupying a world as real as the ones gamers explore on their PlayStation consoles isn't exactly a new one.
As far back as 1999
column2: Morpheus was entering "The Matrix" to break Neo and a few other chosen few out of a simulated reality created by advanced machines in order to use humans as an energy source. But as the idea permeates not just the realm of science fiction and popular culture
column3: but academia as well
column4: every now and then a philosopher or physicist has something new to say about it.

column1: That's what happened this week when a physicist at the University of Portsmouth in the United Kingdom proposed that a new law of physics could support the theory that what we see as our reality is in fact a complex virtual simulation running on a cosmic computer. The theory stems from previous research that Dr. Melvin Vopson has conducted looking into whether information has mass.
Any normal person will think, could it be that maybe we already are in some kind of digital virtual reality world? Vopson said in a March video posted on the university's YouTube channel.

It's not farfetched to assume that an advanced civilization or maybe ourselves in the future, we reach the technological level where we can simulate our world or the whole universe and it's indistinguishable from the reality.
Psyche mission
column2: explained:What to know about NASA's long-awaited trip to a strange metal asteroid

column1: The idea that the cosmos runs on quantum codes has existed for years
column2: becoming popularized in academia in 2003 when philosopher Nick Bostrom of the University of Oxford wrote an influential paper about the simulation argument.

column1: In principle
column2: anything can be simulated with a computer with sufficient power. Bostrom argued that for advanced civilizations
column3: such an intricate simulation would be rather easy for those wanting to explore their histories or entertain their children.

column1: The theory is popular among many notable figures
column2: including Elon Musk. The Tesla founder and CEO weighed in at a 2016 conference
column3: stating that in his opinion
column4: the odds that we're living in what he called "base reality" — in other words
column5: the real universe as opposed to a simulated one — are “one in billions.”

column1: So are we not unlike the characters we oversee in the Sims
column2: confined to a superficial
column3: restricted sandbox while more advanced beings are spectators to our existence?

column1: It's hard to say
column2: as the theory is as hard to disprove as it it to prove. In fact
column3: 2020 research authored by David Kipping
column4: an astronomer at Columbia University
column5: found that the odds of us living in a base reality are pretty much 50-50
column6: with the odds only slightly in favor of our universe not being simulated.

column1: NASA UFO reportHow NASA hopes to shift UAP talks 'from sensationalism to science'
Prada in space:Famed Italian fashion house will help design NASA's spacesuits for mission to the moon
Vopson's latest research stems from the abstract concept that information is the fundamental building block of the universe and has both energy and physical mass.
My questions was, where is that information going when the bit is at equilibrium and is stored information? he said in the Youtube video. "Energy can't exist on its own
column2: it needs to be in some form."

column1: It's the belief of Vopson and others working in the field of science known as information physics that our physical reality could be made up of bits of information
column2: which aren't unlike the cells of living organisms that are coded with DNA containing valuable information about themselves.

column1: After studying digital data storage and an RNA genome
column2: Vopson discovered in 2022 that information systems don't appear to conform to the second law of thermodynamics. That law essentially dictates that any naturally occurring process will result in a loss of energy and increase in a system's measure of disorder
column3: or entropy (think of an ice cube that gradually melts when placed in a cup of water at room temperature.)

column1: In fact
column2: Vopson discovered that the entropy in information systems actually decreases
column3: leading him to establish what he calls the second law of information dynamics.

column1: Vopson recently set out to apply the discovery to genetics
column2: cosmology
column3: atomic physics
column4: symmetry and yes
column5: even the simulation hypothesis. Published last week in AIP Advances
column6: Vopson's paper provides an explanation for how the removal of excess information in our universe resembles the process of a computer deleting or compressing unneeded code to save storage space and conserve power.

column1: In short
column2: it's a process he said could support the idea that we may be living in a Matrix-style artificial reality akin to a computer simulation
column3: where we and anything else we perceive is nothing more than a virtual facsimile.

column1: It doesn't prove entirely that, Vopson said in the video. "It underpins the concept through empirical evidence
column2: but it doesn't mean necessarily that is totally the consensus that is happening; it is one possibility."

The movie "Snakes on a Plane" dramatized perhaps the worst things to encounter on a flight
column2: but imagine being stuck on a real-world plane with a swarm of mosquitos.

column1: It happened to a local flight in Mexico
column2: which was delayed for more than two hours from its scheduled departure time of 4:30 p.m.
column3: due to a mosquito infestation
column4: local media reported. Cabin crew and ground staff tried to get the situation under control by spraying mosquito and insect repellent in the cabins. It eventually took off at 6:59 p.m.
column5: according to the flight's history.

column1: The flight
column2: VOI221 operated by Volaris Airlines
column3: was traveling within Mexico from Guadalajara to Mexico City on Friday
column4: October 6
column5: according to Storyful.

column1: Stop clipping your toenails:These are the 'most offensive' airplane behaviors
Don't bring bedbugs back home:How to avoid the bloodsuckers while traveling
Video footage from the incident
column2: recorded by a passenger
column3: shows the airplane's cabin filled with fumes as flight attendants spray insect repellent to counteract the swarm of mosquitoes buzzing around the cabin. The flight appeared to be ready for takeoff
column4: with all passengers seated. Some of them could be heard screaming in the video
column5: while others swatted the insects away.

column1: As the airlines staff sprayed the mosquito repellent
column2: the insects became more agitated reported the local media outlet El Sol de León.

column1: They did not settle down until all the lights were turned off
column2: a passenger told Storyful.

column1: This is not the first time that a swarm of mosquitos attacked a flight taking off from the Guadalajara International Airport. A similar incident took place in 2019. El Sol de León said that the area in which the airport is located is close to contaminated water bodies and vegetation
column2: both of which are ideal breeding grounds for mosquitoes. Favorable weather conditions also contribute to increasing mosquito populations.

column1: Airport authorities have recognized this as a problem
column2: reported El Sol de León
column3: and have taken steps such as draining water
column4: pruning grass and spraying insecticides to curb the problem.

column1: Volaris Airlines did not immediately respond to USA TODAY'S request for a comment.

column1: 2023 was the year of all things pink
column2: thanks to Greta Gerwig's "Barbie"
column3: so it comes as no surprise that a community in Utah made "Barbie" the theme of this year's Halloween
column4: bringing the pink paradise to life in South Jordan
column5: a city approximately 20 miles south of Salt Lake City.

column1: One of my neighbors bought us all tickets for Barbie" and we went to see the movie together. And as we were leaving
column2: we were like
column3: 'Oh my gosh
column4: you guys. Barbie is gonna be the Halloween theme this year'
column5:
Liz Gallegos, one of the people behind the idea and a resident of Daybreak told USA TODAY.
Building upon her idea, Gallegos' neighbor's daughter Miley suggested they turn their neighborhood into Barbieland
column6:
an idea that everyone loved.
Come September, the residents got to work, dressing up their houses in different themes, including the Mojo Dojo Casa house, Pool Party Barbie and Dream House Barbie.
Gallegos said around seven members of the community were already onboard because they saw the movie together and were in on the plan from the beginning. They invited other neighbors to participate as well, ultimately ending up with 18 houses dressed up in the Barbieland theme.
They left no stone unturned, paying attention to even the minutest of details and adding elements from Barbieland including a pool slide, horses, and neon signs that read, “You guys ever think about dying?” and “RIP the patriarchy” tombstones.

What's really special and unique is that most people in Daybreak care a lot about Halloween. We have historically gone pretty big for Halloween. We've had a 'Harry Potter' house

column1: While many elements from Barbieland were incorporated into the setup

column1: Some people were very much into Halloween, and they didn't want to lose sight of it, so they went with themes like haunted Barbie and graveyard Barbie, Kenzie said.
Barbieland is attracting thousands of people
column2: both Gallegos and Bates said

column1: I mean, we knew that people in Daybreak would care because they love Halloween, said Gallegos. "But none of us had any idea that anyone outside of our little neighborhood would care at all."

column3: with people sending in requests to come and see the setup. At least two of the videos hit more than 2 million views on TikTok.

column1: I feel like it's a landmark or something, said Gallegos. "We have people at our house starting at like 8 a.m. even though we usually turn on lights and music around 5:30 p.m. in the evening. During the day we'll just have moms or kids or strollers coming by
column2: but by the late afternoon and early evening
column3: it really starts picking up and between like 6:30 p.m. and 8:30 p.m.
column4: it's just a constant stream of people like every single night
column5: no matter what night of the week it is."

column1: Gallegos said that the local police force was also taken aback by the number of people and traffic jams.
However
column2: Gallegos and her neighbors do not mind the attention or influx of people.

column1: It honestly makes me so happy because there's a lot of really sad stuff in the world right now, Gallegos shared. "It's hard to keep your chin up every day. So
column2: it's nice
column3: happy
column4: small little things that are making people happy."

column1: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis

column2: 200 Israelis and 22 Americans have been killed in recent days

column6: Israel

column1: You know, Hezbollah is very smart - they're all very smart, Trump said at one point.

column1: Several Republicans noted that
column2: after the 2020 election

column1: Democrats denounced Trump’s comments.

Especially now as Israel is fighting back against one of the worst acts of mass murder in the country’s history. This is a time for all of us to stand shoulder to shoulder with Israel against ‘unadulterated evil.’ That’s what the President is doing as commander in chief.”

People on Social Security will receive a much smaller bump of 3.2% in their benefits checks next year
column2: as the cost-of-living adjustment
column3: or COLA
column4: after government data on Thursday showed inflation steadied in September from the prior month.

column1: Annual inflation was 3.7% in September
column2: matching August’s increase but off a 40-year high of 9.1% in June 2022. Without the volatile food and energy sectors
column3: the so-called “core” inflation rate fell to 4.1% from August’s 4.3%.

column1: Although inflation remains about double the Federal Reserve’s 2% target
column2: it remains mostly lower
column3: which means Social Security recipients will see a lower COLA.

column1: The 3.2% increase in 2024 is about one-third of the four-decade-high 8.7% COLA in 2023. And while the hike in benefits remains higher than the 2.6% average over the past 20 years
column2: older adults are pessimistic about their finances and the growing possibility of Social Security benefit cuts
column3: according to the latest retirement survey of 2
column4: 258 people by The Senior Citizens League
column5: a nonprofit seniors group.

column1: Protect your assets: Best high-yield savings accounts of 2023
“Worry that retirement income won’t be enough to cover the cost of essentials in the coming months is a top concern of 56% of survey respondents
column2: ” said Mary Johnson
column3: Social Security and Medicare policy analyst at The Senior Citizens League
column4: in a release. “Social Security benefit cuts are an even bigger concern.”

column1: Various reasons the COLA is falling short include:
◾ Inflation: 68% of older adults say their household expenses remain at least 10% higher than one year ago
column2: although the overall inflation rate has slowed
column3: according to the League’s survey. They said this situation has persisted over the last year.

column1: ◾ Benefit cuts: Nearly 6 out of 10 respondents rank this as their top worry. “Significant numbers of lower-income older households have lost access to some safety net programs over the past 12 months
column2: ” Johnson said.

column1: Some faced a double whammy. The 5.9% and 8.7% COLAs in 2022 and 2023
column2: respectively
column3: boosted incomes just enough to make some ineligible for low-income assistance programs such as supplemental nutrition assistance program
column4: or SNAP (food stamps) and rental assistance
column5: and federal emergency COVID-19 assistance for SNAP and Medicaid ended earlier this year.

column1: ◾ Taxes: Because Social Security recipients received the highest COLA in 40 years in 2023
column2: Johnson expects more beneficiaries to owe federal income taxes on their Social Security benefits for the first time in the upcoming 2024 tax season.

column1: Up to 85% of Social Security benefits can be counted as taxable income when income exceeds certain thresholds. Unlike other parts of the federal income tax code
column2: the income thresholds that subject Social Security benefits to taxation have never been adjusted for inflation. So
column3: as Social Security income increases due to COLAs
column4: both the number of retirees subject to taxation of benefits and the portion of benefits that may be taxable rise.

column2: rent climbs again

column1: A few states want some too:These states want a cut of your Social Security check. Do you live in one of them?
Congress could pass legislation to allow income tax thresholds for taxing Social Security to be adjusted annually for inflation
column2: the same way the IRS adjusts tax brackets.

column1: Here’s an example of what that might mean for someone:
◾ Current law says if an individual’s income is between $25
column4: you may have to pay income tax on up to 50% of benefits
column5: and if it’s more than $34
column7: up to 85% of benefits may be taxable.

column1: ◾ If those thresholds were adjusted for inflation to 2023 dollars
column2: then the individual filing status of $25
column3: 000 would be about $74
column5: and $34
column6: 000 would be about $101
column8: Johnson said.

column1: Congress also could change how the COLA is calculated to better reflect how seniors spend their money.
“If that was the law today
column2: the COLA in 2024 would be higher – about 4.2%
column3: ” Johnson estimates
column4: using the government’s consumer price index for the elderly.

column1: Social Security Administration bases its COLA each year on average annual increases in the consumer price index for urban wage earners and clerical workers from July through September. The index for urban wage earners largely reflects the broad index that the Labor Department releases each month but differs slightly. Last month
column2: while the index remained at 3.7%
column3: the index for urban wage earners was 3.6%.

column1: The Seniors Citizens League uses the most recent inflation data to keep a running projection of what COLA might be next year. September is particularly important because it makes up the final month SSA officially uses to calculate 2024’s COLA.
About 70 million Americans receive benefits from programs administered by SSA
column2: with retired workers and their dependents accounting for 76.9% of benefits paid in 2022.

column1: Nearly 9 out of 10 people aged 65 and older received a Social Security benefit as of Dec. 31. Among them
column2: 12% of men and 15% of women rely on Social Security for 90% or more of their income.

column1: In August
column2: the average monthly check for Social Security beneficiaries was $1
column4: according to SSA. A 3.2% COLA would mean about an extra $54.58 each month.

column1: The new COLA will be effective starting in January.

column1: A person was arrested late Thursday morning after he exchanged gunfire with police officers in a small town in Minnesota. Parties on both sides sustaining injuries

column1: The Benton County Sheriff's Office posted on Facebook that officers with the Sherburne County Drug Task Force were shot while executing a search warrant in a Benton County home

Three task force officers from the Sherburne County Sheriff's Office wounded at the scene

column1: Robbinsdale Police Capt. John Elder told the Associated Press the three injured officers are at a hospital in Robbinsdale and the other two are in a St. Cloud hospital. He said none of the injuries appeared to be life-threatening.

Cardi B crying while eating a painfully spicy chicken wing. Jack Harlow dodging a pointed question about his type while sipping a juice box. Mark Cuban attempting a Pittsburgh accent.
If you've kept up with celebrity media tours over the last few years
column2: you've likely come across interview shows like "Hot Ones
column3: hosted by Sean Evans; The Really Good Podcast" by Bobbi Althoff (next interviewing Scarlett Johansson); or Amelia Dimoldenberg's "Chicken Shop Date." Though these shows' setups vary
column4: their strategy seems the same: Place a celebrity in an extremely awkward situation and capture as many candid moments as possible.

column1: Cringeworthy clips from these shows regularly go viral on TikTok and Instagram
column2: begging the question: What is it about celebrities and excruciating awkwardness that makes us feel like we can't look away?

column1: There's a reason we are obsessed with this, and much of it has to do with the fact that, whether we mean to or not, we put celebrities on a pedestal, says Henna Pryor
column2: a workplace performance expert and author of "Good Awkward: How to Embrace the Embarrassing and Celebrate the Cringe to Become The Bravest You." "From where we sit
column3: they tend to be extremely good looking
column4: extremely successful. They've got talent that drips from the sky … There's something very relatable and real about seeing them in their element and remembering they're human."

column1: Pryor defines awkwardness as the emotion experienced when the person we believe we are isn't the person who is being perceived.
This gap between the idea of the self versus the true self is especially compelling when observed in celebrities
column2: she says
column3: because we feel we're getting a glimpse into who a star really is behind their carefully crafted persona.

column1: For a moment in time, that external reality doesn't match the identity we painted for them, and we find that fascinating, she says.
Ty Tashiro
column2: a psychologist and author of "Awkward: The Science of Why We’re Socially Awkward and Why That’s Awesome
column3:
says awkwardness can also be instructional and therefore captivating. By watching other people's social blunders, he says, we learn what not to do.
It's a great opportunity for us to learn about social life and social expectations and social behavior without having to risk any of our social capital
column4: he says. It's a real advantage to be able to learn vicariously from watching other people's awkward moments."

column1: People love seeing celebrities in uncomfortable situations in particular
column2: he says
column3: because of a phenomenon called downward social comparison. Tashiro describes this as feeling better about oneself from seeing another person feel worse.

column1: Hot Ones, which shows celebrities struggling to eat chicken wings dipped in extraordinarily spicy hot sauce
column2: capitalizes on this to great effect
column3: he says.

column1: At that moment, we're actually doing better than the celebrity is, he says. "Something feels a little bit extra sweet about that."
In case you missed it:Justin Timberlake dishes on iconic 'It's gonna be me' meme on NSYNC's 'Hot Ones'
Though intentionally awkward interviews may appear to put celebrities in an unflattering light
column2: they actually do just the opposite
column3: says Ellen Hendriksen
column4: a clinical psychologist and author of "How to Be Yourself: Quiet Your Inner Critic and Rise Above Social Anxiety." By showing their awkward side
column5: celebrities give the impression of vulnerability
column6: which endears them to fans even more.

column1: As a result
column2: a sweaty interview over hot wings may do more to bolster a celebrity's public profile than a traditional news interview.

column1: When the guests put themselves in these situations and are either sweating profusely or trying to get through this super awkward interview, it's vulnerable, Hendriksen says. "What they're doing is signaling we are the same
column2: the celebrity and the viewers
column3: because who among us hasn't tried to play it cool or act casual when we're suffering a little? Who hasn't been stuck in an awkward conversation that has no graceful way out?"

column1: Awkward interviews are also more prone to go viral
column2: because they fit into the unfiltered aesthetic that's currently popular on social media.

column1: We went through a very perfectionistic, self-presentational phase, Hendriksen says. "The Gen-Z aesthetic is deliberately weird and ugly and cringe-y as the pendulum just swings the other way. I think we're all sick of perfection and want to see some authenticity."
Whether cringe interviews are a passing fad or here to say remains to be seen; regardless
column2: Tashiro hopes that
column3: in the meantime
column4: they can empower all of us to abandon perfection and embrace our true selves − even if doing so feels a little awkward.

column1: There's so much pressure in celebrity culture or even influencer culture these days to present this perfect self to the rest of the world. As we know, a lot of people really suffer under that kind of pressure, he says. "I think it's great
column2: whether it's in these shows or podcasts
column3: to create these more genuine and real moments."

column1: As schools and parents contend with uncomfortable and increasingly unavoidable truths about persistent learning loss
column2: new data out Thursday points to a key source of the problem: Scores of students have in recent years missed so much school that catching up seems nearly impossible.

column1: The U.S. Education Department data
column2: analyzed by Attendance Works and Johns Hopkins University’s Everyone Graduates Center
column3: shows that in the 2021-22 school year
column4: 2 in 3 students attended schools with high or extreme levels of chronic absence. Chronic absence typically refers to missing at least 10% of the school year
column5: and the analysis considers a school’s levels to be high or extreme if at least a fifth of its students are chronically absent.

column1: Overall
column2: roughly 30% of students were chronically absent during the 2021-22 year. It was an era still reeling from the devastation of COVID-19 – quarantines were frequent
column3: health needs were vast and hardship was widespread.

column1: Going to school was hard during COVID.Why aren’t kids (or teachers) returning to class?
But as in-depth reporting by USA TODAY revealed earlier this year
column2: attendance challenges persisted into the subsequent school year – the one that was
column3: at long last
column4: supposed to feel normal. A separate recent analysis by Attendance Works of 11 states’ data found only a slight decline in chronic absence from 2021-22 to 2022-23. Last school year
column5: 28% of those state’s students were chronically absent
column6: down from 30% the year prior.

column1: “An unprecedented wave of chronic absenteeism has spread across the country
column2: ” the analysis notes. “Not only is teaching and learning more challenging when large numbers of students are frequently missing class
column3: such elevated levels of chronic absence can easily overwhelm a school’s capacity to respond.”

column1: Kids who are chronically absent have lower odds of graduating and
column2: especially when they miss school in the early grades
column3: of learning how to read. And while chronic absence generally is more common at the high school level
column4: the latest report shows the increases were especially pronounced at elementary schools.

column1: The rate jumped from 7% in 2017-18 to 38% in 2021-22. In fact
column2: the number of elementary schools with extreme levels of chronic absence – more than 30% of kids missing 10% of the year – far exceeded that of high schools.

column1: Which kids missed class during COVID?We asked
column2: and shools don’t know.

column1: The U.S. Olympic & Paralympic Committee has begun a process to send financial assistance to Mary Lou Retton

column1: “Upon learning of Mary Lou's condition

column1: Retton

column1: PHOENIX − Mookie Betts

column1: Betts was on his way out the clubhouse door when he turned around. There was Dodgers manager Dave Roberts. They wrapped their arms around each other

column1: They spoke for a few seconds
column2: and with Roberts’ office occupied by members of the Dodgers' front office
column3: he pointed towards the stairs

column1: They stood by the indoor batting cage
column2: just the two of them
column3: and talked privately
column4: spending exactly five minutes trying to make sense out what just transpired
column5: trying to wrap their minds around the fact they were just swept out of the playoffs by the Arizona Diamondbacks. But there were no answers.

column1: We talked about the game, Betts told USA TODAY Sports as he walked out of the clubhouse for the final time this season. "We talked about what we could have done different. I don’t know

column1: The Diamondbacks completed their sweep with a 4-2 victory over the Dodgers in front of a sellout crowd of 48
column2: 175 at Chase Field
column3: sending Arizona to the NLCS for the first time since 2007. But the three-game sweep doesn’t come close to adequately describing just how lopsided this series was from first pitch to last.

column1: The Dodgers never led a single inning. They trailed in 25 of the 27 innings. They were outscored by a score of 19-6.
The Dodgers were down 6-0 in the first inning of Game 1.
They were down 3-0 in the first inning of Game 2.
And they were down 4-0 in the third inning of Game 3 with the Diamondbacks setting a postseason record by hitting four homers in the inning.
As far as the power goes, I’ve never seen something like that before, D-backs manager Torey Lovullo said. "It was almost unbelievable
column2: right?"

column1: It was an ugly beatdown in every conceivable way.
We were embarrassed by the way the whole series went, Dodgers infielder/outfielder Enrique Hernandez said. "They kept punching us in the face
column2: and we were unable to get back up. There’s not a lot of words other than I’m hurt. Disappointed. Frustrated. And a little bit embarrassed."

column1: No team is going to win a series when its starters last a total of 4 ⅔ innings. The Dodgers rotation yielded a 20.25 ERA
column2: allowing a .571 batting average with a 1.808 OPS. It was the fewest innings by a starting rotation in the first three games of a postseason in history.

column1: The Diamondbacks hit nine home runs in the series
column2: including 1
column3: 626 feet worth of homers in the fourth inning alone
column4: while the Dodgers hit just one. The Dodgers
column5: who scored more than 900 runs for the first time since the franchise was in Brooklyn
column6: never scored more than two runs in any game.

column1: The most astonishing stat of the entire series was that Betts and Freddie Freeman

column1: It’s hard to find words right now, Freeman said. "Frustrating. Me and a lot of us didn’t play the way we wanted to. We didn’t do it for three days. Not good by us."

column1: This is a team that has won 211 regular season games the past two years

The USA TODAY Opinion section publishes analysis
column2: argument and essays on a wide variety of subjects. We're looking for timeliness (pegged to news)
column3: persuasion pitched to the other side
column4: new information
column5: novel arguments
column6: revelatory insights
column7: passion without partisanship
column8: first-person experience
column9: original reporting that reveals fresh angles and makes news
column11: and/or a topic that will drive conversation on social media and in the real world.

column1: We accept only pieces that are submitted exclusively to USA TODAY. We do not accept material that has been published on blogs
column2: social media or anywhere else.

column1: Columns typically run 550 to 750 words. They should be pasted directly into an email and sent to theforum@usatoday.com. Pieces should include links (URLs
column2: not headlines or footnotes) to back up quotes and factual material. People featured in columns must be identified by their real
column3: full names.

column1: We do not publish open letters
column2: class projects or material that has been submitted to multiple outlets. Rebuttals to editorials and columns published in USA TODAY should be submitted as letters to the editor
column3: not as full-length op-eds.

column1: Due to the volume of submissions
column2: we can’t respond to all columns sent to us. If our Opinion team is interested in yours
column3: you will hear from us within three business days.

column1: Submissions may be edited for accuracy
column2: clarity
column3: style
column4: standards and length.

column1: Please include with your submission a short biography
column2: two sentences at most
column3: to run at the end of your column
column4: as well as a current photograph
column5: to which you own publishing rights. If you or a business
column6: trade group or other institution with which you are associated stands to gain financially or in any other way from your column
column7: you should disclose that information in detail. In most cases
column8: it should also be included in the body of the piece or in the author's biographical information.

column1: Columns are accepted for online publication; print publication is not guaranteed. All columns published by USA TODAY are available for use online and in print by the more than 250 properties in the USA TODAY Network. They include Austin; Bergen County
column2: New Jersey; Burlington
column3: Vermont; Cincinnati; Columbus
column4: Ohio; Des Moines; Detroit; El Paso
column5: Texas; Indianapolis; Louisville
column6: Kentucky; Memphis
column7: Tennessee; Milwaukee; Nashville
column8: Tennessee; Phoenix
column9: Reno

column1: Authors may post their columns elsewhere 48 hours after they are published at USA TODAY. By submitting a column to USA TODAY and agreeing to its publication
column2: authors are granting exclusive rights to the piece to the USA TODAY Network for 48 hours and non-exclusive rights thereafter.

column1: To get a sense of our range
column2: preferences and requirements
column3: check out our op-ed section
column4: follow us on Twitter and Facebook
column5: or sign up for our daily Opinion newsletter.

column1: If you're interested in joining conversations about topics in USA TODAY
column2: email letters@usatoday.com
column3: comment on Facebook or use #tellusatoday on Twitter.

column1: Letters are edited for accuracy
column2: clarity and length and to conform to our editorial style and standards. Submissions of 200 words or fewer have the best chance of being published. Letters must include a name
column3: address and phone number.

column1: Corrections to published letters or columns follow USA TODAY guidelines.
